1.content:
Ravenscroft Academy is located in upstate Connecticut. To the cowan, it seems like a standard boarding school, with high hedge walls and a gate with voice and vision intercoms to keep out prying eyes. In fact, everyone there, male and female, is a witch, with the adults teaching children aged 11-17 the finer points of witchcraft.

The school proper is composed of five buildings. The central building is the school itself, with classrooms, offices, a gymnasium, and an infirmary.

Flanking the school building are the residence halls. Athame Hall and Wand Hall house the boys, while Cauldron Hall and Chalice Hall house the girls. The doors and windows are magickally shielded, so that persons of the opposite sex can only enter with a special spell that only the faculty members know.

Outside the school are an unpaved courtyard (where Esbats and Sabbats are held) and an Olympic-size swimming pool.

Beyond the school itself, but still on the grounds, are a number of gardens (yielding plants useful for magick) and groves and orchards of nine different trees: apple, birch, fir, hawthorn, hazel, oak, rowan, vine, and willow.

The male and female students have separate headmasters, with the titles Magistra (in charge of the girls) and Magister (in charge of the boys). Currently, Heather Gardner is magistra, while Daniel Cochrane is magister. Professor Elaine Bishop teaches the history of the Craft. Professor Isaac Burroughs teaches spells and incantations. Raymond Carrier is professor of potions and ointments, while Professor Marion Corey teaches elemental studies. Professor Janet Good teaches charms, amulets, and talismans, while Professor Gavin Hobbs is in charge of divination. Professor Selena Wilds is the flight instructor.

There are more conventional subjects, as well. Students learn mathematics from Professor Eleanor Nurse (with so many shapes to draw, geometry is crucial in magick), and Professor Dennis Osborne teaches science (concentrating on botany and geology).

Some students may have a difficult time adjusting to Ravenscroft, so Vanessa Procter is employed as the school guidance counselor. Just 26 years old, Mrs. Procter brings a smiling face and a calm demeanor to help her charges.

The school infirmary, run by Dr. Robert Willard, is practically the school's own hospital, capable of administering to anything from candle burns to broken bones caused by falling off a flying broom, as well as ailments physical and magickal.

The chief groundskeeper's name is Wardwell. I've never heard anyone call him by any other name. He directs the tending of all the plants, and also oversees the guard dogs.

It is something of a tradition for seventh-year students to play pranks on incoming first-years. Teachers are usually willing to let these slide, as long as nobody is harmed, and the pranks do not interfere with schoolwork. The pranks usually peter off after six weeks, and have usually stopped completely by Samhain.

I think that's enough background about the school. Now, here's my story...

11.content:
My name is Alex Weaver. My parents are pretty much the only Wiccans in my neighborhood, so I've gotten used to my friends thinking my family's a little weird. But then one day, I found out exactly how different my family is from the norm.

It was my eleventh birthday. My party had been over for about a half hour, so I was in my room, checking out one of my new books.

Suddenly, Mom came into my room, holding a dowsing rod. "Hey, Mom," I said. "What's up?"

She didn't answer. She just walked around my room with the rod. I wanted to know what she was looking for, but, since she hadn't answered my first question, I didn't think she'd respond.

Finally, Mom came up to me, and the rod twisted in her hand to point at me. Okay, I'll admit, that really got to me, and I finally spoke again. "What's going on? Why are you using a dowsing rod? And why's it pointing at me?"

She sighed. "I wanted to be sure," she said, "before I did anything." Releasing the rod at one end, she held it up. "I was dowsing for something much more significant than water."

"What?"

"Magick."

"Magick?"

"Yes." She sat down on the edge of my bed. "I'm a witch, Alex. And so are you."

"I know we're Wiccans, Mom."

"This isn't just Wicca. I'm talking about actual magick. I can do it. And it seems I've passed the talent on to you."

"You... you mean you and Dad are actual witches?"

"No, Alex. Your father is a cowan, not a witch. That's why I had to test with the dowsing rod. Sometimes, the talent doesn't get passed on, or it skips a generation or two. So, you and I are witches, but your dad isn't."

I tried to wrap my head around this. I was a real witch? "So... what do I do, now?"

"Well," Mom replied, "I'm afraid you won't be going to school with your friends."

That scared me, even more than her saying I was a witch. "Wh... where will I go?"

"We're sending you to Ravenscroft Academy. It's a boarding school for witches. I went there, when I was your age."

"Whoa. Is it anything like Hogwarts?"

"Not really. Your classmates and teachers will all be witches, like yourself. But it's not all like the books and movies."

"Like what?"

"For one thing, you'll be taking a bus. No, the bus isn't magick, unless you think it's magickal for a bus to hold more people than my Prius."

Something else occured to me. "Mom, if we're witches, and Dad isn't, how come he's Wiccan?"

"Years ago, some witches imparted some of our religion to select cowan. That's how they discovered Wicca. We taught it to them, because we saw the dangers of pollution, even before cowan scientists caught on."

"If witches saw the dangers, why didn't we do anything about it?"

"There weren't enough of us. The Burning Times... the witch-hunts... wiped out whole lineages of witches. We had no choice but to try to bring the cowan to embrace our ways. It's our hope that, if enough are touched by our wisdom, we might perhaps turn things around."

"Yeah," I said. "It'd be a shame, if it didn't work. The whole human race, wiped out by their own foolishness, in more ways than one."

Mom kissed me on the forehead, and stood up. "You'll have time to get used to the idea of Ravenscroft. It doesn't start any earlier than cowan school." With that, she left my room.

My name is Winnie Alexander, yeah I've heard all the jokes. I was brought up in an evangelical household, taught to pity those who did not follow the ways of the Good Book, and help those who did understand it better. Due to my parents' strict ways, I was a top grade A student in fifth grade. Still, my family openly disliked me going to a 'public' school.

"You are a cut above the rest, my dear Winnie." said Mom with a certain air of pride. "Therefore, for your eleventh birthday, we are sending you to a boarding school where they will bring out your true potential."

"We are not putting down the public school system, perish the thought." said Dad, smiling. "We merely feel that you can go further with a more... time-honored school, away from the distractions of home."

Thus, they began searching for a strict private school for me to attend. They found one they believed to be the perfect place and, before I knew it, I was given an acceptance letter from Ravenscroft Academy. As Mom read the letter, however, she seemed confused. "Could have sworn I sent her application and references to Ravenscross Academy." she muttered. she then smiled. "It must be a typo on their part, I'm too careful for such elementary mistakes."

She later gave me the acceptance letter. "The bus, taking you to your new home for a while will arrive in two weeks' time, at this precise hour." she said, sternly. "I expect you to be packed and ready to leave when the bus arrives."

"Yes, mom." I said. "I will be packed and ready to leave when the bus arrives two weeks from now, this very hour."

Mom smiled. "That's my girl." she said, smiling. "I will pray for you each night and call you every Saturday before lights out is announced." She smiled, touching my cheek. "You are venturing out on your own, at an early age, I expect to see great things from you."

"Yes, mom." I said.

Mom nodded. "It's bedtime now, get yourself tucked in, I'm turning off the lights."

I quickly crawled into bed as mom then left the room, turning off the lights. "Good night, Winnie." she said.

Once she was gone, a single tear rolled down my face as I whispered, "Please, mom, don't throw me away."

I saw a group of people in front of me. The word 'cowan' flashed through my mind for an unknown reason. "H-Hello?" I said. They didn't seem to notice me, instead they seemed to be waiting for someone. A teenage girl in a violet cloak approached, seeming surprised to see anyone there.

"Blessed be," she said, clutching a book to herself. Book of Shadows, it seemed to whisper to me.

"Why, to meet my coven," the girl answered.

"I'm afraid we can't let you do that."

"Why not?"

The young man raised his hand, and a dagger glinted in the moonlight. Athame. I looked away quickly, and heard the screams of the girl. When they died out, I heard laughter of the group, then, "Let's go find another one."

I sat up quickly, heart beating fast. I clutched the sheets but recognized it was just a nightmare. I sat there, looking up at the moon and waiting for my fear to disappear as the sound of sirens passed by.

124.content:
I didn't sleep well that night, I still couldn't really come to terms with all this. After one of the longest nights of my life, I awoke to the sound of a conversation downstairs. I didn't recognize the man Dad was talking to, but Mom entered my room not long.

"Winnie, there's a man here from your new school. Come down and speak with him."

"Yes, mom." I said.

I got ready and went down to the front room. The man had long-ish black hair, about to his shoulders, a kind smile and pale blue eyes. Blue seemed to be his color, as his suit was a pale blue as well.

"It's good to meet you Ms. Alexander. I'm Andre LeFevre." he said extending his hand.

"Hello, Mr. LeFevre." I said quietly.

"Winnie, he's here from Ravenscross." Dad said, although I already knew that.

"Yes, Ravenscross." Andre said. "An excellent school that makes good use of methods that have been around for quite some time."

There was a twinkle in his eye, like he was making a joke only he understood.

"Mr. LeFevre needs to have you fill out some documents for school." Dad said. "Your mother and I feel you should go alone with him to do this, it will be good practice for school."

"Yes, dad." I said, trying to hide my sadness.

"If it's alright with you, I'd like to get going right away. It may take some time." Andre said.

"Of course. Best to get started early." Mom said.

I quietly followed Andre to his car, and waved to my parents as we pulled out of the driveway. I was silent in the car as well, although Andre wouldn't have that for long.

"So, Winnie, how do you feel about all this? Boarding school at Ravenscroft I mean." he asked.

"Ravenscroft? Don't you mean Ravenscross?" I asked.

"Oh, right. That's what I meant."

"I think it's a great opportunity for me to expand my academic abilities." I said, giving the line I'd had to rehearse.

"I didn't ask how your parents thought about it, I asked how you felt Winnie." Andre said.

I started to protest, but I realized he was right.

"Honestly, I feel like I'm being thrown away. Like my parents don't want me around anymore." I said, barely holding back tears.

"Isn't this where you're supposed to say that that's not it at all, that my parents love me and would never try to get rid of me?" I asked after Andre remained silent.

"Winnie, I don't know what your parent's motives are. If I were to say what you want to hear I would be lying. And I will never lie to you Winnie, I promise that. Do you understand?" he said.

"Yes, I understand." I said, still not quite satisfied.

"Good. We're here as it is." he said as we pulled up to a fairly average looking brick building. He lead me through the front door and into one of the only doors visible from there. This room had another man sitting at a desk, frowning at some papers. He looked up when we entered, and he gave us a tired smile in greeting.

"You must be Winnie Alexander. I'm Mr. Pentral." he said. "Please, have a seat."

"Do you work at Ravenscross too?" I asked.

"Ravenscross?" he said, unsure what I meant.

"It was the name on the sign up form, instead of Ravenscroft." Andre said, taking the seat to my right.

"I see. That's a new one." Mr. Pental commented.

"I don't understand, what's going on?" I asked, really starting to get scared. Who were these men, and what was Ravenscroft?

"Winnie, I need you to remain calm as I explain this, alright?" Mr. Pentral said.

I nodded.

"Good. First and foremost, there is no Ravenscross. Or if there is, it isn't around here. The boarding school you will be attending is called Ravenscroft." he said.

"Why did they use a different name?" I asked.

Mr. Pentral was silent for a moment, before finally answering.

"Winnie, tell me everything you know about witches and witchcraft." he said.

I was a more than a little surprised by the request.

"I don't know much, other then they worship the devil. I've heard of some evil things they can do, but my parents never gave me details." I said.

Andre leaned back in his chair, like my answer disappointed him. Mr. Pentral looked like he was expecting it, but still didn't like it.

"All lies, though it's hardly your fault for believing them. Your parents have been feeding you those falsehoods your entire life." Mr. Pentral said.

"What do you meant?" I asked, getting more confused as the conversation went on.

"Let me inform you of the truth, Winnie. Witchcraft has nothing to do with the devil. Literally nothing, they don't even believe in a devil, much less worship one. Secondly, most of the things you hear about what witches are capable of are very untrue. Witchcraft is a very subtle form of magic, or magick with a 'k' to use the proper term. You'll learn more about that in the coming months."

I didn't know what to say at first.

"Are- are you a witch?" I asked him.

"No, I'm not. The most magic I do is in a D&D session, though knowing your parents you likely don't know about that either, which is a true shame. Mr. LeFevre, however, is indeed a witch."

I turned to Andre in shock, and he gave his kind smile in return.

"Rather out of practice I'm afraid." he said sadly. "That's part of the reason we wanted to talk to you before you left for Ravenscroft."

"Wait, how does Ravenscroft fit into all this?" I asked.

"Ravenscroft is an academy for witches, but there's a problem there." Mr. Pentral said.

"If it's an academy for witches, why am I going there?! Even if everything I was ever told about witchcraft is wrong, I'm still not a witch myself! Why am I going there?" I shouted. I was so confused I didn't know what I was doing.

"Winnie, please." Mr. Pentral replied. "I know this is overwhelming now, but things will be made clear in time. You must remain calm, lives are on the line."

I couldn't respond even if I had something to say, so he continued.

"Understand, Winnie, that witches have been persecuted for centuries, and they still are even today. And sometimes persecution is fatal. An organization, known as The Inquisitors, has been killing witches in the area, and we have reason to believe that they have infiltrated Ravenscroft. If that is true, then everyone there is in mortal danger. But you can help us find the moles, and stop this threat. I know you have very mixed feelings about this, but can you really condemn innocent people to be murdered for any reason?"

"No. I can't. I may not agree with everything witches believe, but I can't live with myself if I know people will have died because of me." I said.

"Good, I knew you'd do the right thing." Mr. Pentral said with a smile. "Now, a few things for you to do. First and foremost, your parents must not know anything about this. They must believe that you are attending a private, fundamentalist boarding school called Ravenscross. It shouldn't be too hard, I know you're forced to hide your true emotions around them anyway. Secondly, you'll need these."

He reached into his desk and handed me a small book and something with cloth wrapping on it.

"Don't open that package until you get to Ravenscroft, and you won't need the book until then either. Keep them well hidden." he said. "Finally, when you reach Ravenscroft, find Vanessa Proctor. She will explain everything in more detail than I can."

"Ok, I will." I said.

"Good. Winnie it's very brave of you to do this, helping to save the lives of people you barely know. Andre will take you home now. Goodbye, and good luck." Mr. Pentral said.

I barely remember anything past that. The drive back with Andre, meeting Dad at home, apparently Mom was out for a while. She was always organizing events in town, so she would be gone for stretches of time. I went back up to my room and collapsed onto my bed.
124.title: I have a strange visitor.

125.content:
Two weeks passed faster than I would have preferred them to and I found myself pushed onto a bus as dad placed my luggage into the cargo compartments on the side. "Make your family proud, Winnie." said mom in her usual stern tone. "Our prayers are with you, always."

"When you return home, you will be a fine woman." added dad, walking up to mom's side. "You will be able to live life on your own, start a family and raise your children, to the standards we had taught you."

I took my seat with a heavy heart, feeling uncomfortable as I waved to my parents as the bus drove off. Once they were our of sight, I sighed. "I can't believe they just threw me away like that." I muttered.

"Don't take it so hard." said a girl, sitting across from me. "Ravenscroft is not a bad school, this is my second year there and I'm having a blast, learning magick." she paused, extending her hand as my eyes widened. "I'm Jenny Wilkins."

"I... I'm sorry, Jenny." I said, stunned. "Did... did you say Ravenscroft? Also, I thought I heard you say magick?"

Jenny nodded. "Of course, they teach all the normal classes as well." she said. "Only, I like magick the most."

I swallowed hard, realized that a mistake had been made somewhere as mom and dad had specifically told me I would be attending Ravenscross boarding school. Still, I looked at Jenny with an air of pity, as I had been raised. "I am Winnie." I said quickly. "Jenny, I don't know what you had been told but nothing good will come of using magick." I paused, looking about to ensure I was not embarrassing her then quietly added, "Walk away from it now and embrace the Good Lord while you still can."

Jenny grinned. "Ah, you come from an evangelical family." she said, quietly as well. "I wonder why you are being sent to Ravenscroft." she shrugged. "Well, prepare yourself, Winnie, you are in for a shock."

I turned away from Jenny, saying. "I intend to correct that mistake the moment I arrive."

The rest of the bus ride was uncomfortable for me as I tried to keep the Lord's Prayer running through my head for 'protection' from the approaching devil's gates. A few hours later, we arrived at an ordinary looking boarding school. As I had read in the papers mom gave me, the school proper was composed of five buildings. The central building was the school itself, with classrooms, offices, a gymnasium, and an infirmary.

Flanking the school building were the residence halls. Athame Hall and Wand Hall housed the boys, while Cauldron Hall and Chalice Hall housed the girls. As the bus came to a stop and we were all ushered off, Jenny turned to me and said, "Good luck, whatever you decide, Winnie."

"Thank you." I replied. "The same to you, may God be with you."

"Blessed be." said Jenny before walking off.

"New students, form two lines, boys and girls!" announced a tall and powerful looking man. "I am Wardwell, grounds keeper, I will lead you to your orientations!"

"Excuse me, err, Wardwell." I said, speaking up. "I believe there has been a mistake in my transfer papers. I am supposed to attend Ravenscross boarding school, not this... establishment."

Wardwell looked down at me with gentle blue eyes as he pushed aside his longish brown hair. "You will have the chance to discuss this clerical error with Heather Gardner, the Magistra." he said. he then turned to the group. "If there are there no other comments, please follow me!"

The group, separated by boy and girl followed Wardwell into the main building where he took them to two offices, one on each side of a wide hall. "Girls, you will form a line to the right, the boys to the left!" he said, clearly. "You will each be given a brief orientation where all of your questions and concerns will be quickly but efficiently addressed by the Magistra to the girls and Magister to the boys.." he paused, smiling at the two groups who seemed nervous. "Relax, I don't bite."

With that, he walked away and the two doors opened with two voices stating, "One at a time, please enter!"

I was the first in line, as I had an issue with being at the school and walked into a luxuriously decorated office with a crystal chandelier hanging from the center of the ceiling. It glowed beautifully as I walked under it. "Welcome, Miss Alexander." said a tall, slender woman with long black hair and deep green eyes. "I am Heather Gardner, the Magistra, or headmistress of the girls at this school."

"It's a pleasure to meet you, madam Gardner." I said. "There seems to be an error here."

Heather rose a single eyebrow. "Oh, what is this error you speak of?" she asked.

"I was told that I would be attending Ravencross girls boarding school, not Ravenscroft." I said. "I would like this mistake to be cleared up as quickly as possible."

"I see." said Heather, giving the chandelier a quick glance. "I am afraid that there is no error here." she turned to pull a file from her drawer and placed a folder in front of you. "Your mother was quite insistent that you attend school here, you can read it for yourself."

I opened the file and read mom's letter to the school, my face turning more pale with each line. "Why has mom forsaken me by sending me to a school of magick?" I asked aloud. "She had always told me that it was the Devil's work, and yet she sends me here."

I felt as if I was going to be sick as the depth of my situation began to sink in. I wanted to scream, to run, but I found myself unable to move and began to wonder if it was too late for me. "God, preserve me as I walk the valley of the dead!" I whispered, sobbing. "Please forgive my parents for their blasphemy for they know not the horror they had committed!"

Heather sighed. "I believe I will have you speak with Vanessa Procter, our school counselor." she said. "Welcome to Ravenscroft Academy,... blessed be."

Before I could respond, I found myself in another room, sitting in another luxuriously decorated office, facing as young and attractive woman, sitting behind a small desk. "Welcome, Miss Alexander." she said, kindly in a melodious tone. she looked at a file in front of her. "I see we have much to discuss...."
125.title: I am thrown among the 'demons'.

1251.content:
I swallowed hard. "Y-you are Miss Procter?"

"Mrs." she replied. "What seems to be the problem?"

"There are many problems, Mrs. Procter. I was supposed to be sent to Ravenscross, not Ravenscroft. Actually, I'm still getting over being sent to a boarding school, in the first place. And, once I get here, I find that you're teaching deviltry?!" I fell down, crying.

I heard Mrs. Procter get up from behind her desk and come around to my side. Then, she placed a hand on my shoulder. "All will be well, Miss Alexander," she said. "I don't know about this Ravenscross business, but I can assure you, devil worship is not on the curriculum. Most of us do not even believe in your Devil."

"All the same," I said, "it's clear that I don't belong here, and I must go."

"I'm afraid that would be most irresponsible of us."

I picked my head up out of my hands. "What?"

Mrs. Procter made eye contact with me. Her face was serious. "Do you remember the chandelier in the Magistra's office?"

"Yes," I said. "It seemed to light up when I entered the room."

"Those were no ordinary lights," she said. "Those crystals are enchanted, to respond to magickal potential. The magistra writes that the crystals were quite bright when you were beneath them."

"Wh-what does that mean?"

"It means, child, that you are, indeed, a witch. One of great potential. To send you out into the world, with no idea how to control or direct your magick, would be like placing a butcher knife in a baby's crib. It's not a question of if someone would be hurt, but who, and how badly."

My heart was in my throat. "I... I'm a witch?"

She nodded. "You are, indeed. And, as you can tell, no demons were involved in your being so." She looked at my file again. "Do you prefer Winifred?"

I shook my head. "Mom and Dad always called me Winnie."

"Winnie, I don't understand your full history. But it's clear to me that, whatever your mother's intentions, it is good that you are here. We can teach you about your abilities, help you find your potential. Will you let us help you?" She held out her hand.

It felt like my spirit was broken. "It doesn't seem like I have much choice."

"I'd prefer it," Mrs. Procter said, "if you phrase that more positively."

I placed my hand in hers. "Yes. Yes, I'll let you help me."

"Splendid. And, if you have a particularly thorny problem, or if you just need a friendly ear, my door is always open. Bright blessings, Winnie."

I left her office, still reeling from what she told me. How could I be a witch? And what did this mean for me?

125111.content:
"Nobody said you were evil."

I turned. "Who are you?"

She offered your hand. "I'm Tanith Leigh, your new roommate."

I politely shook her hand. "Winnie."

"Yeah, I heard. Guess you don't know too much about magick, huh?"

"I was raised to believe witches were evil."

"Yowtch. I guess this is kind of a culture shock, then. Let's get into our school uniforms, and then I'll give you a primer."

I found my uniform on the bed. "How many do we get?"

"Six," Tanith replied. "Five for school days, plus a backup. You have to wear them on school grounds, or during field trips. They'll wash them, and repair them if needed, but it's five demerits if you go beyond normal wear and tear."

The uniform consisted of a royal blue blazer with the Ravenscroft crest over the left breast, a dark gray skirt, a white blouse, and a red tie with black and silver stripes. It didn't take us long to get dressed.

"Now that that's done," Tanith said, pulling out a trunk, "I'll show you my tools, so you'll know what you need." She unwrapped a black-handled dagger from a silk cloth, and held it up. "This is an athame. We use it to draw magick circles, and pentagrams in the air. We also use it for cutting plants."

"Not human sacrifices?"

"No, silly. In fact, we have to be careful handling them. If it draws even a drop of blood, it'll just be a knife."

Next, she did the same with a goblet. "This is a chalice. When we drink during Sabbats, we'll use this. Both it and the athame are used in the Great Rite."

"Great Rite?"

She nodded. "The chalice is filled with juice, then we stick the athame into it."

"Your parents are okay with that?"

"It's just symbolic, silly old bear. It's not like there's any real sex involved."

Like I said, I've heard all the jokes about my name. Tanith, though, seemed to have a way of saying that without sucking all the affection out of it, and I smiled. "All right. What else?"

"There's your wand, of course. I've got a 'starter wand', but they'll teach you to carve your own. They say that, that way, you impart more of yourself into it, making it that much stronger.

"Then we have the cauldron. I've got a small one, for travel. You can brew potions in it, or light a fire in it, to burn something else safely."

"That's everything?"

"Almost." She pulled a necklace from under her blouse. "A pentagram. It's for protection."

"I've got all the protection I need," I said, showing her my gold cross.

She smirked, like I'd gotten it from a cereal box. "There's something important you should know, Winnie. It's kind of a tradition, here, for the sevent-year students to play pranks on the first-years. There's nothing personal, and the teachers let it go, as long as it doesn't interfere with schoolwork. But it can feel rough. Two years ago, my older sister had to spend a day weighing 200 pounds. And she didn't call attention to herself the first day."

I winced, thinking about how I'd acted once I stepped off the bus. I started giving serious thought to getting a pentagram. Maybe a little more protection wouldn't hurt.
125111.title: Nobody thinks you're evil

1251111.content:
That night, I had a terrible dream. I dreamed that I was being burned at the stake. When I looked at my accusers, they were Mom and Dad. The more I begged them, the louder they screamed, "Burn the witch!" As the flames rose, I could hear the barking of dogs.

When I opened my eyes, I wasn't immediately sure I was awake, because I could still hear the dogs. I realized they were real when I saw that Tanith was awakened by them, too.

"Let's see what's up," she said. I was no less curious, so we covered our nightgowns and went looking.

As we set out, it seemed like everyone at Cauldron Hall had heard the dogs. Fortunately, Tanith and I were near the front, so we got a great view of what was going on.

Somebody had scaled the hedge, and was now being questioned by the magistra. "Why have you come?"

"I'm a reporter," he replied. "I aim to find out what this school is about. Why are you so selective, and so secretive?"

"We have our reasons," she responded. "As for you, you should have come at a more civilized hour. I trust your mistake will not be repeated." With that, Wardwell led him to the gate.

I shivered as I walked back to my room. "I don't know what would have happened," I said, "if he'd seen what this school is like."

"I do," Tanith said. "My sister told me about it. That guy got off lucky."

"What happened?"

"According to my sister, the last reporter to pull a stunt like that... is now one of Wardwell's guard dogs."
1251111.title: A dream, and a disturbance

12511111.content:
The first thing I did, after showering and getting dressed, I asked Tanith to take me to the school store where I purchased a protection necklace to go with my golden cross. Of course, I placed a small jewel between the two, just in case the two objects touching might offend others.

http://www.wiccanway.com/assets/images/p...

"Bless me, Father, for I am about to enter a phase of my life where nothing is certain." I whispered, putting my necklace back on with the two powers of protection. "Guide and protect me as I walk the unlit path to my unknown future."

Tanith grinned as I finished my prayer. "Ready for breakfast?" she asked.

I nodded and she led me to the cafeteria. It was large, as far as most school cafeterias but this one was more like a self serve bar with a variety of different foods to choose from. "Just grab a plate and take what you like." said Tanith. "It's all paid for through your tuition and yearly education fees, which your parents pay in advance."

I nodded, hoping that the money was sent here instead of Ravenscross. After getting myself a large salad and a juice drink, Tanith led me to a secluded seat and we began to enjoy our meal. "Just keep an eye open for mischief, Winnie." she said, quietly. "As I had told you, the seventh year students like to play pranks on the first day."

I nodded then gave a quick prayer, thanking God for my meal, then added, "May the union of these two symbols aid me in my quest to understanding and acceptance as I discover myself again... Amen."

It was at that moment, I heard a low chuckle and just knew someone was going to try to cast a spell on me. I was not sure if it was a warning from the two symbols on my necklace or just woman's intuition but I quickly turned to Tanith and whispered, "Get down!"

Tanith, seeing what was coming, ducked at the same time I did, narrowly missing something as it hit the wall and bounced back. We looked up to a loud moan and laughter to see a boy in his late teens wearing a bear suit with the boys uniform over it. "This is embarrassing." he muttered. "How did she see it coming?"

I tried not to giggle but I responded with, "Maybe next time you should chuckle after you cast your spell."

This brought on more laughter as the boy left the room, blushing. Once he was gone, Tanith placed a hand onto my shoulder, smiling. "Well played." she said. "The others will think twice before trying anything but I'd remain on guard."

I nodded, hoping that the boy who tried to prank me does not take his defeat personally.
12511111.title: Breakfast

125111112.content:
As the laughter died down, Tanith and I went back to eating. "I hope I didn't offend you by saying grace," I said.

"It's your way," she replied. "I was saying my own grace, anyway."

"You were? I thought - "

She put up a hand. "I'm not Christian, but I am grateful for what I receive. I didn't thank your God, but I thanked the cook who prepared the food, the farmer who nurtured it, and the animals who died so that I could have sustenance."

We finished eating, then went to dump our trash. As I walked, I had that peculiar feeling again. I knew someone was about to play a magickal joke on me, but I had no idea from where.

Suddenly, I felt some form of energy strike me, and I fell on my face. Tanith ran around me. "Give me your hand."

I did, and she pulled me up. "I think I'm okay," I said.

"Just take a moment," she replied, "to get your bearings."

I wondered what she meant, then I caught sight of something, on the edge of my vision. It was white and feathery. No matter where I turned, I couldn't quite see it.

"On your back."

I reached, and realized what had happened. I now sported a pair of wings, like an angel.

As the crowd laughed at my predicament, I sensed another prank in the offing...
125111112.title: More prank attempts.

1251111121.content:
I had already been hit with one prank, that was enough. I felt I had to put my foot down as I turned and extended my hand with the palm open flat. I felt something hit it as I did then saw, or thought I saw, a small burst of energy as whatever it was had been blocked. I turned to where the spell came from and spotted a table of four older teenage boys, who were all looking at me in surprise. "I am pleased you see me as an angel, gentlemen." I said, kindly. "Only, have you heard?"

"Hear what?" asked one of the boys, a small grin forming on his face.

I smiled back. "It's never wise to risk an angel's wrath."

With that said, I gave a quick mental prayer, hoping my call would be heard and threw my arms up. A strong gust of wind blew into the cafeteria, and my new wings spread in reaction. This startled the other first years as they stared at me, not knowing whether to run or stay. The sky outside seemed to go dark as thunder was heard before I lowered my hands, pointing at the four boys. "Repent and sin no more!" I said in a voice, much lower than I thought possible for me.

That was all the first years needed to flee the cafeteria as the other, older students looked at me uncertainly. Only, before anything else could happen, I heard someone snap their fingers behind me before I fell into darkness.

I was only out for a few minutes but it seemed like hours as I felt completely drained. "What happened?" I asked, trying to get up. "Arrgh!, my head!"

Then a soft hand touched my chest and gently pushed me back down. "Rest, child." said a sweet voice. "You had quite the first day." I heard the woman giggle. "I must say, the seventh year students are already talking about you, they seem to be impressed . Don't be surprised if one asks you to the upcoming ball."

Then, I heard someone else enter and I slowly opened my eyes to see...
1251111121.title: Block it

12511111212.content:
"Mrs. Procter?" I asked, seeing her.

Vanessa smiled as she sat down in a chair next to the the bed I was on. "I heard you had your first experience with magick during breakfast today." she said. "I also heard you threw a prank back... one that caused quite a disturbance."

"Yeah, one guy tried to, err, magickally put me in a bear suit." I replied, blushing. "I managed to dodge that and it bounced back to him, now he's wearing it."

A young man then came into my line of sight, chuckling. "I wondered what had happened that poor boy." he said. "I am Dr. Robert Willard, head of the Infirmary. Professor Isaac Burroughs, who teaches spells and incantations, brought you here." he paused, becoming serious. "You were very pale, young lady."

Vanessa nodded. "Burroughs summoned me, saying that your illusion spell was unusually powerful for a first year." she said. "We will need to work on your focus... you nearly drained yourself completely with that stunt."

"I had to do something, Mrs Procter." I protested, fighting the pounding in my head. "Three pranks were thrown at me in less than an hour, I cannot be expected to take it lying down."

"No one is asking you to, my dear." said Vanessa, calmly. "The staff is usually willing to let these pranks and counter pranks slide, as long as nobody is harmed, and the pranks do not interfere with schoolwork." she sighed. "Your counter prank, though harmless, frightened a lot of other first years into a panic... I am going to be very busy today."

"Fortunately, no one was hurt when they ran out of the cafeteria, screaming." said Dr. Willard. "However, the screams were heard throughout the first floor, disrupting the teachers and students during orientation."

"So it was Professor Burroughs I heard snapping his fingers." I muttered.

Vanessa nodded. "I know you are still weak but you must go through your orientation before nightfall." she said.

"You are free to go, Miss Alexander." said Dr. Willard. "Blessed be."

As I walked, or rather stumbled out of the infirmary, I found Tanith waiting for me in the hall. "Easy there." she said, helping to hold me steady. "Let's get your orientation done quickly so I can take you back to the dorm."

"Please." I said. "Apparently, I don't know my own 'strength'."

Tanith giggled. "Come on, you silly old bear."
12511111212.title: Vanessa Procter.

125111112122.content:
Orientation over, we returned to the dorm. "So," Tanith asked me, "what do you think so far?"

"I think I can get around fairly well," I said. "I'm glad you and I will be sharing most of our classes."

"In a way," she said, "your upbringing has managed your expectations. It seems like half the kids expect the staircases to move around."

I smiled slightly. "I guess there's some benefit to not being allowed to read Harry Potter."

"Wait a minute,... how'd you know that was from Harry Potter?"

My smile got wider. "One night, my parents were out of town, and I saw it on cable. Don't tell anybody, but I kind of liked it."

"It's a popular series, Winnie. There's no shame in liking it."

"I wasn't talking about the movie, Tanith. I mean, I liked watching it, but I also liked... doing something that was against the rules."

Tanith hugged me. "We'll make a witch of you yet, Winnie Alexander. Which reminds me, I got you something." She opened the closet door and handed me something. "Ta-da!"

"Thanks. What is it?"

"It's a robe. You'll need it for Sabbats."

"Sabbats? I don't remember that class."

She shook her head. "A Sabbat is one of eight important witch holidays. The next one is Mabon, the Fall Equinox, just a few days away.We'll gather in the courtyard."

I started to feel a little nervous. "What should I wear... under the robe?"

"You go barefoot, if that's what you mean."

I sighed with relief. "That's okay. I was scared you'd say I had to be naked."

She laughed. "You don't go skyclad at this school, silly old bear. At least, not in the open."
125111112122.title: Back to the dorm.

1251111121221.content:
We decided to hang out for a while in the common room at Cauldron Hall. It was there that I learned what Tanith meant. With just us girls around, some of the older students chose to walk around the Hall stark naked. I hardly knew where to look. I certainly couldn't imagine myself parading about in my birthday suit.

I caught sight of a girl, about 13 or 14, sitting by the fireplace. The odd thing was, she was trying to conceal the huge grin on her face. If it weren't for her age, I'd think she'd been on the receiving end of a hex prank.

I wasn't the only one to notice her. I guess some of the teachers live in the Halls as well, and one of them approached the grinning girl. "What is your name?" she asked.

The girl stopped grinning, and was now clearly nervous. "Umm, Penelope... Cruise."

The teacher shook her head. "There is no such student here, at your current grade level." She pulled out her wand and placed it on the girl's lips. "Who... are... you?"

Now the girl seemed to struggle to keep her mouth shut, and I knew the teacher had cast a spell. Finally, she blurted, "Chris Ostermeyer. I'm at Wand Hall."

The teacher nodded. "I think you've seen enough, Chris. Off you go. Vanarbi."

As Chris left the Hall, I walked up to the teacher. "Ma'am, what did you say to her... him, just before he left?"

She giggled. "Oh,... just something to show him, for the next week, what a mistake he'd made, trying to sneak in here."

Hearing that, a fifth-year girl ran up to her room. She returned, bearing a crystal ball. "Let's see what that sneak's comeuppance was."

All the students gathered around the crystal ball, as an image formed of a young boy, apparently Chris, as he began to undress. I shielded my eyes, afraid of what would happen to me if I saw a boy naked.

When the other girls squealed, though, I opened my eyes, and saw his front was completely flat. "He looks like a Ken doll!" Tanith laughed.

As the image faded, one girl asked, "What do you suppose is gonna happen to him now?"

"I'm sure Professor Wilds didn't hurt him," another replied. "Though he might come in for some teasing, especially if that truth spell hasn't worn off."
1251111121221.title: An unfamiliar face

12511111212212.content:
The next morning, we went to breakfast. As we made our way to a table, a few of the first-years flinched at the sight of me, and a lot of them kept their eyes on me as I ate.

I was glad to see Mrs. Procter in the cafeteria, and happier still when she sat down to join us. "How are you two doing?"

"I guess I can't complain," I said. "I just wish they'd react this way to the warlocks who started it."

"Witches," Mrs. Procter corrected.

Tanith agreed. "'Warlock' is a hate word."

"I'm sorry," I said. "I didn't know."

Mrs. Procter nodded. "The original, war loga, means 'oath-breaker', and, by extension, 'liar'. When your enemies wish people to view you a certain way, they begin with words."

"Mrs. Procter," I asked, "is there any way to... to take away my magick?"

"Why would you want to do that, Winnie?"

"It's too scary. I'm afraid I'll hurt somebody."

She placed her hand on mine. "Tell me, Winnie,... how do you feel about electricity?"

"Huh?"

"Well," she explained, "the same electricity that makes the lights come on, can be used to kill. Would you ask that all the power plants be shut down?"

"Of course not."

She nodded. "And magick is the same way. We cannot control how you use it beyond these walls, but we can show you how to direct it, to prevent people from being hurt unnecessarily. All we ask is your cooperation."

I nodded. "I'll try, Mrs. Procter, if for no other reason than to keep me from using magick accidentally."
12511111212212.title: Next day, at breakfast

125111112122121.content:
Tanith and I reached our first class early to find that we were the first ones there. Standing behind a large desk was a tall, muscular man with short black hair and brown eyes. He smiled at us and said in a booming voice, "Enter, if you dare where screams are heard in the dark corners of our lair."

Tanith shivered at that, as did I only, for some reason, I remembered hearing the phrase somewhere and recited, "Drink from the cauldron and rest ye well, soon to join the others, trapped within our spell."

"Winnie?" surprised, Tanith asked. "Are you okay?"

"It's a poetic warning I saw in my grandmother's diary." thinking back, I said. "She had told me that it was to frighten away the curious so they would not suffer a cruel fate."

"You are partially correct, Miss Alexander." said the man. "I am Professor Isaac Burroughs. Please enter, I don't bite."

We walked into the room and took a seat near the front of the class. "Was the cryptic warning used to keep the curious away from the witch academy?" curious, Tanith asked.

"Yes, it was." simply, Issac replied. "Only it was excluded when this academy was built as people these days see such warnings as a challenge." he chuckled. "Enough of that, though. In this class, you will be learning how to properly use, detect, and combat magick."

"I learned early that using magick is quite draining." wincing, I said.

Issac smiled. "Yes, you made quite an impression on this school the other day." amused, he said. "I find it ironic that someone who fears magick so much carries such a great potential." I blushed at that as he added, "A fear of magick means you will not abuse it. A respect for magick means you will use it wisely."

It was then other students began to pile in, taking their seats. Many of them eyed me with some uncertainty, making me feel as if I had to speak up. "I am Winne Alexander, a first year, like all of you." standing up, I said. "You can relax, I won't bite you."

A few of the students smiled as Issac chuckled...
125111112122121.title: Spells and Incantations class

choices: go to the ball with him.
1251111121221211.content:
"To ease all of your fears and warn others, I do not tolerate magickal pranks of any kind in my class," serious, Professor Burroughs said. "Those who try to pull a prank on any of you during class will wish they had not." He paused, smiling, as footfalls were heard moving from the door.

"The seventh years target first years during class?" worried, I asked.

"It's forbidden to do so," serious, he replied. "Some see it as a challenge." His smile returned, "They only make that mistake once. Now, let us begin. Potion making is not too much unlike chemistry but it involves more than just simply mixing ingredients."

"It likely involves precise measurements and temperature," said a girl sitting behind me. "Also, a knowledge of what order to add the ingredients."

"You are close, Miss Child," nodding, the teacher said. "However, it also involves a catalyst, a magickal spark. Otherwise, it's just simple chemistry."

"Only adding too much or too little could lead to disaster," I guessed. "Am I correct, professor?"

He nodded. "Yes, that is correct," he patiently replied. "However, I would appreciate if you two allowed me to teach the class."

I blushed at that and fell silent, as he smiled and continued his lecture.

The rest of the class went smoothly, with Professor Burroughs warning us all to keep what potions we make for his class safely locked up in our provided lockers. As I left the class, an older girl, a seventh year student, approached me. At first, I suspected another prank attempt, but she instead took a neutral pose. "Blessed be, Miss Alexander," smiling, she said. "I am Anna Gale, and my brother asked me to talk to you."

"What about?" on guard, I asked.

Anna smiled and replied, "Understand, my brother is rather shy. He wanted me to ask if you would... "
1251111121221211.title: Class begins.

12511111212212111.content:
Hearing that, I looked past Anna to see a young gentleman my age, nervously looking at me from behind a tree, not too far away. I could not help smile as he caught my eye and hid behind the tree. "I am not going to bite you, young man." Bemused, I called out. "Come forth and know me better."

Anna smiled before turning and motioning her brother forward which he reluctantly did. "My-My name is Andy Gale." Shyly, he said. "Please... it- it would be an honor to escort you to the Mabon ball this weekend."

I had seen Andy in all of my classes though we never really talked. He was the most shy person I had ever met. I would dare say he was almost frightened to be in the classes we attended as I was at first.

"I am flattered, Andy." Giving a curtsy, I replied. "Have you found..." I stopped myself short, blushing then asked, "Have you found the courage to look me in the eye?"

Andy jolted his head up, blushing as well. "Of- Of course... sorry."

I saw Andy fumbling with something hanging around his neck and smiled as i realized it was a Christian Cross. I turned to Anna to see her discretely show a cross of her own with a bemused smile on her face. "There is good in everything on this Earth." Whispering, she said. "That includes magick."

I giggled, relief in my mind, and turned to Andy. "There is nothing to be sorry for." Bemused, I said. "I would be delighted to go to the ball with you."

Andy looked at me, surprised but beamed with joy as I showed him my own cross. "Here I thought my sister and I were alone." Tearing up, he muttered.

"You are never alone with God, Andy." smiling, I said. "Meet me outside Cauldron Hall at the fifth afternoon hour."

Andy smiled more. "I will be there."

He nodded, and I gave a curtsy in return before he ran off, as if he were floating on air. "He has been struggling to build up the courage to ask you from the first moment he saw you." Smiling, Anna said. "Thank you for giving him a chance."

I smiled. "Thank you for showing me I have nothing to fear."

Anna returned my smile. "Blessed be, Winnie Alexander."
12511111212212111.title: go to the ball with him.

choices: A woman visits to see my trunk.
I search for Ravenscroft on the web.
13.content:
My name is Nico Child. Go ahead, laugh, see what it gets you. I'm a child genius, you might say. I have a love for science, mathematics, and especially chemistry. Those who laugh at my name find a nasty surprise when I pour a little concoction into their milk or soda while they are not looking. I gave one annoying girl, the head cheerleader, uncontrollable acne for a few days when she called me a little cat girl, making fun of my name. However, upon my eleventh birthday, near the end of summer vacation, I received an acceptance letter from some boarding school called Ravenscroft. At first I thought it was a mistake, so I questioned my parents, was I in for a surprise....

"That acceptance letter is no mistake, young man." said mom, sternly. "You are going to that boarding school for your own good, and that is final."

"Hardly, mom." I countered, to her annoyance. "I am exceeding all expectations of my school and receiving offers to attend other schools to help their students." I smiled. "Maybe you two are planning a cruise, hmmm? Planning to add to the family, are we?"

Mom and dad were not impressed. "Your revenge pranks at school, whether or not you believe they are justified, can no longer be tolerated." said dad, sternly. "You are being sent to a school that will teach you control of your gifts!"

"My gifts?" I asked, confused.. "No offense, dad, but I could ace college. If it is my pranks that are pushing you both to this decision, I can back off."

"Nico, we are not talking about your academic gifts." said mom. "You see, I am a witch and so is your father."

"A witch?" I asked, with a slight chuckle. "Surely you jest."

Mom grinned as she retrieved a narrow rod from the folds of her dress and pointed it at me before asking, "How else would you explain your unusual fashion sense?"

I looked down and screamed as my normal school uniform, pants, shirt, and blazer, had been replaced with girls' uniform, skirt, blouse, and blazer. "What the Nyuk!" I yelled.

Mom and dad laughed, as 'Nyuk' was a made up curse word I used so not to get in trouble. "As I told you, Nico." said mom, changing my clothes back to normal. "I am a witch and so is your dad. We are sending you to Ravenscroft to help you control your magick powers." she smiled, slightly proudly. "You leave this coming Saturday, I'll help you pack."

"Will I be allowed to bring my chemistry trunk?" I asked. "I don't feel at home without it."

Dad shrugged, knowing my chemistry trunk was no larger than a small footlocker. "We'll have someone come to look it over tomorrow morning." he said. "If this person approves, fine, you can take it. If not, it stays here."
13.title: Nico Child

choices: Mom laughs, which she doesn't do very much at all.
Another witch comes (male) and doesn't look trustworthy.
131.content:
The next morning, a black limousine arrived outside our house. I gasped at the sight of it. We hopped in the back (with my chemistry trunk) and the driver turned around to check on us. I was struck by her beauty.

"Everything OK?" she asked. This must be what mom called a " witch". Doesn't look too bad. Then she started up the limo, and we took off.

When we got to Ravenscroft, I gasped. We were looking at the oldest building I had ever seen.

When we got out, all the witches looked at us. "There is a newcomer!" hissed a beautiful witch. "Is he the one of prophecy?"

"I foretell not," my mom said. "I see another with the Strong Magick."

The witches all gasped. "Professor Pollyanna!" exclaimed the first witch.

"That's right, Slyvestia, I'm back," mom replied.

"You always remember all our names," the witch named Slyvestia laughed. "Good to have you back, Professor."
131.title: Arriving at Ravenscroft.

132.content:
The next morning, as promised, Dad escorted a woman to my room. "Blessed be, Nico," she said. "My name is Alyssa, I understand there's a question regarding a possession of yours?"

I nodded. "My chemistry trunk." I opened it up for her.

She started checking out everything I had in the trunk. Oddly, not only did she examine the labels, but she also held this little crystal near the bottles. "What does this do?" she asked of a particular bottle.

"If you drink it," I replied, "it turns your urine blue for the rest of the day."

"Why would you want to do that?"

"It's not for me. I use it on people who give me a hard time, like this one jock last year. Scared the Nyuk out of him and his family."

"Interesting," she said. "And what would you do, if you didn't know who was doing it?"

"I can usually pick out a decent suspect," I replied.

"And, if you guess wrongly?"

That brought me up short. I hadn't thought of that before.

A slight smile crossed her face. "Perhaps you should hope that, if you challenge the wrong person at Ravenscroft, she or he will be more forgiving." She closed the trunk and stood. "I see nothing intrinsically wrong with this trunk, or its contents. Although it may compete for space with other things you'll need at Ravenscroft. Good day, Nico."

After she left my room, I secretly followed her, to hear what she said to my parents. "How'd it go?" Dad asked.

"It's just an ordinary chemistry set," she replied.

"I'm worried," Mom said, "about what would happen, if he started playing his pranks at Ravenscroft."

"I'd be worried, too. The seventh-years will eat that boy alive!" Alyssa said, giggling.
132.title: A woman visits to see my trunk.

1322.content:
That Saturday, Mom flew with me to Connecticut, and saw me off when the bus came. "Bright blessings, Nico," she said, hugging me.

"'Bye, Mom," I replied, squirming. I mean, I wasn't the only kid waiting for the bus, and the guys were watching.

The bus pulled away, leaving Mom to wait for her return flight. Luckily, none of the others were in a talkative mood, so I grabbed the chance to take a nap.

As I slept, I dreamed it was back when Mom and Dad first told me about Ravenscroft. I laughed off the notion of them being witches, and Mom responded by turning my shirt and pants into a blouse and skirt.

In the dream, though, Dad smiled. "I think you're onto something, dear," he said. He pulled out a wand of his own and pointed it at me. It flashed.

When my vision cleared, I first thought nothing had changed. It wasn't long, however, before I caught sight of the long hair that was now growing from my head.

I looked down. The front of my blouse was just barely being pushed out by my budding breasts. I lifted my skirt, and saw that the front of my panties was now perfectly flat. Dad had turned me into a girl!

"Interesting," Mom said. "What do you think, Nico?"

I smiled. "I love it! Thanks, Daddy!" The three of us laughed and played...

... Until somebody shook my shoulder. "Dude," he said, "wake up. We're here."

I wiped the sleep out of my eyes, noting with regret that I was still a boy.
1322.title: The bus to Ravenscroft

choices: changed my clothes back to normal.
13221.content:
Upon stepping off the bus, I looked up to see a towering man with a bushy mustache and beard, wearing black robes with dark pants and shirt beneath. The very sight of him made me shiver.

"New students, form two lines, boys and girls!" announced the man. "I am Wardwell, grounds keeper, I will lead you all to your orientations! Do not wander or fall behind, you will not like the results!"

That made my heart skip a beat, remembering what I had heard my mom and dad say to woman who had visited our home to inspect my chemistry trunk. 'The seventh years will eat him alive!' I considered myself safe, being third in line, and followed Wardwell with an air of confidence. That confidence left me as I felt a breeze in my nether regions, followed by a number of giggles from the girls. "Dude, look down." said the boy behind me.

I did so and screamed, seeing that I was now wearing the girls' school uniform, to which everyone burst into laughter, causing Wardwell to stop and turn around. Seeing me, he shook his head and pulled out a narrow wand from the folds of his robe and pointed to someone out of my line of sight. "Tyler Cohan, you know the rules!" he barked. "No pranks are tolerated before orientations!"

"My humblest apologies, sir Wardwell." said Tyler with a low bow. "My wand slipped."

"You will not like what happens when I allow my wand to slip, young man." Wardwell stated, unimpressed.

Tyler rose his hands, chuckling. "The spell wears off in a day, he'll live." he said, smiling. "If 'she' asks nicely, I might reverse it now."

Wardwell turned a slight shade of red, his patience growing thin. "I'm warning you, Cohan." he said.

"Allow me, sir." I said, grinning.

Wardwell shrugged. "Very well."

I stepped out of line, feeling the skirt rubbing against my legs and looked Tyler in the eye. "That's not a bad trick." I said, pulling a small cylinder out of my now feminine blazer. "Try this, from me, its a gas!"

With that, I sprayed a thick smoke from the canister into Tyler's face, covering my mouth with my free hand and stepped back as he coughed, breathing it in. "You little twerp!" he raged. he screamed as his voice was considerably higher, much like that of a girl. "What did you do to me!?"

I laughed, along with Wardwell and my fellow first year students. "If you want the antidote for that new feminine voice of yours," I said, folding my arms, "change my clothes back to normal."

Tyler looked down at me, anger flashing in his eyes before he...
13221.title: Orientation

choices: later, introduced to my new dorm
132211.content:
.. muttered "I don't need anything from you or your pathetic chemisty set. Hope you like the girls' dorms, jerk, casue thats where you'll be spending the year" Tyler sneered, as I felt my body twist into a form much more suited to my uniform.

I looked at the other students in a mixture of horror and embrassment, but surprisingly, there was very little laughter. I didn't know it then, but the boys were thinking of how easily it could have been them that suffered my fate. As for the girls, they had wry smiles on their faces.

The only person that was completely passive was Wardwell. He just ignored my sudden gender switch, at least at first. "Miss Child. Can you go to the other line, thanks?"

I looked at him in annoyance. "Can you do something about this" I demanded, pointing to my now feminine body.

"No. It is not wise to counter a spell used in anger or to counter it so soon. You'll be staying in the girls' dorm until Mr Cohan decides to remove his spell" Wardwell said, to my horror. The horror spread quickly to the other first years, as they realized they'll be fair game to others soon. "However, you get to decide what is done to Mr Cohan."

"I'll think about it" I said, as I noticed another seventh year student guide me to the girls' line. She gave me a small smile, before leaving. I tried not to look at the other first year girls, and I felt that they felt a little awkward at looking at me.
132211.title: changed me into a girl!

1322112.content:
Once I had a good idea of the layout of the school, I was directed to Chalice Hall, which would be my dorm, at least until Tyler Cohan decided to change me back. I set my things on a bed, sat down, and sighed.

How could all this have happened? I had half-convinced myself that I must have imagined Mom changing my clothes back home, but this was completely different. Somehow, in a way science could not explain, I had been turned into a girl.

There was a knock on the door, and another girl came in. She looked to be about 14 or 15. "Blessed be," she said. "I'm Rachel Downs. I'm your new roommate."

I shook her hand. "Nico Child. Is it usual to place older girls with new students?"

"Huh?" Then she looked at herself and laughed. "No, I'm just an early bloomer. I'm eleven, just like you. Don't worry, you'll catch up to me in your own time. In fact, in some ways, you'll probably surpass me. My doctor says that I may keep developing for a few years, but I've probably maxed out at 5-foot-4."

"We'll see." I wasn't sure why she spoke to me that way. Didn't she notice what had happened to me earlier in the day? All the same, for some reason, I couldn't help but imagine myself looking like her in a few years.

There came another knock. "Who is it?" I asked.
1322112.title: later, introduced to my new dorm

13221121.content:
"Blessed be, Miss Child." said a young woman, entering the room. "I am Mrs. Vanessa Proter, the guidance counselor for Ravenscroft." She giggled. "I heard you were having a new experience."

"You could say that." I replied with a sigh. "Why are seventh year students allowed to attack the first year students?"

Vanessa smiled. "It was not an attack, at first, just a harmless prank." she said, patiently. "You insisted you could handle the situation on your own, then openly challenged Mr. Cohan with a counter prank, using your chemistry."

"So, if I had remained silent, the spell would have been lifted?" I asked.

Vanessa nodded. "We normally overlook such pranks as long as no one is injured and it does not disrupt any of the school functions." she explained. "Orientation is a school function, Cohan would have been forced to return your clothes to normal and been given a reprimand for his actions." she paused. "Have you decided on Cohan's punishment for disrupting your first school year here?"

I grunted. "He can keep that feminine voice for as long as I have this feminine body." I replied. "The effect does not wear off until the antidote is given, and I doubt it's a good idea to mix magic with my science."

Vanessa sighed. "I would have to agree with you." she said. "Very well, I will inform the Magister of your decision and he will inform Mr. Cohan." she then smiled. "If you have any problems adjusting to being a girl, just ask your roommate. She had to help her older brother adjust last year when he accidentally botched a spell, sealing his own fate as her new little sister."

Rachel giggled. "She restarts school next year." she said. "That's why I was bunked with you, so to help you adjust until you change back... if you want to change back."

"What do you mean, 'if?'" I asked.

Rachel shrugged. "A year is a long time, you might get to like your new life." she said. "I'll help you all I can."

I sighed at that. "Well, my first question is, what am I supposed to do with all this hair?"

Both Vanessa and Rachel laughed.
13221121.title: Mrs. Procter, the guidance counselor

132211211.content:
My first experiences as a girl really hit me when I had to use the bathroom this morning. Rachel was very patient though and she walked me through the steps. It was embarrassing, having to relearn a lot of things. Getting dressed was the next challenge but, again, Rachel was a big help. She showed me, with a game of mirror, how to put on a bra and explained how and why to wear pads. After all of that, it was time to get ready, which took us twenty minutes in all.

"I never realized girls had to go through so much in the morning." I breathed, walking quickly through the halls.

Rachel smiled. "This was a rush job." she replied. "Just wait until we have to get ready for a night out or a dance."

I shivered at the thought but placed it aside as we walked into our first class, spells and incantations. Professor Isaac Burroughs was the teacher. He was a tall, well built man in his early thirties with black hair and blue eyes. He urged the last few students to enter. Rachel and I made it to our seats just before the bell rang. Isaac smiled as the door then closed tight on a straggler who politely knocked. "Please let me in." he said.

"What is the most misused magick word, known to cowan? asked Isaac.

There was a pause before the boy guessed, "Abracadabra?"

The door opened and Isaac allowed him inside. "Each time you are late for class, the question gets harder." he explained to the entire class. "If you answer incorrectly, you get a pass back to your dorm and you will have to ask to read the notes of one of your classmates."

"Yes, sir." replied the boy, softly. "It won't..."

"Do not say 'it won't happen again'." warned Isaac. "You are only asking for a jinx, if you do that."

He then smiled. "Now that we have all settled, let us begin." he said, pulling out a wand. "Who would like to volunteer?"
132211211.title: First class.

choices: Isaac turns Nate back to normal
Just one more transformation. Clothing and animal means mermaid
1322112112.content:
"You should have Miss Child volunteer. She is already transformed" a voice says somewhere behind me. Hearing a few snickers, I felt myself begin to blush. Rachel grabbed my hand, but she could see I was reassured by Isaac; he was not impressed.

"Thanks for volunteering, Mister Parsens" Isaac says seriously. "I was going to show several amongst the class but I guess Nate wants all for himself.

"You're already seen gender.." he said, and I could feel eyes stare at me. Again I felt myself blushing. Isaac continued "..but guess you can all see it again."

"No. Don't.. I don't want.... what have you done to me!?!" the newly formed girl shrieked. I could feel some sympathy for him or her, though I doubted Isaac would keep her like this.

"Another spell we use is age progression/ regression"

"Isn't it enough to.. Urrgh" Nate said, as she began to develop a little more. I guess Isacc just added a year or two. Nate understandably freaked, since she was somewhat pretty. I looked around the class and saw some torn reactions. Some wanted Nate regressed. Others wanted further progression, and some of the boys were looking away awkwardly.

"Okay," the embrassed girl begged, 'you've had your fun. Please turn me back."
1322112112.title: Isaac picks someone.

choices: Not working yet. Something else is needed
13221121121.content:
"And so you see, class," Professor Burroughs said, "the first and most important thing to remember in spellcasting is to be very careful what you say." With that, he returned Nate to his original form, and sent him back to his seat.

"Those are but a few of the spells you will learn over the next seven years," the professor resumed. "For now, let's keep things simple. Take up your wands."

Once we all had our wands ready, he said, "We'll begin with a simple levitation spell. Each of you will find a feather in your desks. Toss it in the air, then use your magick to keep it in the air, for as long as you can."

We all did as we were told, but I had some problems. I could get the feather in the air, no problem. However, when I tried to make it float, it would only glide downward, as if my power were nothing.

"Is there a problem, Miss Child?" Professor Burroughs came to my desk.

I shrugged. "I can't make it float."

"No," he said, "you can't make it float. You can't make it fall, either. All you need to do is to let it float."

"You talk like it has a mind of its own," I grumbled.

"Like all things," he said, "it is a reflection of the Goddess, and of her consort. We do not ask, nor do we command. We work together with the targets of our magick. Try seeing it that way."

Everything was connected? I knew that all matter was composed of the same basic atoms, but this sounded like something much deeper. Looking at it this new way, I tried again.
13221121121.title: Isaac turns Nate back to normal

132211211212.content:
I sighed, seeing the feather glide down to my desk again. "It has to be some mind over matter issue but how do I trigger it." I whispered, frustrated. "There has to be some catalyst."

Hearing me, Rachel Downs giggled. "You're thinking like a scientist." she whispered. "Forget what you think you know about how the world works and try again."

I turned back to the feather and pointed my wand at it, expecting nothing. To my surprise, it rose off the desk and floated where ever I pointed my wand. A dream like smile formed onto my face as I watched the feather dance in the air with the flick of my wand. "Wow...."

Professor Burroughs chuckled as, even though I was late to make my feather float, I was keeping it up longer than the rest of my class. "That is quite enough, for now, Miss Child." he said. "We must move on the the next lesson."

"Y-Yes, sir." I replied, blushing. I allowed the feather to float back down to the desk. "Sorry."

A few of the girls in my class giggled slightly but fell silent as Professor Burroughs continued. "Levitation is merely the first step towards learning more complicated spells where one may not even think levitation played a key role." he said. "In fact, there are dozens of spells where levitation is used."

I rose my hand. "For example...?"

"When you heal a person from serious injury with magic, it is necessary to levitate the body so the spell is not dispersed into the ground, weakening its effect." replied Professor Burroughs. "Another example is the ground shake spell, you will want to be levitating off the ground so you are effected by your own spell."

Professor Burroughs gave a few more examples, levitating members of the class as they sat in their seats than inviting them to try themselves. I managed to levitate Rachel a few inches off the ground before suddenly dropping her, feeling exhausted from the effort. Fortunately, I was not the only one who was wore out from the attempt.

"Size and weight is not a factor in levitation." said Professor Burroughs. "It is a simple mind over matter issue and the catalyst is merely the belief that you can make it happen." he then smiled at me and added, "Of course, one must have a certain amount of power behind such levitations but that is a lesson for your classes next year."

With that said, the bell, marking the end of first class rang and Professor Burroughs dismissed us to our next class....
132211211212.title: Not working yet. Something else is needed

1322112112122.content:
The moment I stepped out of my first class, I heard a boy scream and turned to find a first year I did not remember seeing in line at orientation now wearing the girls' school uniform, the same prank played on me. "Cohan doesn't know when to quit." I muttered.

I was about to step in when Rachel gripped my shoulder. "Hold on, that's Sam Procter," she said. "I heard he was kidnapped a few years ago by a crazy woman who wanted magick." She grinned. "They say that she's been turned into a first year student as an ironic punishment."

"This is not funny!" protested the boy, Sam in tears. "I'm not a girl!"

"It's just clothes, squirt," giggled Cohan, still with his girlish voice. "They'll change back tomorrow."

Sam began to shake with a certain fury before a firm hand touched his shoulder, followed by a low chuckle. "It's just a harmless prank, son," said a familiar voice. "Try not to take it too personally."

Sam turned to his dad and sighed. "I'll be laughed at," he pouted.

"I was laughed at when my clothes were turned into infant attire," said Cohan, shrugging.

"I was laughed at when I spent my first day in a wedding dress," added Sam's dad, blushing slightly. "It was your mom who did that, trying to prank back at a seventh year student.... that was when we first met." he gave another low chuckle. "It's ironic, when I look back at it now."

"So... everyone gets pranked on their first year?" asked Sam, turning from Cohan to his dad.

"Everyone who doesn't go into a rampage," said Cohan. "I got my new squeaky voice from a guy who tried to play on my level." He smiled. "She is now on the girls' side of the school..."

I turned away from the conversation at that point. "What's our next class?" I asked Rachel.

Rachel did not answer, she merely giggled. I turned to her annoyed until she pointed out my new attire. "You really need to be on more on guard... princess," she said, grinning. "It shouldn't last more than an hour as any longer would disrupt your classes but..." She giggled again. "You really look cute."

She summoned a mirror for me to see myself. I looked at my reflection and saw a young girl in a pink princess cut dress, forcing a scream to echo from my throat as I was now...
1322112112122.title: The pranks start again.

13221121121221.content:
"I'm having enough trouble adapting to being a girl for the year!" I whined, stomping one foot as any other little girl.

"Relax, young man," said a familiar voice. "It was an accident."

I turned around to find the guidance counselor, Vanessa Procter. "You did this to me?" I asked, tearing up.

"As I said, it was an accident." said Procter. "I meant to hit that Cohan student you gave a girlish voice to. However, you jumped in the way right when I cast the spell." she smiled. "You see, the boy he decided to pick on is my son, who was just rescued from a kidnapper."

My eyes grew wide then narrowed as my face turned red. "Who is this kidnapper?" I asked her. "I have the perfect concoction that will deal with him."

"She has already been dealt with, young man." said Procter smiling. "In fact, her punishment is very ironic. She kidnapped my son to claim him as her own so to gain magick." she giggled. "She got her wish and is now an eleven year old girl with no family... I intend to adopt her."

I grinned at that. "That beats my idea." I said. "Um... can you..."

Procter giggled. "It will wear off in an hour, princess." she said. "In the mean time, try to enjoy yourself. It's not often we get to visit our childhood."

With that, she walked away, leaving me fuming. "So, she want to play, huh?" I whispered. "Let the games begin."

"I wouldn't," warned Rachel, smiling. "She is known as the 'queen of pranks' here."

I frowned, not knowing my idea was a bad one. She is about to be dethroned, I thought.

Unknown to me, Procter had decided to use the accidental prank on me as a test, to see if I had learned from my previous experience. "Let's see if Miss Child has gained any patience."

Later on...
13221121121221.title: A six year old girl!

132211211212212.content:
After giving my idea more thought, I decided that throwing a prank at her now would be an obvious course of action and with her being dubbed 'the queen of pranks', she would be expecting one to come. "Maybe you're right, Rachel." I said. "The timing is not right, I couldn't even match powers with a student."

Rachel smiled. "I'm glad you see reason." she said, giving me a quick hug. "Don't worry, you're magick skills will grow with time and practice, whether or not you decide to return to being a male."

I smiled back at her. Once I get a better grip on this magick, Mrs Proctor won't know what hit her, I thought, walking to my next class. Only I wouldn't want to hurt or overly embarrass her, just show her the new 'king'.

As I worked on the perfect prank to pull on Mrs Procter, I kept my mind sharp for pranks from other seventh years as I walked to my next class. The day's lessons proved to be challenging to my mind, which made me anxious to learn more as I made all of my notes in scientific terms to understand better when I studied for the tests. The teachers noticed this but paid no real mind, just grinned at my approach to learning.

"Having difficulty copying Miss Child's notes, Miss Thomas?" asked Professor Isaac Burroughs, teaching spells and incantations. "If you had paid closer attention to the class than to painting your nails, you would not have this issue." he then waved his hand, causing a copy of my notes to appear on her notebook before he smiled. "You now have all of Miss Child's notes, if you can translate them. Class is dismissed."

As the students filed out of the room, Trevor took my hand and pulled me aside. "Please, can you translate what you wrote down?" she asked. "I'll do you a favor in return."

What do you say?
132211211212212.title: I decide not to.

1322112112122121.content:
"See me after school lets out," I said. "I'll explain it all, then." A friend would be good in this place, I thought. If nothing else, I can use him as a Trojan horse, when I'm ready to show Mrs. Procter who the new head practical joker is.



I had a few welcome surprises, as we had some regular classes, like math and American history. In these classes, I was at least on familiar footing.

At the end of the school day, Trevor came to see me. "Your notes?"

"It's very simple," I said, "once you understand it. I'm a newbie when it comes to magick, but I excelled at science, so I put everything down in scientific terms." I showed him some examples.

"Pretty clever," he remarked. "Most of the kids here use Theban or runic letters. I guess this works, too."

"So far," I replied. At least I now knew why my note-taking technique so amused my teachers.

"Thanks for the help, Nico," he said, after he understood my notes. "Anything you need, let me know. I'll handle it for you."

As he walked away, I caught myself thinking, He's kind of cute, for a boy.
1322112112122121.title: I agree.

13221121121221211.content:
I went back to my room to study. As I worked on my lessons, Tanith came in. "How was your day, Nico?"

"Crazy," I replied. "Somebody cast a spell on the Procter boy, and his mom accidentally turned me into a little girl. On the plus side, my note-taking system amuses the teachers, while mystifying the kids trying to copy off me. How was yours?"

She rolled her eyes. "Some seventh-year crossed the line with his idea of a prank. He turned my clothes transparent."

"No!"

"Yes. Bad news for him, the teacher caught him. She made him change my clothes back, then cast some kind of sex-offender spell on him. Now, he can't be alone with any female. If he tries, somebody gets teleported away."

As I started figuring out pranks to play on Mrs. Procter, I noticed Tanith doing something. "What are you doing?"
