"I was about to give a mild demonstration of a magick accident to show how dangerous playing with magick can be." said Isaac, looking at me. "Unfortunately, this class seems short of volunteers, I was about to pick one."

I gulped, somehow knowing that Professor Burroughs was asking me to volunteer for the lesson. What should I do?
14212211221.title: Visiting first class.

choices: School supplies of a different nature
142122112211.content:
I swallowed hard and raised my hand.

"Splendid," Professor Burroughs said. He leveled his wand in my direction and muttered something.

I saw a flash from the tip of his wand, and I felt a peculiar tingling.

"How do you feel?" the professor asked.

I wanted to say that I felt fine. What came out, however, was, "Spider-Man dipstick gravity." Puzzled, I turned to Dad. "Image computer Yankovic?"

The class laughed, and I realized that this was the spell Professor Burroughs had cast. "It's an aphasia spell," he explained. "What you want to say is not what you actually say. If you were to try to write something, you'd find the same problem." Turning to the class, he said, "From time to time, students like to attempt pranks on the faculty, just as the seventh-years occasionally haze you first-years. However, I must caution against this, particularly with the aphasia spell. We teachers are wise to you, and we have several mirrors ready at a moment's notice, to deflect or reflect any spells cast at us. As you can imagine, finding that you've accidentally cast an aphasia spell on yourself would impact your studies, and you'd be unable to reverse it. Which reminds me." He raised his wand to me again, and cast another spell. "How are you now?"

I cleared my throat. "Um,... okay?" He'd broken the spell.

"Splendid," he said. "You'll receive a credit for your assistance on this point. Thank you, Master Procter."
142122112211.title: volunteer and hope for the best.

1421221122112.content:
Once I was through touring my classes, Dad brought me to the school supply store. "I'll help you pick out the things you'll need," he said. "Most of the school supplies will be familiar to you, but you'll need help with the magickal items." He picked out a knife, which he called an athame, a cauldron, a chalice, and a pentagram.

Once we returned to my room, he told me to wait, as he needed to pick up some more things. He returned with a bowl of saltwater, a small branch, a burner, and some incense. He lit the incense and said, "Now we need to charge your magickal tools."

"How do we do that?" I asked.

"We'll start with the wand," he replied. "Hold it in front of you, close your eyes, and envision your energy flowing into it."

I tried it, and was surprised by the result. "It looks blue, like electricity."

Dad smiled. "That's how it should look. Now, using the branch, sprinkle the wand with saltwater and say, 'I charge thee with water and earth.'"

When I did that, he said, "Now, hold it in the smoke from the incense, and say, 'I charge thee with fire and air.'"

When I had done that with all my tools, I asked, "How often should I do this?"

"Three months is standard," he replied. "You'll need to clean the chalice after every use, but the other tools won't need cleaning. Just wrap them in silk, and place them in your chest, on top of your Book of Shadows. The pentagram can go around your neck."

There was a knock on the door, and Mom stepped in. "How are you doing, Sam?"

"Fine, Mom. I just finished charging my tools."

"That's good," she said. "I came to make an announcement: Our family is growing."

I stared, then smiled. "Y-you're going to have a baby?"

She chuckled. "No, son, nothing of that sort. There is a girl, about your age, who has no family of her own, and we've decided to adopt her." Stepping aside from the doorway, she said, "Sam, meet your new sister."

I could have died. My new sister was Anna.
1421221122112.title: School supplies of a different nature

14212211221121.content:
"Th-This is a twist." trapped between amusement and pity, I said. "Um... hi, Anna. We-Welcome to the family, sis."

Anna gave me a stern look and opened her mouth as if to say something but stopped, seeing a stern look from mom, and teared up to the point of making rivers. "Th-Thanks... bi-big brother." almost sobbing, she said.

"Big brother?" turning to mom, I asked.

Mom giggled. "You were born in May, Sam, while Anna was born in October." She smiled. "Hence, when she was regressed to an eleven year old, you became about six months older than she is."

Anna began to cry, a look of complete humiliation on her face before she covered it with her small hands. Feeling sorry for her, I pulled Anna into a warm hug. "I'll be okay, sis." holding her, I said. "At least we're all a family now."

"It's quite fitting, I think," Dad said, a tone of satisfaction in his voice. "Anna wanted Sam in her life, magick powers, and a family to call her own." He smiled at his new sobbing daughter. "This way, she gets everything she wanted, just not the way she had planned it."

"Yes, sir." sobbing, Anna said.

"Now, now, my dear." Dad cooed. "We went over this."

Anna sighed, looking up at Dad. "Yes... daddy." reluctantly, she said.

Dad smiled. "That's much better, sweetie." Wiping one of her tears away, he said. "It will get easier to say in time."

Later on, I...
14212211221121.title: Continue

142122112211212.content:
Later on, I was taken to see Anna's dorm in Cauldron Hall by Mom. There, she and I were left alone for a moment, Mom saying she had to retrieve someone from her room. I knew she was referring to her familiar, Maddalena, but I was uncertain she would be as patient with Anna as she was with me when I fist met her.

"I can't believe they made me their child." pouted Anna, tearfully. "I had enough trouble with puberty the first time."

"They could have done worse." I said, wincing.

Anna shivered, remembering her meeting with Heather Gardner. "Don't remind me." she said, "It's going to be tough, getting used to being a child again as it is." she sighed. "I know what I did was horribly wrong but..."

"That's over and in the past." I said, touching her hand. "You are my sister now, a witch, like me." I gave her a small grin. "We are together, that's all that counts."

Anna gave me a small grin in return. "Thank you, Sam." she said.

Just then, Mom entered, smiling, with a black cat resting in her arms. "Maddy, this is my new daughter, Anna." she said, calmly. "She was the woman I told you of earlier."

Maddy dropped from mom's arms and walked over to where Anna was sitting then stared at her with her tail straight in the air. Anna was surprised to hear a feminine voice in her head. *You got off easy.*

Somehow, Anna sensed it was Maddy who had said that and raised her hand as if to swat her. Seeing this, I winced.
"I wouldn't do that, sis." I thought.

Suddenly Anna screamed, pulling her hand back, as Maddy sharply turned to her. I saw nothing alarming, but Anna saw Maddy suddenly become a black panther who roared at her with a deafening sound.

"Maddy, you will show greater patience!" scolded Mom, sternly. "Apologize at once!"

With a low meow, Maddie turned to Anna, now seen as a regular cat to her, and projected her thoughts. *I'm sorry you are so easily frightened.*

She then suddenly turned to me and I saw the same image of her panther form, hearing the same roar. Only I smiled at this, wide eyed with a certain wonder. "That's so cool!" I said, laughing.

The image vanished a few seconds later and Maddie walked back to Mom. As she did, I could have sworn I heard Maddy giggling to herself...

That night...
142122112211212.title: A moment  with Anna.

1421221122112121.content:
... I returned to my room, to find a boy my age sitting there. "You must be my new roommate," he said, extending his hand. "Steve Wilkes. Blessed be."

"Sam Procter," I replied, shaking his hand.

"Any relation to the guidance counselor?"

"She's my mom."

"Well," he said, "welcome to the room. I had thought I'd be going it alone in here. My last scheduled roommate got into a prank war, and wound up turned into a girl."

"I've only had the one prank on me, so far," I replied. "I gather the older kids are kind of afraid of my mom."

He chuckled. "That's respect, not fear," he said. "I'm the youngest witch in my family, and my older brothers and sisters have told me all about the 'Queen of Pranks.'" He leaned in close to me. "If you want to see people afraid, wait for somebody to damage the trees or the gardens, or to hurt the dogs. That'll bring Wardwell on them."

"Wardwell's the tallest man I've ever seen," I told him. "How much do you know about him?"

He shrugged. "All anybody says is that he showed up one day, said his name was Wardwell, and asked if there was a place for him here. He's good with plants and animals, so they put him in charge of the various grounds duties. A few of the teachers do things to help with his health. since being so big puts a lot of strain on his system."

"Has anybody asked him?"

Steve shook his head. "Wardwell doesn't talk about himself. The teachers all respect that, and don't press him about his past. " I detected an unspoken you should probably do the same.
1421221122112121.title: I meet my roommate

14212211221121211.content:
Unknown to me, I received a visitor that night. John Scooter, a friend of mine from my old school, was worried about me, suddenly being transferred to Ravenscroft Academy before Anna vanished. "I have to know if he's okay in there." whispering to himself, John said. "If I don't do this, and I later find out he was hurt, I'll never forgive myself!"

John looked around upon reaching the top of the stone fence and looked around. He saw nothing alarming but a number of beautiful plants and flowers along the inner wall. "Someone will be upset if i trample on those." wincing, he said. "Maybe I can clear them, the ground is soft enough from the rain earlier, I hope."

Taking a breath, John jumped from the wall, clearing the plants but he did not land right and his leg turned sickly under him, causing a scream of pain to escape his lips. "Of all the rotten luck!" whispering, John cursed. "I twisted my ankle!"

He tried to stand but he could not put any weight onto his right leg and cried out again as he tried, falling into a sitting position, before seeing a light approach him. "Busted."

"You there!" a thundering voice called. "This is a private school! What are you doing here?"

John turned to face a towing man with a lantern in one hand. "No one answered at the gate, sir." in a fearful tone, John replied. "My friend, Sam Stone, got transferred here, I have to know he's alright." pausing, he added, "His mom went missing yesterday morning."

"Regardless of the reason, we can not have you or anyone else trespassing." seriously, Wardwell said. "I must ask you to come with me."

John stood but cried out again as he tried to walk. Wardwell sighed before taking John into his arms. "Consider yourself thankful all you did was twist your ankle, young man." he said.

Wardwell carried John into the medical wing where the magister, Daniel Cochrane and the head physician, Dr. Robert Willard, were waiting. "No one likes to be disturbed in the middle of the night, young man." sternly, Daniel said. "We do have a listed phone number which you could have used, rather than risking injury, climbing our wall..."

As Daniel gave John a strict lecture, Robert discretely used his magick on John's leg before wrapping it with some gauze and taping it tight around his ankle. "Your ankle was badly twisted but its not broken." drawing John's attention, he said. "Just avoid putting too much weight on it for a day or two and it should be fine."

While Robert gave John some advice of his own, Daniel discretely pointed a narrow wooden rod at John then placed it back into his pocket before helping John to his feet. "I will not send any note home to your parents with you, this time." firmly, he said. "However, I warn you not to try this again, understand?"

John nodded. "Yes, sir."

Wardwell then escorted John to the gates before giving him a folded piece of paper. "Write to this address, and your friend will receive your letter." calmly, he said. "Good night."

That morning, I was handed a note to report to the magister's office. Curious, I entered the room. "You wished to see me, Magister?"

"Your friend, John Scooter, paid us a visit last night." calmly, Daniel said. "Do not fear, he was released with a warning, but I must caution you. Do not mention what you are learning here, outside of normal academics. If he were to learn what we do here, his life, and all of ours, may become... complicated. I am certain you do not wish that to happen."

I quickly shook my head and was dismissed.
14212211221121211.title: Next day

choices: Nothing, I didn't cast a spell.
142122112211212111.content:
As luck would have it, my first class was with Professor Isaac Burroughs, teaching Spells and Incantations. I entered his class early, wanting to make a good first impression, and strangely found myself the only one in the room. "Am I too early for class, Professor?" confused, I asked.

Isaac chuckled. "No, Master Procter." smiling, he replied. "You are here just in time. I placed a spell onto the entire class after you left, to see if their magick can detect it."

"What will this spell do to them?" concerned, I asked.

Issac smiled. "Fear not, it's harmless. Those who have detected the spell will arrive shortly with late passes as they would have to visit the nurse to have the spell removed." Seeing my confusion, he added, "It's a sick day spell, causing them to believe they are too ill to attend classes."

"Wouldn't that disrupt their other school activities?" accusingly, I asked.

"Ah, you paid attention to the prank rules." smiling, Isaac said. "I designed the spell to cancel itself out long before they need to move on to their second class." He then pointed to the number of tardy slips on the desks. "Those who do not detect it will arrive halfway through class and receive a warning to always be aware of magick use around them before they are sent to the nurse's office."

"So what will we be doing in the meantime?" curious, I asked.

"You and I will be covering the class you missed yesterday." simply, Isaac replied. "Please take out your wand, I wish to show you how to properly hold, maintain, and harness its power."

After carefully taking my wand out of its case, Isaac instructed me to give it a wave, which I did.

What happened?
142122112211212111.title: First class.

1421221122112121111.content:
I moved the wand about, but nothing happened. I turned to Isaac, confused. "Am I doing something wrong?"

"Not at all," the professor replied, with a smile. "I had you wave your wand to demonstrate that the wand is not the source of a witch's power, as many cowans believe. The wand merely helps a witch focus that power, especially when using complex or powerful spells."

"So if a cowan were to take my wand, it would do him little good," I mused.

"Except to make the witch he stole the wand from annoyed," he replied. "Now, to properly use a wand you must first cast the spell in your mind then, just before reciting the last word, point the wand at your target. However, with more complex spells, you should point the wand first to keep that magick focused."

"I think I understand," taking some notes, I said. "Simple spells only require the wand so to point out a specific target, say in a crowd of people."

"Correct, master Procter," retrieving a wand of his own, he said. "The wand is also a tool for defense against unwanted attacks from other witches."

"Like the prank spells?" hopeful, I asked.

"Not quite," chuckling, Isaac replied. "Prank spells are relatively harmless, and can be countered or reversed if the target student is alert and unafraid to ask for assistance." He sighed. "Most first years are too embarrassed or frightened to ask a teacher for help when they are pranked but we will help, if only asked."

"A student used a wand against me to change my clothing to the female uniform." blushing I said. "Was that to point me out in a crowd?"

"Wands are used in pranks as a required warning," winking at me, Isaac said. "We normally do not tell the first years this as such pranks make them more alert to magick so they can learn dodge or deflect spells faster." Returning to his desk, he added, "Yes, some of the pranks are cruel. You will hear horror stories about that, I'm sure. However, there are limits to the pranks that can be pulled, and there are punishments to those who cross the line."

"You said the wand can be used to combat magickal attacks. Are you referring to a duel?"

"Good guess." smiling, Isaac said. "Although not necessary, wands are often used in magick duels but they can also be useful in combating curses, identifying potions, and so forth."

Just then, a group of annoyed looking students entered the room, carrying hall passes from the nurses office. "Nice prank, professor," sarcastically, one student said. "Turnabout is fair game, though."

"It is, but this was not a prank." smiling, Isaac replied. "This was a lesson, you need to learn to detect magick before you can properly combat it."

"Um... how do you detect magick?" raising my hand, I asked.

"A very good question, master Procter," turning to me, Isaac said. "It is a pity your fellow classmates did not think to ask that in yesterday's class."
1421221122112121111.title: Nothing, I didn't cast a spell.

14212211221121211111.content:
Professor Burroughs waited for everyone to take their seats before looking at the clock. "This class is nearly at its end," he said. "However, I will briefly explain. Energy is energy, regardless of its source. One must summon their bio-energy to cast any given spell." Smiling, he added, "This is why we allow pranks to be played on first year students, so you can learn to sense that energy and either dodge it or deflect the spell being cast against them."

"Are we allowed to prank back?" one student asked.

"You are." chuckling, the teacher replied. "However, you do so at the risk of a worse prank later on."

Everyone nodded just before the bell rang, ending the class. "Stay on your toes, first years." smiling, the professor said. "This is only the second day, more pranks and lessons are to come."

Unknown to me until later, as I walked to my second class, Mom tapped a telephone with her wand then picked up the receiver and dialed a number. Two rings later, someone answered. "Skye Walker." she said.

"Blessed be, Skye," smiling tearfully, Mom said. "My son, Samuel returned to me."

"Thank the Goddess," sighing, Skye said. "Who had taken him, did he or she pay for the crime?"

"It was his babysitter," ice in her voice, Mom replied. "She is now my adopted eleven year old daughter, as she committed the crime to obtain magick."

"A fitting punishment," giggling, Skye replied. "Congratulations on your growing family."

"There is another reason I am calling," after some hesitation, Mom said. "It's about John Scooter."

"My next door neighbor's kid? What of him?"

"He- he sneaked onto Academy grounds, worried about Samuel." nervous, mom replied. "The magister, Daniel, told me that he had been touched by magick." After a pause, she asked, "I know you live on the other side of the Academy but... have you heard anything?"

Skye giggled. "I owed his parents a debt of honor years ago, and placed a karma shield spell onto him," she explained. "This spell lasts a lifetime. It gives John good or bad karma to prevent him from falling into greater harm or risk." Pausing, she added, "I'm guessing he twisted his ankle gaining entry, and was caught before he could learn anything."

Mom giggled with Skye. "I'm glad. Sam was worried for him."

"John is in no danger, so long as he can keep his curiosity under control," amused, Skye said. "It was nice to hear from you again, Vanessa. I have to go, my son is calling for me."

"Blessed be, Skye." said Mom. She ended the call.
14212211221121211111.title: Lessons in and out of school.

142122112211212111111.content:
My next class was Mathematics. It seemed dull when compared to Spells and Incantations. However, Professor Eleanor Nurse informed me that, with so many shapes to draw, geometry was crucial to magick use. "Also, you will find that potions and elixirs require exact amounts of the needed ingredients for them to work," facing her class, she said. "Mathematics will hep you all become powerful witches, so do pay attention."

Eleanor was a very short and slender young woman with doll-like features who could have easily passed as one of the first year students, if she so wished to try. She had mid-back-length midnight hair, and curious green eyes that seemed to hypnotize anyone who stared into them for too long. She wore the standard girl's school uniform, complete with the Mary Jane shoes and blazer, only she also wore a ruby tipped pin on her blazer that shone like a beacon. I guessed it was that which marked her as a teacher.

"I sense you have a question, Master Procter," looking at me Eleanor said. "What do you wish to ask?"

"I'm just curious as to why you wear the school uniform," sounding small, I said. "I mean no offense, but teachers are allowed to dress causally."

Eleanor smiled. "I wear the school uniform so to connect better with the students," simply, she replied. "You may be surprised to know that I look this way due to a prank that I had thought had ruined my life."

"What happened?" concerned, I asked.

"I was hit with a 'youth visit' spell," sighing, Eleanor replied. "Normally, the spell only makes the target five years younger for twenty four hours, leaving him or her feeling vulnerable."

"Only something went wrong," a girl student guessed.

Eleanor nodded. "The prankster botched the spell and cast a 'youth lock' spell, making me physically eleven years old for eleven years. The eleven years expired a few days ago, so I am now aging normally, and will be 'twelve' in a few months' time."

"What- What happened to the prankster?" showing some anger, I asked.

"Do not fear, Master Procter," smiling, Eleanor said. "The boy who cast the spell was given the same treatment. He, too, started aging normally from sixteen a few days ago. I hear he is doing well."

"Was there no way to counter the spell?" asked another student.

"Spell locks require first making a key spell to open them," with a hint of regret, Eleanor replied. "The boy forgot to do so. That was why he was given the same treatment." She then smiled. "Now then, who can tell me the basic structure of a parallelogram...?"
142122112211212111111.title: Sam's second class.

1421221122112121111111.content:
At lunch, I saw Anna and Mom sitting together, so I decided to join them. "Blessed be," I said as I sat down.

"Bright blessings, Sam," Mom replied. "Anna was telling me how her schooling is going. Is there anything you would like to say?"

"Professor Nurse told us why she looks so young," I said. "She was hit with a youth spell as a prank, but the prankster got it wrong."

Mom nodded. "She was one of my favorite teachers."

Anna's eyes widened. "How old is she?"

"Her next birthday will mark 40 years since she was born," Mom explained. "I was at her handloosing."

"Handloosing?"

"As handfasting is our version of marriage," Mom explained, "handloosing is our version of divorce. Her former husband has been looking after her, posing as an older relative. He later remarried, and Eleanor - Professor Nurse - has helped take care of their children."

"That had to be rough on her," I said.

"It wasn't easy. She had suffered an accident when she was 15, and that left her unable to conceive children of her own. So, in a way, that prank almost helped her."

"Helped? How?"

"As I said, Professor Nurse was unable to bear children because of an accident when she was 15. However, now, she is not yet 12."

I understood. "So, because of the spell, she will be able to have children?"

Mom nodded. "That's what the doctor says." Then a sly smile crossed her face. "You seem quite interested in your teacher, Sam."

Anna smiled too. "Sounds like somebody's got a crush."

I blushed, regretting my decision to sit here.

"It's alright, Sam," Mom said, brushing my cheek. "A crush is a perfectly healthy thing, preparing you for when true love does strike you. Just remember, it would be unseemly for a teacher to have a romantic relationship with a student, so she won't treat you any differently from any of your classmates."
1421221122112121111111.title: skip to lunch.

14212211221121211111111.content:
As I reached the door to my next class, I heard a feminine voice from inside say, "Blessed be, child. I am Professor Janet Good, please enter."

I was about to comply when I sensed something and hesitated, focusing my eyes. To my surprise, I saw a dim glow around the open door. "I will not walk through a doorway that is enchanted with a prank, Professor Good," politely, I said. "Please cancel the spell and allow me to enter freely."

The glowing around the door vanished and I cautiously entered to see professor Good standing behind her desk with a bemused smile on her face. Professor Good was very tall and slender with long flowing sand blond hair and ocean blue eyes that seemed to dance in the light. Her long dress accented her figure well as she walked out from behind her desk and smiled at me. "Well done, Master Procter," looking at me, she said. "Your first day as a student and you are already detecting magick." she then giggled. "However, I do not teach spells or enchantments in this class."

My eyes widened as I felt a breeze and I looked down to find that I was wearing the school uniform of a girl! A scream escaped my lips as I discovered that was not the only thing that had changed, I was now a girl! "Professor..." pouting, I protested.

The professor laughed then placed a light hand onto my shoulder. "Do not fear, Miss Procter," gently, she said. "You will return to your proper gender and attire upon leaving this classroom." She then pointed to a strange object above the door that looked like the male and female signs intertwined in a Celtic cross. "When you are able to forge a talisman that will counteract my gender swap charm, you will have passed a third of my class."

"A charm and an amulet are the other thirds of your class?" surprised by my new voice, I asked.

"Correct. You will be affected until you learn to make each of the three objects I teach. Hands-on is the fastest way to learn this, and I find that using them against my students gives a good incentive for them to learn."

I giggled. "Some students may want to make a talisman to prank you back."

Janet shook her head and pointed to a strange object that looked like a small shield with crossed wands over her desk. "Those who try will only have it run back onto themselves as I keep a shield amulet over my desk," amused, she said. "Yet another incentive to learn if they even want a chance to prank me."

"I think I'm going to like this class," smiling, I said. "Um... where do I sit?"

"I suggest you sit in the front of the class, Miss Procter," pointing to a seat, Janet replied. "I have a feeling, being the son of the 'queen of pranks', not too many students will dare to try a prank during class."

"No stress," pouting, I muttered.

Janet giggled. "Your mother holds quite a legacy. Do not get lost in her shadow. Make your own legacy, one that will make her proud."

This made me feel better and I jokingly did a curtsey. "Yes, ma'am."

Janet giggled as the next student approached the door. She and I shared a quick grin before she said, "Blessed be, child. I am Professor Janet Good, please enter..."
14212211221121211111111.title: Charms, amulets, and talismans! Oh my!

choices: I accept along with a few others.
I decline but a few accept.
142122112211212111111111.content:
Once all of the students had been given the gender swap scare and introduction, Professor Good sat at her desk and called for silence in the room. "There are twelve steps in creating a talisman," she began. "We will go over each step in length throughout the school year."

"Are there also twelve steps to creating charms and an amulets?" curious, I asked.

"We will get to those objects soon enough, Miss Procter," she replied. "Please open the book in front of you to page five. If anyone looks at the pages before, their new gender will be locked until sundown."

"Why threaten us, professor?" annoyed, a boy asked. "I don't understand."

"The first four pages of the book are a quick reference guide, Mister Alexander." simply, the professor explained. "I was not allowed to remove them from the book as students are permitted to purchase them after graduation." she then frowned. "There will be no shortcuts in my class! They will not help you when you need to make a magickal charm, talisman or amulet in a pinch!"

Everyone turned to page five, careful not to look at the first four pages. On page five was the following...

The twelve steps to creating a talisman.

1. Decide the purpose of the talisman.
Without first assigning a purpose, your talisman will be nothing more than a fancy piece of jewelry.

2. Identify appropriate planetary influences to determine best time for ritual.
Without this important phase, your talisman will not have enough power for the task you had selected. If this is done improperly, your talisman may not have enough power, or worse, too much. Know your planets and their influences before going any further.

3. Undertake self-purification.
Without this cleansing ritual, anything you make with the use of magick will not be pure in turn, causing unpredictable results.

4. Don ritual garments, and gather appropriate magical tools.
This should be self-explanatory but always use the right garments and tools for any job. If you do not know them, do not continue until you do.

5. Create a magick circle to work within.
This is a very important step as it focuses all the magick being used into one focused area, making the other steps easier to control.

6. Invoke appropriate divine, angelic, and spirit help.
Everyone, even the most experienced witch, needs guidance. Allow the spirits to guide your hand and your words so your talisman will reach its full potential and mistakes you may have made in the previous steps may be spotted and corrected before it is too late.

7. Inscribe a circle on a piece of metal, parchment, or paper.
Doing this on paper or paper and parchment would be for a specific short-term objective, so the talisman may be destroyed when the goal is achieved. Doing this on metal (depending on the metal type) is for longer purposes.

8. Inscribe symbols and sigils.
These symbols must be associated with the appropriate planet, as well as any sacred names, words, or charms, on one or both sides of the talisman in order to grant it the power desired.

9. Focus intent, will, and emotional energy during inscription.
This locks in the purpose of the talisman so it will do the task desired once activated or triggered.

10. Purify talisman
This is done by passing metal through fire (such as a candle flame) or paper through smoke of incense.

11. Charge talisman with magical power.
This must be done by consecrating it in a ritual on the appropriate day of the planet.

12. Store or wear talisman in protective covering.
This is for the protection of the talisman and the protection of those the talisman is not intended for. Unless the talisman is given the purpose for a specific person or group, it will effect anyone who wears it or walks under it.

"Your lesson for the first day is to study those steps," kindly, the professor said. "You have already been given the talisman's purpose, to counteract the gender swap talisman I have introduced you all to." She then giggled. "I will gladly lock the talisman's effects onto those who wish to earn extra credit and walk in the shoes of the opposite gender."

Who takes the challenge?
142122112211212111111111.title: class begins.

1421221122112121111111111.content:
I decided that it couldn't hurt to try to improve my GPA, and raised my hand. "I'll do it, Professor."

"So will I," said a boy I couldn't see.

"Splendid," Professor Good replied. "The Procter children are on board. Who else would like to join them?"

I turned, realizing from Professor Good's words that Anna was the boy I'd heard. He smiled at me.

One by one, other students volunteered for the extra credit assignment. When the teacher had five boys and five girls, she said, "Very good. Would our volunteers please rise?"

After we had stood, she pointed her wand at each of us and cast her spell. "I'll leave the rest of our class time open, so that our extra-credit students may choose who to exchange rooms with."

One girl who had not volunteered raised her hand. "Professor, my sex wasn't changed when I came in. Why is that?"

"You are already under an enchantment, Miss Child," the professor explained. "However, you should still work on your talisman along with your fellow students. After all, you won't be under that enchantment forever. Come up to my desk, and I will give you an alternate extra credit assignment."

I walked up to my sister-turned-brother. "Want to switch rooms, Anna?"

"Okay. But it'll be Andy, for the time being, Samantha."

I smiled. "Not quite what you had in mind when you started all this, is it?"

She smiled back. "No, it's not what I imagined. But I'm still happy. You're learning magick, and I'm becoming a witch. So it's still what I wanted in the long run."
1421221122112121111111111.title: I accept along with a few others.

choices: The life of a female student.
14212211221121211111111112.content:
Upon entering Cauldron Hall, where Anna - now Andy - was assigned living quarters, I was greeted by Mom. She smiled then giggled slightly. "I see you and Anna took Professor Good's challenge for some extra credit. How do you like being a girl so far?"

"It's not too bad," shrugging, I replied. "I can't get over the fact that I walk into the girls' bathroom without thinking."

"That is part of the extra credit spell," kindly, Mom explained. "Professor Good is trying to give her students a new experience, not torment them by turning their world upside down."

"Well, it's definitely a new experience," to Mom's giggles, I said. "At least I can borrow Anna's clothes for a while instead of buying my own until I made the talisman that will break this spell."

"It's more complicated than that, I'm afraid," smiling, Mom said. "You see, Professor Good paired the boys and girls who accepted the extra credit into teams of two, each to switch dorms for a while."

"What does that have to do with making the talisman?"

Mom grinned. "I went through this too, with Professor Switch; she retired a few years ago." She paused. "You will not be able to break the spell keeping you a girl, until your partner, Andy, makes his talisman as well."

I winced. "So, until both talismans are made,... "

"Both of you are stuck as the wrong gender. I will explain this to Andy soon." She paused, seeing tears forming in my eyes. "Oh, now don't fret,... Samantha. You will be changed back at the end of the semester if you finish your talisman, even if Andy does not finish his by then. But he will lose his extra credit."

"So there is a time limit to this extra credit assignment."

"If you had studied Professor Good's class rules, you would have already known this," smiling, mom said. "Each teacher has a set of rules for their classrooms, I'd take the time to study them so you do not get yourself roped into 'volunteering' for a demonstration."

I blushed at that, unaware how cute it made me look. "I'll make a note of that."
14212211221121211111111112.title: After school

142122112211212111111111122.content:
As I left Mom's office, I bumped into an older woman. "Excuse me," I said.

"Hello, dear," she said. "I'm Magistra Gardner." She took a careful look at me. "I don't believe we've met before, have we?"

I shook my head. "I'm Sam Procter, ma'am. I've taken Professor Good's extra credit assignment."

She nodded. "Of course. It sounds like it's becoming something of a family tradition. Did you know that your parents met this way?"

"No, ma'am. Mom said that she'd taken extra credit when she was my age, but she didn't mention that."

The magistra smiled. "I suggest that you look on this not only as a school assignment, but as an opportunity to make new friends you might not have come to know otherwise. As I've said, it was how your parents became friends, and eventually more."

"Yes, ma'am. I would like to make more friends."

"Just be careful how far it goes. You were the first child born to students who were enrolled here, and we would like you to be the last. Raising children is quite difficult, especially for those who are still children themselves."

"Yes, ma'am. I'll be careful."

"Good. Oh, by the way, don't be surprised to find your magickal tools in your sister's locker. That, too, is part of Professor Good's spell."

"Thank you, ma'am."

She smiled again. "I look forward to seeing you again, Sam."

"So do I, ma'am." I went looking for my new room, thinking about what Magistra Gardner had said about Mom and Dad meeting in Professor Switch's class. When Andy and I ate with her again at supper, I would have to remember to ask about it.
142122112211212111111111122.title: Meeting the Magistra.

1421221122112121111111111221.content:
Andy and I met again at suppertime, and we spotted Mom and Dad waiting for us. "Good evening, kids," Mom said. "I've been telling your father about your extra credit work."

"You both look very nice," Dad said. "You know, your mother and I first met when we took the extra credit challenge."

"The magistra told me," I replied. "How come you didn't mention it sooner?"

Mom smiled. "We didn't want to spoil the surprise when you kids found yourselves changed."

"Yes," Dad agreed, "and there was more, too. Just think, Sam, if your mother and I hadn't helped each other with our talismans, we might never have fallen in love."

"And, if we had," Mom added, "I wouldn't have been your mother."

I stopped eating. Was Mom saying what I thought she was?

Andy asked, "What do you mean?"

Dad smiled. "Before that class, my name was Melissa, and your mother's was Vance. The schoolwork brought us together, and the assignment made us realize that we wanted to be the opposite sex."

"So," Mom continued, "once the project was completed, we asked Professor Switch to make our gender changes permanent."
1421221122112121111111111221.title: At supper

14212211221121211111111112212.content:
The next morning, Andy and I sat down with Mom again at breakfast. "Your father had to go to work early," Mom said. "That's a lovely ponytail, Sam."

"Thanks," I replied. "My new roommate showed me how. I don't know if I'll ever get used to all this hair."

"I know what you mean," said Andy. "I'm used to running my hand through my hair, and I don't have as much anymore."

"I'm sure the two of you will do fine," Mom said. Then, she changed the subject. "What would you like to do this weekend?"

Andy and I shrugged. "I don't know," I said.

"What is there to do," Andy added, "with no classes?"

"Just because we're a school of witches," Mom explained, "doesn't mean we live in complete isolation from the outside world. On Saturdays and Sundays, all students who are not under disciplinary action are allowed to go into town for a few hours. You can go to a restaurant and eat what you'd like, then you can shop, or see a movie."

"Sounds good," I said. "How's it work?"

"The same buses that brought our other students here, and will bring them back home for vacation, will carry you to town. I, along with other faculty members, will chaperone. Now that Professor Nurse has begun to age again, she'll be going along, although she will pretend to be a student. You will be required to wear your school uniforms, so that the townsfolk will know where you're from, so be on your best behavior."

"Sounds great," Andy said. "I don't know what I'll do in town, but I'll think of something."

Then, something dawned on me. "Wait a minute. If I go into town, I'll run into my friends from before. How will I explain why I'm a girl?"

"Don't worry, Sam," Mom said. "Your friends from before won't recognize you. You and Andy can interact with them as if you're two kids from out of town. They won't be the wiser."
14212211221121211111111112212.title: The next day

142122112211212111111111122122.content:
It was finally Friday afternoon; classes for the day were over, and I was free for the weekend and looking forward to going to town for some shopping. My roommate, Tabitha Wilkins, was a great help in my adapting to the life of a girl. She was about my height, with long black hair and gentle green eyes. Thankfully, Ms. Good's spell made being a girl a little easier than I had first feared. However, she did not make everything easy, as it was meant to be a new experience. I had to get used to wearing the girls' school uniform and girls' clothing. Although the spell kept me from blushing ten shades of red, it all still felt alien to me. Still, Tabitha helped me through the transition, and I was now putting on some makeup, to get ready for my first sleepover.

"You are adjusting far better than I had originally hoped, Samantha," smiling, Tabitha said. "When you first came here, under the extra credit challenge, you didn't know a thing about being a girl." She giggled. "Now look at you, acting as if you'd been a girl all your life."

I blushed at that, not realizing how cute it made me look. "You've been a great help, Tabitha," I said, smiling. "Without you, I'd probably still be making a mess of my face with this makeup."

Tabitha laughed. "I remember the first time you tried to put it on yourself. You looked like a science experiment gone wrong."

I laughed with her, remembering. It was three days ago, I wanted to really learn the full experience, so I borrowed some of Tabitha's makeup and tried my best to put it on myself. As I had no idea what to use first, or what colors worked best for my face, I just randomly put the stuff on.

Now, looking into the mirror, I saw a beautiful girl staring back at me and sighed. "Mom and Dad met each other this way. I wonder where my experience will take me."

"Only one way to find out, girl," grabbing my arm, Tabitha said. "Let's get to that sleepover, so you can make some new friends."

I smiled at that, and followed Tabitha out of our dorm room...
142122112211212111111111122122.title: Adjusting well.

1421221122112121111111111221221.content:
I walked with Tabitha into Chalice Hall, where we met up with an upperclasswoman who seemed to have been waiting for us to arrive. She smiled, making us both wince. Seeing this, she sighed. "You two have nothing to fear from pranks tonight," serious, she said. "This sleepover is a school function, to allow all the students, young and old, to get to know each other."

Hearing that caused Tabitha and me to relax a little. "Some of those pranks the seventh years pull on the first years are borderline cruelty," tearing up, I said. "I saw one girl get turned into a doll by one of them. She told me that she got carried around from class to class, being treated like a piece of property, missing a full day of her own classes."

The girl nodded. "The girl responsible was punished for that, I assure you," serious, she said. "Ravenscroft Academy does not tolerate such cruel mischief." she frowned. "She spent a day in the trophy case, as a mannequin, to teach her what it is like to be treated like property." She then smiled. "Enough business. I am Melissa Stonehenge; welcome to the all-girls sleepover."

"Thank you," smiling back, I said. "This is my first sleepover, so I'm kind of curious to see what is done at one." Melissa gave me a curious look, but giggled when I added, "Professor Good's extra credit challenge."

"How do you like womanhood so far?" smiling, Melissa asked. "Most boys who get their gender switched avoid this function, fearing they would get to like being girls."

"Its strange, and does take some getting used to," blushing a little, I said. "All in all, though, it's not so bad."

Melissa nodded, then stepped aside, allowing us to enter the common room ceremony hall, where dozens of other girls were talking amongst themselves. I recognized one as Nico Child, from Professor Good's class, and walked over to her. "I'm glad to see I'm not the only transformed boy to attend this sleepover." startling her, I said.

Nico sighed. "Sorry, you startled me," catching her breath, she said. "Recent events have me a bit jumpy."

"I had my share," thinking of John sneaking onto campus, I replied. "How are you taking to the experience?"

"Being a girl I can get used to," frowning slightly, Nico said. "It's some of the things girls do, and now I'm finding myself doing, that have me stumped."

"Like what?" curious, you asked.

"Switching from one emotion extreme to another, for one," sighing, Nico replied. "Sometimes, I don't know what I am feeling, and it makes it harder to talk about it to anyone who has not experienced it." She sighed. "I never thought it could start as early as eleven..."

"One of a million mysteries," giggling, I said. Only I stopped giggling when Tabitha whispered in my ear, and I blushed brightly, as I turned back to Nico. "I- I'm so sorry," I stammered. "I didn't know."

"It's no big, just a period," sniffing, Nico said. "Dr. Willard told me that the scare I had earlier could have triggered it to start early, but it also means...." she tearfully sighed.

"Your chances of changing back have diminished?" Tabitha guessed.

Nico held back a sob as she nodded. "Dr. Willard explained that there is a standing rule spell here, that places a child into a magickal 'lock down' if her menstrual cycle starts early, as their emotions will run dangerously high," tears falling, she said. "The spell that changed me is locked and may not be reversible."

"When will you know for certain?" concerned, I asked.

"At the end of the year, when the curse is due to cancel itself," frowning, Nico replied. "Ironically, I find myself uncertain if I want to change back."

Hearing that, I smiled. "You have a full year to worry about this," taking her arm, I said. "Come on, there will be no pranks here tonight, so let's get to know everyone."

"Go on, Nico," stepping up, Tonya said. "It'll be good for you to mingle a little."

Nico sighed, then followed me into the crowd, where we talked to a group of...
1421221122112121111111111221221.title: The sleepover.

14212211221121211111111112212212.content:
I put my guard up instinctively, on seeing the group of seventh-year students. I'm sure I wasn't the only one.

"Just a reminder," Melissa said, "there will be no pranks tonight. You are all safe here, as in your own beds."

"But why are some of the pranks so cruel?" Nico asked. "My roommate was stripped naked, in front of everybody."

"The pranks aren't supposed to escalate into cruelty," replied an upperclasswoman. "They're supposed to get you on your toes, in case you're attacked by a witch with bad intentions. Unfortunately, there's no way to weed out the malicious ones."

"Try to remember," said another, "that we were all first-year students, ourselves. We were pranked, just like you. And Mrs. Procter was still in college in our first year, so we didn't have her keeping an eye out for us."

"And those of you with older siblings," added another, "know that pranks don't stop at the gate. Some of us got pranked in our own homes, by older brothers and sisters looking to get a rise out of us."

"Excuse me," the first girl said, "but I don't think I've seen you before." She pointed to me. "How did you get in here?"

"I'm Sam Procter," I replied. "I took Professor Good's extra-credit assignment."

She relaxed, and laughed in recognition. "I hope you've got a good partner, Sam. I spent the entire semester with a thing."

Hearing all these stories, I began to relax. The seventh-years weren't that different from us, just older and more experienced. Most of their pranks weren't supposed to be mean-spirited, just a little embarrassing.

"You okay, Nico?" asked one girl, seeing her clutch her abdomen.

"First period," she replied. "I was attacked by a cowan, and they think that started me off early."

"You'll be okay, Nico," said the second upperclasswoman. "Everybody here knows what you're going through, or knows someone who does. I'm sure even Sam, here, has heard some stories."

"Not really," I replied. "Nobody thinks to talk to boys about menstrual cycles. That may be part of what's got Nico so scared. Nothing she's been told before has prepared her for this."

Nico squeezed my hand. "Thanks."

I squeezed back, and thought of how, if I were still a boy, I would have thought about kissing her. I gave her a peck on the cheek, anyway. She wiped at her cheek and smiled.

My thoughts from earlier returned to me. Was Nico the person I would meet, as a result of my seeking extra credit?
14212211221121211111111112212212.title: seventh year students.

142122112211212111111111122122122.content:
As we spoke with the older girls, one of the teachers popped in. "Just a reminder, children," she said, "tomorrow, those of you who are doing well in your classes will be allowed to take one of our buses into town for a few hours. There, you will be free to shop, or see a movie. This is not strictly a school function, but you are encouraged to wear your uniforms, and to conduct yourselves as representatives of Ravenscroft Academy."

Nico raised her hand. "Will there be pranks?"

The teacher smiled. "As I said, those who are allowed to go must present a positive face for the school. Also, students should refrain from using magick in town, lest we be exposed to cowan eyes."



When we were done socializing, it was time for bed, so we unrolled our sleeping bags. Nico was almost ready for bed, but she quickly ran to the restroom.

When she returned, I asked, "Are you okay?"

"Early puberty is rough," she said. "Sometimes, I'd really like to get my hands on the man who put me through this."

"From what I hear, if Wardwell got his way, he would do worse than you could think of."

"Worse than growing breasts and having periods? I can't think of it."

"Everything will be okay, Nico. Relax. We get to have some fun in town, remember."

She settled down. "A movie would be nice."

I gasped. "I just remembered. My friends live in town."

"So you'd get to hang out with them?"

"Avoid them, is more like it. I can't explain to them why I've got long hair, and am wearing a skirt."

"Guess it's my turn to tell you to relax. You'll be a face in the crowd. Maybe they won't even recognize you. They'd be looking for a boy, not a girl."

I supposed she had a point. After we both calmed down, we went to sleep.
142122112211212111111111122122122.title: Bedding down for the night

1421221122112121111111111221221221.content:
Morning came, and we started washing up and getting dressed. "How'd you sleep, Nico?" I asked.

"I had a dream that really bothered me," she replied. "I dreamed I went home for winter break, and my folks had a dress laid out for me on my bed."

"It might not mean anything, Nico," said an older girl, the one who told of spending a whole semester as a boy. "From what you said, you could very well be a girl when you really do go home, and your brain is just telling you that."

Nico nodded, but she didn't seem convinced to me.



After showering, I got dressed. I was just putting on my shoes and socks when Maddalena came into the room, with a small bag tied to her collar. "Morning, Maddie."

*Good morning,* she replied. *Do you have any treats?*

"Huh? Uh, no. I didn't know you'd be coming."

*You didn't know I wouldn't be coming, either,* she shot back, as she hopped into my lap. *Whatever. You do have fingernails. Scratch.*

I started scratching between her ears, and was rewarded with the sounds of her purring. "What brings you here to see me?"

*Your mother sent me. The bag tied to my collar holds your allowance.*

I untied the bag, only to have Maddie protest. *Don't stop.*

"I need both hands to get this bag off your collar."

*Fine.*

I opened the bag, and found a $20 bill. "If you see Mom before I do, please thank her for me."

*I definitely will see her before you. She has treats.*

"Point made, Maddie." I made a mental note to be sure to pick up a bag of cat treats, just in case Maddie paid me any more visits.
1421221122112121111111111221221221.title: Next morning

14212211221121211111111112212212211.content:
Students gathered in the front courtyard, where buses waited to bring us into town. "Do we just get on?" I asked.

"Not yet," said an upperclasswoman. "One of the faculty chaperones each bus, and we don't get on until they do."

As the teachers approached, I realized that our bus would have two faculty members: Mom and Professor Nurse. "You're coming, Professor Nurse?"

"Yes, I am," she replied, "but please remember to call me Eleanor when we're in town. People would think it strange if you called such a young girl Professor. I'll be meeting with my former husband. He and his second wife will be posing as my parents to the community at large."

Nico shifted uncomfortably. I could see that her clothes didn't seem to fit quite right. Apparently, early puberty was giving her a growth spurt. "Are you alright, dear?" Mom asked.

"Itchy," Nico replied. "Early puberty."

"I can certainly sympathize, child," Professor Nurse said, putting an arm around Nico. "Puberty was brutal for me the first time around, and I'm not looking forward to going through it again."

Our faculty chaperones boarded the buses, and we got on after them. I was able to get a seat close to Nico, who had Professor Nurse close by, as well. Andy sat next to me.
14212211221121211111111112212212211.title: Heading for town

142122112211212111111111122122122111.content:
The buses stopped to let us off in the shopping district. After Andy and I got off, we stood next to our bus as others let off the other students. While we were waiting, I noticed one of the teachers getting off another bus. Her stunted limbs made her less than three feet tall. "Who's that, Mom?"

"That's Professor Wilds, Sam. You'll have her in seventh year."

Once all the students were off, the buses pulled away. "Alright, students," Mom told us, "you will all have four hours to shop, eat or take in a movie. In four hours' time, report back here for the bus back to Ravenscroft. Don't be late, any of you."

Andy and I both went to the grocery store. "Maddalena talked to you about treats, too?" Andy asked.

"Yep. You grow up hearing stories about familiars, but I don't remember any saying that they were still house pets."

"Maybe we'll learn more in the years to come," he replied. "I can tell you one thing: In my schooling before, none of my teachers was a midget."

"A-hem."

We turned. Professor Wilds was standing right behind us.

Andy swallowed. "S-sorry, Professor. I should have said 'little person'."

"'Little person' is certainly the polite term," Professor Wilds replied, walking between us. "However, for students, the correct term for me is 'Professor'."
142122112211212111111111122122122111.title: In town

1421221122112121111111111221221221111.content:
After we were done with our shopping, we walked along, talking about what to do next. "Want to see a movie?"

"Not really," Andy replied.

"Hi, kids," called a voice behind us.

We looked. Professor Nurse had joined us. "Hi."

As she approached, she spoke more quietly. "I'll be having lunch with my ex-husband and his family. Care to join me?"

"We wouldn't want to impose," I said.

"It's no imposition," she replied. "Besides, even if we somehow missed the bus back, we could still get back to Ravenscroft, and I'd vouch for you."

That did sound good. "Okay," Andy said, "we'd be glad to join you."

As the three of us walked to where the professor's ex lived, she asked, "How's the extra credit going? Learning anything?"

"Quite a bit," I replied. "I've noticed how many ads and magazine covers depict women, and I keep catching myself comparing my body to theirs, even though I'll go back to being a boy once we figure out how to make the talisman."

"Always remember, Sam," Professor Nurse said, "in the eyes of the Goddess, we are all beautiful. All that matters is that we are healthy, in mind, body, and spirit."
1421221122112121111111111221221221111.title: Meeting Professor Nurse

14212211221121211111111112212212211111.content:
Professor Nurse's ex-husband met us at the door. "Hello, Rebecca," he said. "Who do we have here?"

"These are two of my students," she replied, "Sam and Andy Procter, Vanessa's children. They're taking extra credit in Charms, Amulets, and Talismans."

"Good to meet you both," he said. "I remember Rebecca telling me about Mrs. Procter's son going missing. I'm glad you made it back. If anyone outside the school asks, we're Rebecca's parents."

The family was certainly getting along. There was a seven-year-old boy running around, and Mrs. Nurse was five months pregnant. "I'm a bit surprised by how happy you all seem," Andy said. "Most of the divorced couples I knew before couldn't stand being in the same room."

"Handparting is a simple matter for us," Professor Nurse said. "We remember how things were, but we recognize that they are not that way any longer."

Mr. Nurse nodded. "If we had been separated by some circumstance other than Rebecca becoming a child again, I'd like to think that we would still be friends."

As we sat down to eat, Mrs. Nurse said, "So, you're two of Rebecca's students?"

"Yes, ma'am."

"They're taking extra credit," Mr. Nurse added.

Mrs. Nurse shivered. "I never had the courage for that. I wanted back in my own body as soon as possible. How's it going for you?"

"I'm certainly learning a lot," I said. "After half an hour looking at Cowan magazines, I started wondering if I was fat."

"It's good that you take this experience with you," Professor Nurse said. "Make the world better for all of the Goddess's children."

"I'd better tell you, Rebecca," Mr. Nurse said, "Ravenscroft will be visited by an accreditation team in a couple of weeks."

She nodded. "We'll have our glamours up."

"'Glamours'?" I asked.

"Special spells to conceal the truth from Cowan eyes," she explained. "Mine makes me look like a 40-year-old woman. Most of the magickal classes will look like art and literature classes. And the flying class will be invisible."

"What does Wardwell do?" Andy asked.

"Not much. He's proud of his height. He simply conceals the nature of some of the plants he grows."
14212211221121211111111112212212211111.title: The professor's family

142122112211212111111111122122122111111.content:
After our lunch with Professor Nurse's family, we went back to meet the bus to go back to Ravenscroft. There, we met Nico again. "What did you guys do?" she asked.

"Professor Nurse bumped into us and invited us to lunch with her family," I replied. "How about you?"

"I went to see a movie."

Once we were back on the bus, Nico asked, "Can I ask you two a favor?"

"What is it?"

"When you two work on your talisman against the gender spell, can I join you? I don't have a partner, and, since the spell I'm under blocks it, I wouldn't know if what I was doing worked."

"Sure," Andy said. "I have an idea for how to do it, and I picked up enough ingredients that we can split it three ways."

Back at Ravenscroft, Mom asked Andy and me, "How was your trip?"

"Professor Nurse invited us to her family's place. They say there's an accreditation team coming by soon."

"I'll make sure word gets out," Mom said. "So you know, when the accreditation team is walking around, all pranks are forbidden. Any plans for the rest of the day?"

"I've got an idea for the gender talisman," Andy replied. "Nico will be working with us."

"Good. Helping a fellow student is always good to see. Blessed be, you three."
142122112211212111111111122122122111111.title: Continue

151.content:
"Piper!" Jak bellowed.

Oh, crap. I hid the dagger I'd been using to fight a tree (that's right, a tree - what else was I suppose to practice on?) in the sleeve of my loose shirt.
"Yes?" I turned around, to face my dear older brother. Sarcasm on the "dear" part. "What is it?"

"Mom wants to talk to you," Jak said, brusquely. He was that sort of fellow: tall, large in girth, with a rough attitude.

"Fine, whatever." I tugged at my dress, making sure I looked presentable.

"C'mon, Pipes." Jak turned around and began walking to the large mansion we call home.

"Coming," I called, jogging to keep up with him as I combed my hair with my hands. "What does she want?"

Jak lowers his voice. "It's about Ravenscroft."

I felt a thrill of anticipation go through me. Mom didn't talk about the school much, but I knew it would be time for me to go. After all, I'd already shown I had magickal capabilities, if the fact that Billy Brensworth is now walking around convinced he was a famous musician was any clue. "I hope it's good," I mused.

"I doubt it."

"One of our ancestors was involved with the prosecution in those trials."

"Whoa. A-and they didn't know they had witches in the family?"

I sat down quickly, before I could fall down. "I don't understand. Why would a witch go against his own kind?"

"We ready to go home, then, guys?" a young man asked his group.

"You know it, Ryan," said a guy a bit older than him.

"Of course," said a girl who was the young man's lover.

"Let's head back," said a young boy 3 years younger than the man.

The person they were talking to was called Ryan Carlson, a young 17-year-old attending Starmage academy for witches and hunters. It was a school based in the UK, much different than Ravenscroft. The girls were trained as witches and the boys as the witch hunters, and people born in the UK had a sort of immunity to TG and shrinking. Starmage also had boys and girls share the same dorm rooms, to allow equality in all aspects. Ryan was once a normal teen. That all changed, however, when he discovered his Mother's magick. Shortly after that, Ryan had to battle a rogue witch, and won out of sheer luck. Then, his destiny set, he traveled to Asia to learn martial arts. He also made a pact with a mystical katana that belonged to a warrior called Asura.

The older man was Chon Kay, an 18-year-old from China. He had had a dark past: his older brother had been slain by witches when Chon was a young lad. Seeing his brother murdered made him tear his own eyes out in sheer horror. Since that day, Chon trained in martial arts and the use of chi energy to see, while donning a blindfold to cover his loss of eyes. All so he could wreak his revenge against those witches. He may not be from the UK, but he carries the same immunity to magick as Ryan does, due to his intense hatred of magick. In fact, using magick on him often just makes him angry.

The girl was named Jenny Forth, a 16-year-old witch. Her magic was done differently from most witches, she required a book which belonged to her Grandmother. The reason for this was known to only Ryan's group: she was half cat, which was shown when her cat ears were out. She used magic to cover that feature up. She and Ryan had met before Starmage, and they dated at Ryan's old school for awhile. Then, one day, she left, leaving Ryan a hoodie that belonged to her. Then, when they met at Starmage, the two rekindled the flame. She was Ryan's chain and morality pet.

Lastly, there was a young man called Alexander, a 14-year-old who was an old friend of Ryan's. They knew each other ever since Ryan helped out in a fight when Alexander was younger. Alexander's fighting style was a mixture of fighting with a rapier and summoning a large robot to aid him in his fighting.

Now that the four had finished saving the world as only they could, they stepped into the magic portal to return to their school.

But as they did, they realized that they were flying. That was normal, as they were flung around the world by use of this portal. But it was taking much longer than normal.

"What's happening?!" Ryan yelled out, as they kept falling.

"I think it's a problem with the spell! It must be on their side!" Jenny yelled as she kept hold of her book.

"This isn't good!" Chon said.

"Stay together!" Alexander said to all of them.

Just then, the world reappeared around them. However, they quickly found out that they were not anywhere near Starmage academy. Rather, they were at Ravenscroft. But where exactly were they?

At this some of the guests at my birthday celebration stepped aside to reveal a small pile of wrapped gifts. "Those presents" explained dad.

15311.content:
The witches led me to a white van with tinted windows. After loading in my trunk, they silently motioned for me to come inside, and I did. Not only was it difficult to see into the van, but it was also tricky to see out of it. Later I'd realize the van was magicked with a powerful shield, but at the time, I think, I had other concerns.

I still didn't quite believe that magick was real. I thought this was either a prank, or perhaps my parents had finally abandoned me for good. I didn't even look at the others. For some reason I felt shame. As if they sensed my feelings, the others gave me lots of room in the van, remained quiet and left me to my own devices. I passed the time looking down, trying to sing songs in my head to cheer myself up.

We didn't drive for nearly as long as I thought we would. For some reason I had expected a journey of at least many hours, but somehow, we reached the place in only a few minutes. The others ushered me outside, together with my trunk, and sped off down the road without a word.

My first impression was not of the academy itself, but the surrounding countryside. A far cry from the suburbia I grew up in, Ravenscroft was set on a beautiful country estate. Surrounding the property were green fields, lush forests and gentle, rolling hills. A large stone archway comprised the entrance to a long path with beautiful fountains to the sides, freshly mowed lawns, sweet flowers and water features. Of course, I didn't know what I'd expected, but the sweet breeze and wonderful scenery did much to calm my nerves.

Walking down the path, and dragging my trunk behind me, I began to get a closer look at the main building of Ravenscroft. It was a large, imposing chateau, apparently with a 17th-century architecture. It reminded me of a painting I'd once seen of a royal French palace, but certain features, such as the narrow windows, seemed much more gothic in appearance. I thought about this as I walked, since I was a gifted young student. The building was made of yellow bricks, although the roof was red and tiled. Behind the main building I could see several other, smaller buildings built in a similar architectural style. Being something of a nerd in many respects, including architecture, I had to admit it actually looked kind of cool.

I didn't take it in for long, though, as my thoughts were interrupted by the sound of an enormous BANG! It sounded like a cannon firing right in front of me. Instinctively I curled up into a little ball on the ground and looked on fearfully. On the far side of the building I could hear shattering glass and screaming. A plume of red-grey dust rose up behind the building, followed soon after by a large flock of crows. The plume slowly dissipated into the air, while the crows flew off into the distance.

From that moment on, it dawned on me that this wasn't just an out-of-the-ordinary school. Magick, I realized, could be dangerous. I hoped the school had good safety procedures in place.

Composing myself, I stood up, dusted myself off, and picked up the handle of my trunk of belongings. A little more cautiously now, I walked through the idyllic setting towards the large imposing school building.

As I approached the oversize, heavy wooden doorway at the front, I began to wonder how in the world a small girl like me was going to open it. Luckily, the handles moved themselves as I approached and the door swung open with a heavy creak.

"Blessed be" said the door in a deep voice as I passed through it.
"Blessed be" I replied instinctively, before suddenly realizing how odd it was to be talking to a door.

Just beyond the door was a large foyer. In the middle of the foyer was an open fire, the smoke from which was entirely covering the ceiling of the room. Nonetheless the room was at least two stories high. Numerous passageways led out from this chamber, and all over the plastered walls were ancient paintings, statues and other ornate artifacts. Besides the fire, the room was unlit, giving the whole place a smokey, mystical appearance. Next to the fire, I saw an old woman looking deeply into the dancing red flames, as well as a large, albeit cute, dog sleeping beside her. She wore long, dark robes and sat perfectly still, as though she were meditating.

"Uh - blessed be?" I asked "My name is Eva. Eva Dawn. I was sent here by my parents?"
"I see" croaked the old woman, without taking her eyes from the fire "You must be the daughter of Richard and Emma Dawn?"
"Uhm - yes" I replied uncertainly.
The old woman smiled. "I remember them. Both good witches. I sense great magick power in you, young Eva. But you must be careful. Your parents have many foes. In fact, I would think it wise not to tell anybody else about your parents. But also you must never be afraid to help others. Do not forget that power corrupts, Eva. Harm none."
I pondered on this for a moment. "Who are you, exactly?"
"I am the keeper of the fire" the old woman croaked in almost a whisper "I have tended to these flames for many generations. I have seen many witches come and go. Any student is welcome to sit with me whensoever they wish."
I thought that was odd. Why did this school need to keep an open fire burning indoors for that long? Perhaps it was some archaic tradition, I thought to myself, which the school could not let go of.
"Oh" I replied after some hesitation "So, do you know what I'm meant to do now?"
"I prophecy one of our senior students will come by to show you around in thirty four seconds" said the woman in a low, dramatic whisper.
I wondered whether all witches were such drama queens.

Exactly thirty four seconds later, a teenage girl strutted into the room. She was wearing a fashionable crop top and high cut jeans, giving her an exceptionally beautiful appearance. "Blessed be kiddo, I'm Caitlin" she said sweetly "Welcome to Ravenscroft academy for young witches."
"Blessed be. I'm Eva," you replied quietly. For some reason you couldn't explain, you were much more confident talking to the old lady by the fire compared to this fellow student.
"Well, welcome Eva, to your new home!" said Caitlin "Come on, let me show you around!"

Caitlin led you down one of the hallways, while you dragged your heavy trunk behind you. You wondered why Caitlin didn't cast a spell to make your trunk any lighter as you went. Most of the building's interior seemed dimly lit yet very clean, with fire torches for lighting. The smoke was much less intense than you might have expected, however. You walked past numerous heavy wooden doors through the labyrinthine corridors before ascending a staircase and seeing a window with a view to the gardens outside. Would you ever find your way around this whole place, you wondered?

Eventually Caitlin stopped. "This will be your first classroom here." she explained "The door is locked right now but your first class is tomorrow. It's like a new-entrant class for witches, you just learn the real basics at first."

You nodded, and Caitlin kept walking. "If you ever get confused, just follow the others" she explained "I know it's a bit daunting to find your way around this whole place at first."

Caitlin showed you the way to the mess hall - a large dining room with ornate silverware and candles - the middle school lounge - a cosy affair which, to your surprise, featured a huge wide-screen TV - various bathrooms, and, eventually, your dorm room. Inside the dorm there were six bunk beds, all made up with fine sheets and bedding, as well as a fireplace, some cupboards for storage, a private ensuite bathroom, a narrow window, and a huge chandelier hanging from the roof. Besides five of the bunk beds stood others who looked about your age - three boys and two other girls - all staring at you. It was freaky.

"Blessed be" said the door to your dorm as you walked inside.
"Uh - am I supposed to say something back to the doors if they talk to me?" I asked Caitlin. I hoped that wasn't a stupid question.
"Well it would be polite" explained the door.
"Well, blessed be, I guess" I said. Caitlin chuckled to herself. "You'll get used to it" she said.

"Blessed be! Welcome to our dorm" said one of the boys, wearing a loose Hawaiian shirt that showed off his beach body "I'm Ben. I love sports, especially surfing."
"I'm Jack" said another boy, wearing expensive looking clothes and a golden watch "I like business and investment."
"Amy" said one of the girls, adjusting her glasses "I like reading and science."
"Liam" said the last boy, who was quite small, "I ... don't really know why I'm here. I miss my mummy."
"And I'm Jessica" cheered the remaining girl "I like unicorns and rainbows and candy!"

You blinked as they all looked at you, as though they expected you to say something back. All you could think was how normal all their hobbies seemed. For some reason you'd expected witches to have really odd hobbies, like milking frogs, taming dragons, or staring into a fire for decades.

"Oh" you managed to splutter out eventually "I'm, uh ... I'm Eva, I guess. Blessed be all of you."
You smile faintly hoping the others in your new room will like you.

"I'll leave you to get settled" said Caitlin, leaving the room "Bright blessings, Eva!"
And with that she was gone.

You laughed nervously to yourself as you saw your roommates stare at you again. Could things get any less intimidating?
15311.title: Orientation to Ravenscroft

153111.content:
After an awkward moment, Jack spoke up. "Gosh that Caitlin is beautiful, isn't she?" he mused dreamily.
"Yeah ... I'm so jealous of her boyfriend" said Ben.
"Get a grip, both of you" snapped Amy "You're both eleven. Right now we have a new girl in our dorm and that's what you talk about? Seriously."
For some reason, Liam looked away out of the window, apparently sobbing gently to himself.
While Amy scolded Jack and Ben, Jessica came up to me. "Here, I got you some chocolates!" she said cheerily, handing you a pink box with a white bow "They're not magick or anything, but they taste so good they might as well be!"
"Thanks" I said quietly, dragging my trunk towards the lockers.
"You can have this bottom one" explained Jessica, twirling around in her cute pink dress "Want me to help you with that trunk?"
"I'll be fine" I say as I begin to unpack "What's going on with Liam?"
"We don't know. He won't really talk to us" said Jessica "He seems to like the teddy bear I bought him, but I think he doesn't like being a witch. He keeps saying that he misses his parents and that this is all a mistake. But getting him to open up seems impossible."

I understood perfectly. The whole experience was totally overwhelming to me, too.

Soon enough I'd packed away my things. My bed was between Jessica and Ben, so Jessica and I decided to play chess together. Unfortunately, Jessica was a much better player than I was, and kept beating me in only a few moves. Her chess set was unusual too, with all the pieces and squares being pink and white instead of black and white.

"All of us are still quite new here" said Jessica "Ben's been here the longest, and he only joined something like a month ago. Jack joined soon after ... Amy and I have been here for about two weeks each. Liam just joined a few days ago."
"Are we all in the same class?" I asked.
"Yes, we will be" explained Jessica "Our teacher's Professor Lewis ... he's a bit mad, but really nice."
"That's good" I said "Let's play again."

After being thrashed in chess about a hundred times, Ben told me it was time for dinner. As I went with Ben towards the dining room, he tried to make conversation.
"You seemed to get on well with Jessica" he noted.
"Yeah, she's nice" I said quietly, looking down.
"Sorry I couldn't help but gush about Caitlin before" apologized Ben "You could say she's one of the most popular girls around for a reason."
"I get it" I said simply.
"So, uhm ... do you like sports? Ever tried surfing?"
"I've never really tried" I explained "I've always just lived at home with a private tutor. My parents were rarely ever around."
Ben nodded. "Mine either" he explained "They were both witches who went to magick prison. Some bastard called Richard Dawn locked them both up."
"Oh" I said, making a mental note never to tell Ben about my heritage.
"Anyway, surfing is lots of fun! I've got to show you one day!" he said enthusiastically. I just smiled.

Dinner was nice. On my plate I found a delicious roast chicken with gravy, fresh steamed vegetables and potato. I noticed other kids had other foods on their plates, all presented as though it were created by the finest chefs. For dessert, I had sweet chocolate ice-cream and cake. Everyone talked around me, but I just smiled and concentrated on finishing my food. When I drank the orange juice in my cup, I noticed the cup automatically refilled itself. It was amazing.

After dinner, I saw the others from my dorm room head towards the middle school lounge. Except Liam. Liam went back to the room. I thought it would be better to give Liam some space, and followed the others to the lounge, remembering to say "Blessed be" whenever a door opened itself for you.

The scene looked like a party. There was music (which sounded a lot like the pop music you were used to), people drinking juice and pure water from ever-refilling cups, video games played on the giant TV, dancing, excited chatter and party games galore.
"So I guess this is what witches do every night to unwind?" I thought out loud to myself "Huh, who knew..."
"Pretty much" said Jessica, appearing behind you from out of nowhere "Hey Eva, this is Julie. Julie, Eva."
I looked at the red-haired girl Jessica was introducing me too. She looked down towards the ground with her sweet blue eyes. I did too.
"Julie is pretty new here too, but she's a great dancer" explained Jessica "I've been trying to convince her to let loose a bit more. Would it be ok if she taught you how to dance?"
"Uhm ... if she wants to" I said quietly.
"I... uhm..." whimpered Julie quietly "Ok Jess."
"Great!" cheered Jessica enthusiastically "Hey DJ! Switch to track nine!"

Immediately the record that was playing skipped, and a blond haired boy at the front with large headphones on switched the track to a soft Cuban beat. Immediately the pace of dancing around the room switched from fast to something slower and smoother - which was good, since I definitely would trip over myself if I tried to dance quickly.

Julie held you hands softly and pulled herself tight against your body until you could feel her breath (which, thankfully, smelt like peppermint) on your face. "Follow my lead" she whispered softly "Just do what I do"

I did a few simple steps, dancing across the room. It wasn't anything special, but it was clear from the little flourishes she did that she was an accomplished dancer. I just tried to follow along as best I could. The whole experience was alien to me.
