Not because there were small, minor touches of magic around the place (though far less than I would have expected) but because I'd never been in such a social environment before. Every so often, Jessica would come past, each time talking to different people, to check up on how we were doing. We'd both shyly tell her we were fine - I got the impression Julie was NOT comfortable with showing off in any way. I could imagine her having serious stage fright. Jessica, I began to realize, was the resident party animal. I saw the others, too - Ben was among the guys playing video games. Amy was being surprisingly non-social, reading a book in the corner by the fire with a few others - I thought maybe tomorrow night I should go directly there. And Jack was dancing too, though he occasionally would play games of tag or something like it, running around the room with some of the others.

I actually didn't expect the slow dancing to be nearly as exhausting as it was. After a short period of time, Julie noticed me looking tired. "Do you want to go to bed?" she asked.
"Yeah, I've had a long first day" you explained.
Julie nodded. "Just wait until you have class tomorrow" she said, before signalling for Jessica to come over.

Jessica led you back to the dorm so you wouldn't get lost. You noticed in the dorm had the lights out, and Liam was apparently asleep in his bed.
"Good night" whispered Jessica with a smile "I'll tell the others not to wake you up"
"Night" I whispered back, as Jessica left to go back to the common area.

I sighed, before heading for the ensuite bathroom. After a quick shower and a brush of my teeth - during which I wondered whether I'd ever learn to speed up that process through magick - I put on my pajamas and slid into my cosy, warm bed. It was still unfamiliar to me - I was used to a much less comfortable bed than this one - but I was too exhausted to care.

As I began to drift into sleep, I remember vividly hearing Liam sob to himself on his bed.
153111.title: The first night at Ravenscroft

1531111.content:
I woke up early the next morning. After a yawn and a stretch, I pulled myself out of my comfortable covers and towards the bathroom. As I did so, I noticed everyone else was seemingly fast asleep. I noticed Jessica was a bit of an oddity, sleeping on top of her covers rather than between them, and wearing only pink lingerie. After a warm shower and going through the rest of my morning bathroom routine, I went back to the dorm room. Here I saw Amy was also awake by now, reading a book on potions while waiting to use the bathroom. "Blessed be" she said casually as she set down the book and passed me.
"Blessed be" I whispered back.

I crept back towards my bed and got changed into my clothes underneath the covers. I noticed my bed made itself every time I came off it, which was extremely useful, because I was not good at making my bed neatly.

One by one the others stood up, Jessica being last. Everyone said "blessed be" to each other as they woke up. I amused yourself for a while by sitting down on my bed repeatedly and watching it re-make itself every time, no matter how much I messed it up. Eventually, Amy finished. "Want to come down with me for breakfast?" she asked "Oh, just leave your dirty laundry on your bed. It'll be clean by the time you come back from breakfast."
"Oh, uhm, ok" I said to myself, a bit unsure.

"I've only been here a bit more than a week" said Amy "My mum was a cowan - apparently that's what they call non-magical people - and my dad was a witch. They both worked in the city library, so I got to read a lot as a child. Eventually I even found a few of my dad's secret books and learnt a few simple spells. The professor says I'm one of the gifted ones."
"Hey, the keeper of the fire said the same thing to me!" I said, remembering "Maybe we'll be in a group together."
"That would be nice" replied Amy as I entered the dining room, hoping I'd have cereal wherever we decided to sit down.

Strangely enough, I saw Julie talking with a boy at a nearby table. We both decided to sit down beside them without a word, and I was happy to notice that seemingly by dumb luck, I had a bowl of cereal with fresh milk right in front of me.
"Oh yeah, apparently the cooks prophecy exactly what we will want to eat and where we will sit" explained Amy, noticing my look of confusion.
"You get used to it" said Julie softly, with a faint smile "Blessed be."
"Blessed be" said everyone else.
"Have you met Andrew yet?" asked Amy, gesturing to the boy.
I looked down in case I had but didn't recall. Everything was happening so fast and there were so many new faces to remember.
"I'm from Julie's dorm" said Andrew by way of introduction "I like drawing and playing the guitar."
"Nice to meet you" I managed quietly "I'm sorry, I'm not used to meeting so many new people. Everyone is so different, too!"
"Well, we all have only one thing in common" noted Amy "All of us are witches. Witches don't just come from one walk of life - there's books in the library about the sociology of witchcraft, very interesting stuff."
I smiled faintly. Being friends with Amy would definitely be helpful for any assignments I was set.

Soon I was packing a small bag for class in my dorm room. Jessica had apparently stayed up most of the night in the middle school lounge party, so she slept in for a long time and had to skip breakfast. Nonetheless she was as sociable as ever. I noticed she didn't talk with Amy much, however.
"I like your shirt" Jessica told me as all six of us headed for class. I smiled back at her in reply.
Behind the five of us, Liam sulked with his head in his hands, walking as reluctantly as he possibly could.

I shared a blessing with the classroom door, allowing us entry. Inside was a classroom that was ... surprisingly normal. There were desks, wall displays, a whiteboard, and numerous kids racing about playing silly games. A window showed a nice view of a courtyard outside. A middle aged, dark-skinned, balding man wearing a formal suit and tie walked over from a teacher's desk, and introduced himself to me. "I am Professor Lewis" he said proudly "Head of new enrollments here at Ravenscroft. It's my job to get you and your friends ready to move into a first-year class at the beginning of the next academic year."
"I'm Eva" I replied softly.
"Pleasure to meet you" said Professor Lewis "Your desk is over there. If you work hard, you'll be a great and powerful witch in no time! This is where your life really gets started, Eva. Don't mess up this chance. I will expect a lot of work from you, but I know if you try your best always, you'll be able to make it. Trust me."
"Thank you" I said.

A few moments later, a freaky ghost thing came through one wall screaming with a high pitch, rushing through the classroom like a freight train, before going through the wall on the opposite side. Everyone covered their ears at the loud noise, and afterwards, rapidly made for their seats.

"Alright, the banshee has called, that's our signal to start the day!" said the professor. I thought it was interesting that this school used a freaky ghost instead of a normal bell. I also noticed that I was sitting between Ben and Jessica. It seemed like the class had about fourty students, which was much more than the one-on-one tutoring I was accustomed to.

"Blessed be" said the professor.
"Blessed be" replied everyone.
"We have a new student today" beamed the professor "Eva, why don't you introduce yourself."
All eyes turned to me. Immediately I went into shock. I started shaking and didn't know what to say.
"Uh - blessed be?" I managed to say.
"Blessed be" said everyone in response.
"I'm Eva and I'm, uhm" I really didn't know what to say "I just turned eleven yesterday so, yeah, I'm new here. Uh - any questions?"
The class was silent.

After a moment the professor took over again. "Welcome to our class Eva. Why don't we all give her a big clap for her fine speech?"
The class broke out in applause that, I am certain, nobody actually meant.
"It's always hard on your first day. I am sure many of you will remember coming to my class for the first time. For some it is especially difficult."
At this everyone's heads seemed to turn to Liam, who was slumped over his desk with his head still firmly planted in his hands.
"Hey, one two three, all eyes on me!" commanded the professor "We're here to help each other out, ok? We're all in this same boat together. So if somebody is new, I want you to help them out. Have you made any friends yet, Eva?"
Jessica gave me a soft nudge. I nodded quietly.
"Great!" said the professor "Remember this lesson, young witches - help those who need it. That is true strength. Your power lies not in your aptitude for magick, but in your service to others. Now, for class today I have something very special to show you..."

He took out from his pocket a tiny glass ball, a little smaller than a tennis ball. The glass appeared quite frosted, but strangely pretty. The professor tossed it into the air, and everyone gasped as they saw the seemingly frail glass bounce off the floor, and back into the professor's hand.

"Obviously this is a real magick" explained the professor "You will recall we've been learning about the differences between magick and stage magic in this class. But who would like to make a guess as to what this curious thing does?"
Amy's hand shot up. "It is a crystal ball, professor."
"Very good. And what are the properties of a crystal ball?"
"It shows you things through space and time" replied Amy instantly.
"Well, that is a good general answer" said the professor "To be more precise, a crystal ball will show you whatever you need to see. It might be another place, or something from the past, or even the future. Sometimes you may gaze into it and see nothing, for there is nothing you need to see. But a crystal ball never lies ... it will always show you the truth."

Soon enough, the professor passed around his tiny crystal ball, and everyone took turns at looking into it. He explained that only the person gazing most directly into it will see anything, and then only if they were holding the ball with an outstretched palm. In the meantime, the rest of the class would write an essay explaining possible uses for crystal balls. I couldn't really think of any unless the ball felt like showing something helpful, so I spent a lot of time just sitting there staring at my mostly-blank piece of paper.

Eventually, Ben handed me the ball, with a big smile on his face. "This is so cool" he said to himself, obviously very satisfied with what he'd seen.
I looked into the ball. At first I saw nothing, and was disappointed. Then, very faintly, I noticed something like clouds inside the ball moving. I felt a force on my mind, projecting itself into the ball. And then...

There was my dad, wearing some kind of uniform, chained up in a dark underground prison. A menacing laugh rang out from the darkness.
"You'll never see her again! Ha ha ha..."
"Nooooo..." cried out my dad.

I dropped the crystal ball in shock and almost fell backwards on my chair. Everyone in the class was staring at me as the frosted glass ball bounced in front of me.

"You ok?" asked Ben.
"Uh - I think so" I said.
"Seriously?" asked Jessica "I mean, your eyes literally glazed over, and then you started screaming the word no as loudly as you could."
"Yeah, that must have been one heck of a vision" added Ben.
I looked down, ashamed. Remembering everything I'd been told, I realised it probably wasn't a good idea to talk about it.
"Let's keep going, class" said the professor "Eva is new, remember class? Things are still very weird for her, I bet. And Eva ... if you need to talk about whatever you saw, I suggest you keep it private. A crystal ball will always show you the truth, but it is always something you need to see ... not necessarily what the rest of the class needs to hear about."

I nodded softly to myself.
1531111.title: First magick classes

15311111.content:
After this, we had to go through a textbook chapter practicing calculating circumferences for some reason, while the professor marked our answers on potential uses of the crystal ball. My final paper was actually mostly blank, while I could see Amy had written a mini-thesis on the topic.

As I calculated the equations in front of me, I wondered to myself, how far in the future would my father be imprisoned? What if he was imprisoned right now? Who had captured him? What if the crystal ball was showing me an alternate reality somehow? My parents had said I'd be safe so long as I was in the academy, but were they safe? What if they put me here because they knew they were about to be captured?

I glanced over to Liam, who was clearly not doing the task and just looked dejected. In a way I understood what he was feeling. Being here did feel like a mistake - magick wasn't even supposed to be real. There was no way that crystal ball could have known that. And I missed my parents like nothing else. Even though I rarely saw my parents as a child, I missed them now, and feared I'd never see them again. Just like that harrowing, menacing voice in her vision.

Suddenly I became aware that Jessica was busy copying all my maths answers. "Hey" I whispered to her.
"I didn't know you were so brainy" Jessica smiled back "Seriously, I can do maths, but not half as quickly as you can!"

Soon everyone had to cover their ears again as the school banshee raced past, and the class made for the mess hall. You found a banana and munched on it quietly.

"I saw myself surfing this huge wave!" said Ben excitedly.
"I saw myself when I first learnt how to play the guitar" said Andrew "It made me remember why I love it so much."
"Lucky for you guys, I saw myself dropping a dollar down a drain and not knowing how to get it out" said Jack.
"Well I saw my marriage ceremony!" cheered Jessica "It was so good. My dress is going to be amazing!"
"Did you see who you'll marry?" asked Julie softly.
"Oh yes" blushed Jessica "But I'm not telling who!"
"Is it someone we'd know?" asked Jack curiously.
"Yes ... uhm, no more questions!" said Jessica quickly, looking down.

I stayed quiet, not really wanting to share anything about what I saw in the ball. The professor had been right ... many things one needs to see are better kept private.

After this snack and a short chat it was time for our next class. We resumed our seats and the professor lectured again.

"Now I hope you already know this" he began "But magick is dangerous. We always say we should harm none. That is for a good reason. When we try to use magick to harm others, we actually harm ourselves. Many who have tried to use magick to destroy the world, corrupted by its power, have seen instead their own destruction. When we use magick to help others is when we find ourselves blessed."

The professor handed out sheets of paper with "blessed be" apparently translated into tons of languages, and we split off into pairs to practice saying those words in different languages. Apparently this was to help us say incantations written in archaic languages as we got older. As everyone was pairing up, I went directly over to Liam's desk.

"Blessed be" I said gently.
"Go away" he sighed, seemingly on the verge of tears again.
"I'm sorry" I explained "Can I share a secret with you? I don't want to be here either."
Liam looked confused. "Then why do you hang out with all of these freaks?" he asked "This isn't normal! If my parents knew what this place was really like ... they told me I'd be going here for a holiday camp. This has to be a mix-up ... it's not right! Now they're lying to me. Everyone's lying, saying my parents were witches and everything! I don't want to be a witch or do magick. I want to go back home with my friends and my family. I miss my dog Bones and my cat Nightstalker. I miss warm hugs from my mum..."
He broke down in tears at this point. I was almost crying too. In my mind I imagined he couldn't accept his parents lied to him ... but what if he really wasn't a witch and it was genuinely a mistake? Was that possible? And I could definitely understand the part about being homesick. Now that I knew the fate of my father, at least, I certainly was too.
Carefully and softly, I moved my hand to his back and patted it. He let me. "I hear you" I said "After what I saw in the ball this morning ... I totally understand where you're coming from."
"The ball lies" said Liam firmly "It said my parents were happy I was here so they didn't have to hide their magick from me any longer. But I know in my heart that's not true. My parents would never lie to me!"
I nodded quietly. "I'm sorry" I said "I'm so sorry that happened. I wish I could do something to help you."
Liam looked up and smiled a little at me. It was the first time I'd see him smile even a little. "You're the first person..." he muttered "Everyone else thinks I'm crazy here. It's been going on like this for days..."
"You're not crazy" I assured him "And whatever happens, you and me both, let's make a pact that we will see our parents and our friends again. Ideally, alive and well."
I offered him my hand. He looked at it for a moment, and then clasped it.
"Thank you Eva" he said "This means a lot to me."

In the corner of my eye, I noticed the professor had been watching this whole exchange with a smile. I had expected him to tell us off for not doing what he'd asked, but instead he seemed fine with it all.

For the next class, the professor took us outside to the gardens. He showed us a small shrub with holly growing.
"Who knows what we call this?" he asked.
"That's holly!" answered Amy before anyone else could reply.
"Great! Holly is useful in lots of concoctions and rituals. Today we'll be harvesting some of this holly."

The professor handed out sickles and small baskets for collecting holly. Everyone seemed to struggle somewhat with using them, as there was something of an art to it. Even Amy didn't seem to take very naturally to this task. It was slow and painstaking.

"Usually" lectured the professor while we worked "You would only harvest holly at specific times, depending on the ritual or whatever spell you wished to cast. Holly harvested at particular times on particular dates can have a very high street value."

I thought about how my kitchen at home was always well-stocked with herbs and other green leaves ... perhaps it was not simply, as I had always assumed, that my mother had been a great chef, but also that she performed magick with them. I wondered what kinds of spells my mum would cast around the house.

"Now be careful" continued the professor "Holly can be poisonous if you don't prepare it right. We're just harvesting right now ... we'll make something out of it later."

All the harvesting did give me something of an appetite. Luckily it was followed by lunchtime, where the cooks had apparently prepared a delicious smoked chicken salad for me.

"Hey - look" said Jessica, thrusting a newspaper into my hands "This is the Ravenscroft Chronicle - it's a thrice-a-week newspaper for everything Ravenscroft"
"Oh" I said "Thank you."
"Take a look at the third page" she continued "That's the clubs directory, in case you want to join something. I do cheerleading, netball, rowing... Ben's teaching me how to surf, too."
"I'll be sure to take a look" I said.
"Why don't you come with me and take a look at the library?" asked Amy "It's nice there."
"Sure, that sounds like an interesting way to spend my first lunch break."

Soon enough you found yourself in a giant hall with seemingly endless stacks of books around you. There was plenty of tables, bean bags, cushions and even some platters with refreshments. "Just get a book, find a cosy spot, and read!" explained Amy.
"How do you find anything in this library though?" I asked, uncertain.
"That's the best part!" replied Amy "It took me a while to remember this too, but this IS a magical library so ... just call out loudly what sort of book you're looking for, and the library will make the closest book fall straight into your lap! It's so nice! See ... watch ... Book about how to use magic libraries!"

As soon as she said it, a book came flying past her. With a swift snatch she caught it and then handed it to you. "When you're done, just leave it lying around here somewhere, the book will return itself" she said "Isn't it awesome?"
"Yeah, that was pretty cool" I had to admit.
"All the librarians really do is enchant new books that come in and fix books when the enchantment starts to fade" explained Amy "I've already begun my training, of course. Anyway, right now I could use a good book on ... Werewolf Politics!"

We chuckled and laid down together on the same beanbag. Time flew while I learnt how to call out various specific commands for books and got the hang of catching them as they flew past. It was surprisingly easy with practice, even for me - and you should know, I'm a very lazy catcher. Unfortunately, the break was too short, as the wail of the banshee informed us it was time to head back to class. Lying down next to Amy and just reading quietly to ourselves was definitely my level of social - still doing things together but without all the brashness that Jessica seemed to have.

"That was fun" I said on my way back to class.
"Yeah, the library's a nice place to unwind" said Amy "I'm down there quite a lot - it's great for homework and stuff too! Just blurt out the question, and a book with the answer will usually come right your way. Plus the place is big enough that you can hardly hear anyone else saying their questions."
You smiled. Sometimes, just sometimes, being in a magick school sure was fun.
15311111.title: More lessons

choices: The orphans realize I am missing.
154.content:
My name is Tia Grant. I am very short and frail for my age of eleven; I look more like a six year old and often get treated as one. What's worse is the fact I am an orphan; left abandoned on the steps of Child Hope Orphanage as an infant. With sun blond hair, blue eyes, and doll like features one would think a couple would want to adopt me right away. Only no couple ever seemed to want me; it was as if they did not even see me like I had a dark cloud over my head. The other orphans seemed to ignore me as well when they were not pushing me around. The staff never seemed to see the bullying or just did not care.

My troubles became unbearable upon my eleventh birthday the other day. Strange things began to happen that I could not explain. The kids who got rough with me were suddenly thrown off their feet by an invisible force and food would appear in my hands when I grew hungry were strong examples. It did not take long for me to realize that I had magick. The staff and other orphans began to like me even less after that. I had cried myself to sleep, praying to be rescued from my misery when I was visited by a black cat. For some strange reason, I could hear a female voice in my head...

*My name is Maddalena; you can call me Maddy.* Softly, the cat introduced. *I heard your cry for help; please follow me.*

It was almost like a sequence in a dream. My curiosity was too great not to follow the strange talking cat and she lead me out of the orphanage through a service entrance that was left open and down the dim lit sidewalk. Though I was only wearing a nightgown and undergarments, no one seemed to notice me. I continued following Maddy until we reached a tall iron gate in a high stone wall. I did not know what purpose the complex of low building beyond served but I had always sensed something powerful inside when the orphanage bus had passed it to and from field trips the orphanage offered.

"Curious and more curious." Whispering, I muttered.

Maddy easily slipped between the bars and meowed loudly until a massive man came forward. He was towering with a bushy mustache and beard, wearing black robes with dark pants and shirt beneath. I sensed powerful magick within him, making me shiver only his gentle blue eyes oddly placed me at ease.

"Maddalena, who have you lead to our gates?" Softly, he demanded. "This poor child looks as if she had been severely neglected."

"I- I'm Tia Grant." Finding my voice, I stammered. "I am an orphan with magick, living at Child Hope Orphanage a few blocks from here." I bowed deeply, adding. "Please, mighty wizard... teach me how to control my magick."

The towering man raised a single eyebrow as I heard or thought I heard Maddy giggle. A bemused look came across the man's face. "Quiet." Grinning, he scolded.

He then produced a long thin wooden rod from the folds of his ropes and pointed it at me. "Interesting." Softly, he said. "My name is Wardwell; groundskeeper of Ravenscroft school. Please follow me."

With that, he opened the gate and offered his hand. Uncertain, I accepted his hand and he gently led me inside as the gate closed behind us on its own...
154.title: Lonely Orphan

1541.content:
Wardwell led me through the grounds. "How did you come to know of us here?" he asked.

"Sometimes," I replied, "the orphanage bus passed by this place, and I felt there was something special about it. Will you accept me as one of your apprentices?"

He chuckled, a deep, rich sound. "As I said, I am the groundskeeper here at Ravenscroft Academy. I am taking you to the magistra."

We walked until we reached a door, and he knocked.

After a few minutes, the door opened, and an older woman stood before us. "What is it, Wardwell?"

"Maddalena has brought us a guest, Magistra." Gesturing to me, he said, "This is Tia Grant. I know she doesn't look it, but she is of age, and she has magick."

She curtsied to me. "Good evening, Tia, and blessed be. You've come rather early, as the school year doesn't begin for another week."

"Then I can learn about magick here?"

"Of course, my dear. However, our dormitory halls are not yet ready to accommodate students. We will need to make some sort of arrangement for you."

"May I stay with Mr. Wardwell?"

She blinked. "I'm not sure if he has the room for you, Tia."

"I don't take up much room, Magistra. At the orphanage, I've been put into several small spaces."

Wardwell sighed. "I could find a room for her, I'm sure."

"Very well, then, Wardwell, I leave her in your care. Bright blessings." With that, the magistra closed the door.
1541.title: Meeting the magsitra.

choices: We are met by four large dogs.
I am given a place to sleep.
15411.content:
Wardwell led me to the back of the campus near a walking path close to the wall of the property where we soon found a sizeable garden with a cottage on the other side. "Did you grow all of these yourself?" Wide eyed, I asked. "It's a beautiful garden"

Wardwell smiled. "Thank you." Kindly, he replied. "I tend to this garden and various other smaller gardens along the perimeter wall." He motioned to the garden ahead of us. "We grow our own vegetables for food along with herbs and spices for potions of various purposes."

I paused to sniff one of the flowers and it opened for me for me to do so. "Ghost Orchids." Whispering, I said. "They smell so lovely."

Wardwell saw the flower open up for me and raised a single eyebrow. "They are very rare." Softly, he said. "I am surprised you know what they are. Have plants always reacted to your presence and touch?"

"I love gardening." Still smiling, I said. "Plants seem to understand me, I guess."

Wardwell was thoughtful for a moment. "Every witch specializes in one or more types of magick." Smiling slightly, he said. "Your specialty may be Agro-bonding; the rare ability to communicate with and command plant life."

"Is that a good thing?" Wincing, I asked.

Wardwell let out a deep chuckle. "Well, it helps me know where to start in defining your magickal strengths." Bemused, he replied. "Also, I would hope it is a good thing as that is one of my specialties as well."

I smiled at that as Wardwell then led me to his cottage. I was very surprised to find that it was made of a large circle of trees with its high branches interweaving to form the roof. Tightly wound vines surrounding the trees made up the outer walls. The windows were made up of hardened clear tree sap and the door was a curtain of loose hanging branches of a weeping willow that made up part of the cottage.

Seeing it all made me feel... at home. "You grew your own house." In awe, I whispered. "You are a mighty wizard..."

Wardwell laughed, confusing me. "I wish I could take credit for such a feat but no." Amused, he said. "The trees and vines did this on their own for me in a gesture of friendship and trust." He then turned serious. "Magick exists in all things as such all things can use magick in their own mysterious ways."

"Even normal people?" Wincing, I asked.

"Normal people, whom we call cowan, have magick but it is too weak for them to use." Smiling, Wardwell replied. "It finds an outlet through their talents and skills which is why they say they can work 'magick' in what they do best."

I nodded at that then yawned. "Sorry." Wincing, I said. "I don't get much sleep."

Wardwell smiled kindly. "Let us find room for you to sleep then."

With that, he led me into the cottage.
15411.title: Wardwell's cottage

154111.content:
As soon as Wardwell opened the door, we were met by four large dogs. "Are-are they friendly?" I asked .

"They help me to guard the grounds," he replied. "They don't know who you are, but they know me. For now, they're curious. By the time you move into one of the residence halls, they'll regard you as a friend."

The main room of the cottage was a combination living room/dining room/kitchen. Next to the table was a bookcase. Most of the books were about philosophy. On the table was a book by Immanuel Kant. Its condition suggested that this was far from the first time he'd read it. Hanging on the wall were pictures. Except for one of him holding a baby in one hand, they were all of various dogs he had owned.

Wardwell took out his wand and cast a spell, creating another bedroom. "Have a look inside," he said. " Let me know if it's big enough."

"I'm sure I'll be fine," I said.

"I'm not looking to cram you into something just to see if you fit," he replied. "Let me know if I need to make it bigger."

I went into the new room, and Wardwell didn't have to worry. It looked like he had made the room for himself when he was my age. "It's fine," I assured him.

"Alright, then," he said, "good night. In the morning, we'll take you to Dr. Willard, just to make sure you're alright. Good night, buttercup."

"Good night, Wardwell."

That night, I had what started out as a nightmare I often had. My family had died in a boating accident, and I guess I was close by when it happened, because I often had nightmares where I was in the water, struggling to stay afloat, with no land in sight.

This time, however, my dream had me picked up by an immense hand. As I sat in the palm of this huge hand, I heard a laugh. I didn't need to hear the laugh, however, to know that I had been rescued by Wardwell.

He carried me to dry land and set me down, but it almost didn't matter. I could have stayed in Wardwell's hand forever.
154111.title: We are met by four large dogs.

choices: I get a tour of Ravenscroft Academy.
1541111.content:
I awoke the next morning to the smell of pancakes and eggs. The aroma brought a smile to my face and I stepped out of bed. I followed the inviting smell to the dining room where I found Wardwell busy in the kitchen with his back turned to me. "Good morning, Miss Grant." Kindly, he said without turning to me. "Please wash up and get dressed before joining me at the table."

"I'm afraid I don't have anything else to wear." Pouting, I said.

"Look on the table to your right, buttercup." Calmly, Wardwell countered. "I got them from the academy student store last night after you fell asleep."

I turned to my right and was surprised to find two large piles of assorted clothing in my size. This included undergarments, socks and shoes. "You did this all for me?" Tearing up, I asked.

Wardwell chuckled. "Well, I couldn't just let you run around in nothing more than a nightgown and undergarments." Bemused, he said. "It was simply the right thing to do." He turned back around with a smile and a large pile of pancakes on a plate. "Please wash up and get dressed."

With a grateful smile, I nodded and took the clothing I needed before rushing back into my bedroom to change. Once done, I came out wearing a moderate length blue skirt and ivory blouse with a pair of flats. Wardwell smiled kindly then helped me into a chair. The four dogs were already happily enjoying their own morning meal as we began to eat. As we did, I could not help wonder about the dream I had. "Um... Wardwell, I had a dream last night about how my parent's died." Softly, I said. "I dreamed that you saved me..."

Wardwell sighed before wiping his mouth with a napkin. "That was not a dream, my dear." Firmly but kindly, he replied. "That was a memory." He paused, as if to search for the right words. "Your mother and father were adventurers, always looking for the next big thrill. They had decided to take you with them for your first adventure out on a boat."

"What happened?" Curious, I asked.

"They ran into an unexpected storm." Softly, Wardwell explained. "I was in the area when I caught their distress call on my radio. I sailed out to see what I could do but the storm had already taken the boat and your parents." He gulped down a hard lump before adding. "I was crying when I took you into my hand because I came too late to save your parents."

"So that wasn't a laugh I heard in my dream." Gulping, I thought. "It was Wardwell crying."

I rose from my chair and offered my hand to Wardwell. "Thank you for saving me." Smiling slightly, I said. "Also, thank you for trying to save my family."

Wardwell shed a few tears as he took me into his arms and racked me a little. "Had I known then you had magick, I would have adopted you on the spot." Tearfully, he said.

"You could adopt me now." Hopefully, I said. I sniffed. "No one who came to the orphanage even bothered to look at me."

I began to cry as Wardwell continued to rock me like a small child, crying himself. The four dogs began to whimper then howled in tune with our cries. Out in the garden, every flower opened in a beautiful display of approval; a powerful bond had been made.
1541111.title: Next morning

choices: Maddy and a woman come to visit.
15411111.content:
After breakfast, Wardwell and I talked in length about what my life was like while growing up in the orphanage. There was not much good to say, unfortunately as I was for the most part treated poorly by the staff and other orphans. Wardwell listened intently then knotted his jaws in decision. "I can not, in good conscious allow you to go back there." Firmly, he said. "I left you at the orphanage in hopes you would find a good home, not to be treated in such a way you described." He then smiled at me kindly. "I will adopt you, if you will have me."

I replied by jumping into his arms, crying. Wardwell again rocked me gently then, after I had calmed down, he took me to the magistra's office where he again knocked. Minutes later, the magistra answered. "Blessed be, Wardwell." Patiently, she said. "What brings you back to me with Tia so soon?"

"I wish to adopt her." Serious, Wardwell replied. "It was I who rescued her from the ocean waters ten years ago and left her at the orphanage, not knowing she had magick. It is only right and only fair." He paused, tearing up. "I cannot stand seeing her get sent back there; the horrors she spoke of when telling me of her life there..."

"I see." Smiling, the magistra replied. She turned to me. "You need not worry, dear child. I will take care of this matter immediately."

With that, she produced a long thin wooden rod of her own and pointed it at me and then at Wardwell. I had expected to feel different but all I felt was a sense of relief. The magistra then smiled as us both. "Congratulations, Wardwell and to you, Tia Wardwell."

I teared up. "Tia... Wardwell?"

"You are now officially Wardwell's adopted daughter." Smiling, magistra said. "You need not ever go back to that orphanage as all the paperwork is already done. As far as anyone is concerned, you are a family."

Tears were falling at this point. "I love magick..."

The magistra giggled slightly. "I am pleased to hear that." Patiently, she said. "Now off with you both; we all have much work to do. Blessed be."

Wardwell and I returned to the cottage for a small celebration. "How would you like to help me work in the gardens, Tia?" Smiling, Wardwell asked. "I can show you flowers you had never seen before, at least not in person."

I beamed at that. "I would love to... dad."

Later on...
15411111.title: Wardwell adopts me.

154111112.content:
My new father and I were working in one of the gardens when I heard a familiar voice in my head. *Has you at work already, does he?*

I turned. "Maddalena!"

With Maddalena was a young woman I hadn't met yet. "Blessed be, Wardwell." Turning to me, she said, "You must be Tia. Maddy has spoken of little else but you since she came home."

"Vanessa, this is Tia," Dad said. "Tia, this is Mrs. Procter, the school's guidance counselor."

Shaking my hand, Mrs. Procter said, "I understand congratulations are in order."

Dad nodded. "Magistra Gardner made it official this morning."

"I'm happy for you both," Mrs. Procter said. She began wiping at her eyes. "I just wish my Sam could be here."

"Sam?"

She nodded. "My son."

"You seem young to have a son."

"I began younger than was perhaps advisable. Certainly, the woman who stole him from me thought so."

*I think Sam is closer than you know,* Maddy said. *The Goddess is at work, be assured. Why don't you use that contraption you insisted on bringing?*

"Oh, yes." She took out a camera. "Your first family photo."

We didn't need more encouraging. Dad picked me up with one hand and smiled.

Mrs. Procter took the picture. "A home feels empty without some pictures. I'll have this over to you soon."
154111112.title: Maddy and a woman come to visit.

1541111121.content:
"Are you the school guardian angel?" My eyes dancing, I asked Maddalena.

Maddy giggled. *Something like that.* In a bemused tone, she replied.

Mrs Procter smiled. "Maddalena is my partner in magick." Kindly, she said. "She is a familiar."

I smiled. "Ah, an animal guide."

Mrs Procter giggled. "Close enough." She then turned to dad. "Have you taken Tia to see Dr. Willard yet?"

"He is expecting us within the hour." Politely, dad said. "I will take her as soon as we clean up."

"Very good then." Kindly, Procter said. "Blessed be."

Minutes later, Wardwell took me into the infirmary where we meet a young man in an adult version of the school uniform with a long white lab coat over it. He smiled kindly at Wardwell and I as we entered his office. "Blessed be, Wardwell." Smiling, he said. "This must be the young lass Tia I have heard so much about."

"You heard about me?" Curious, I asked.

Dr. Willard chuckled. "Young lass, you have been the topic of every teacher's conversation since your father adopted you this morning." Bemused, he said. "Happy news always travels quickly among witches." He smiled seeing me blush. "Now then, let us make certain you are in good heath, my dear."

I tried to prepare myself to be probed and prodded but Dr Willard instead produced a wand and began pointing it at me from various angles. After a few minutes, he wrote a number of notes on a form then turned to dad. "Your new daughter is in perfect health." Kindly, he said. "Her small size is nothing to be concerned about; she has many years for growth spurts to kick in." He chuckled, adding, "I believe you know this from experience, Wardwell."

Dad blushed slightly at that before turning to me. "I was your size, if not smaller when I was your age, Tia." Smiling, he said. "Big oaks grow from little acorns."

That made me grin from ear to ear. Knowing that dad was just as tiny as I at my age was a great comfort to me; it filled me with hope. Dr Willard wiped away a single tear at the touching scene as dad and I shared another hug. "School starts in less than a week." Politely, he said. "I suggest you begin gathering everything Tia will need to attend her classes."

Dad nodded then turned to me. "It's time we go shopping, then."
1541111121.title: Big oaks grow from little acorns

15411111212.content:
After Dad bought me my school supplies, some of which were unlike anything I had needed at any other school, he started taking me around the academy to meet my teachers. As Dr. Willard had said, they had all heard about me and were glad to see me.

The two who stood out the most, I think, we're Professor Nurse and Professor Wilds. Professor Nurse was unique because, as a result of a prank gone awry, she was in the body of an 11-year-old girl. Professor Wilds stood out because she was only a couple of inches taller than I was.

"You're the first student I've had that I could look down on," she said to me.

"That might not last too long," I replied. "Dr. Willard says I might grow like Dad did."

"That won't happen for another couple of years," Dad said. "But, I should warn you, they hurt."

"What hurt?"

"The growth spurts. They feel like you're being pulled in every direction at once."

As we headed back to the cottage for lunch, I asked, "Why doesn't anyone call you anything except Wardwell?"

"Why shouldn't they call me Wardwell? It's my name."

"Don't you have a first name?"

He saved his hand dismissively. "I haven't used it in years. At my size, you don't need a whole name to stand out. This French fellow I met years ago taught me that."
15411111212.title: skip to orientation.

154111112122.content:
The days to the official start of school went fast as dad taught me the wonders of potion making through the various gardens they grow to make them. "To a cowan, these mixtures do nothing for them except to perhaps upset their stomach." Serious, dad had explained. "Magick is needed to properly mix the ingredients into a usable potion."

"Cowan can still make some real good medicines." Politely, I countered. "They are made from herbs and spices as well."

Dad smiled. "That is true and that is where their extremely limited magick comes into play but potions are far more effective due to the stronger magick used to make them." He looked at the clock on the wall. "It is time for me to greet the students for their orientation. Would you like to join me; you already had yours."

I eagerly nodded and dad led me to the front courtyard where the buses were already beginning to gather with the next class of fresh students. They were people from all walks of life who, as dad explained, just discovered they had magick abilities. Two students caught my eye though I'm not sure why. The first was a tall young girl with mid back blond hair and blue eyes looking about in an almost panicked state. She kept rubbing her fingers on a Christian cross hanging from a necklace. The second was a short young boy with brown hair and brown eyes looking rather confident, I dare say cocky even. He was carrying an odd case with him and I wondered what he could possibly be bringing with him.

As they approached, dad motioned me to stand out of sight. "It is customary for the seventh year students to play magickal pranks on the first year students to keep them on their toes." Serious, he whispered. "It's not personal but you would be seen as an 'easy' target." He grinned. "I'd rather wait and see the look on their faces when they learn that is not the case."

I smiled at that as dad had taught me a number of defensive spells to block and even throw spells back at the aggressor if I felt cornered. I stepped back into the shadow of a weeping willow and allowed its hanging branches to hide me from sight. I could see out into the crowd but no one could see me.

"New students, form two lines, boys and girls!" Firmly, dad commanded. "I am Wardwell, grounds keeper, I will lead you all to your orientations! Do not wander or fall behind, you will not like the results!"

As the boys marched forward, I sensed magick being used. I turned and nearly gave myself away with a gasp as the confident boy's uniform changed into a girl's uniform. I heard the boy behind him whisper, "Dude, look down."

The boy screamed in fright then looked about angrily as nearly everyone burst into a nervous laughter at his comical predicament. "That poor boy." Wincing, I thought. "Someone got him even before orientations."

Dad looked about then slowly shook his head before pulling out his wand from the folds of his robe; pointing it to someone out of my line of sight. "Tyler Cohan, you know the rules!" he barked. "No pranks are tolerated before orientations!"

The boy, Tyler walked into sight with a smile on his face. He was a skinny but fit young man, most likely in his seventh year with short red hair and green eyes. "My humblest apologies, sir Wardwell." said Tyler with a low bow. "My wand slipped."

"You will not like what happens when I allow my wand to slip, young man." Unimpressed, dad countered.

Tyler rose his hands, chuckling. "The spell wears off in a day, he'll live." he said, smiling. "If 'she' asks nicely, I might reverse it now."

Dad turned a slight shade of red, I could tell his patience was growing thin with this boy. "I'm warning you, Cohan." he said.

"Allow me, sir." Grinning, the confident boy said.

Dad shrugged. "Very well."

I watched, curious, as the boy stepped out of line and looked Tyler in the eye. "That's not a bad trick." Grinning, he said. I noticed him discretely pulling a small cylinder out of his now feminine blazer. "Try this, from me, its a gas!"

With that, he sprayed a thick smoke from the canister into Tyler's face, covering his mouth with his free hand. Tyler stumbled back, coughing as he breathed the gas in. "You little twerp!" he raged. He screamed as his voice was considerably higher, much like that of a girl. "What did you do to me!?"

I covered my mouth to suppress a giggle as the boy laughed along with dad and the other first year students. "If you want the antidote for that new feminine voice of yours," Folding his arms, the confident boy said, "change my clothes back to normal."

Tyler was less than impressed. "I don't need anything from you or your pathetic chemisty set. Hope you like the girls' dorms, jerk, casue thats where you'll be spending the year" Tyler sneered, as the boy's body then transformed into the female state to match the uniform.

The boy looked at the other students in a mixture of horror and embrassment, but surprisingly, there was very little laughter. I began to wonder what made seventh year students so mean, so vicious to the first years. The other boys seemed more nervous while the girls had wry smiles on their faces.

The only person that was completely passive was dad. He just ignored my sudden gender switch, at least at first. "Miss Child. Can you go to the other line, thanks?"

The boy, now girl, Miss Child, looked at dad in annoyance. "Can you do something about this" pointing at her now feminine body.

"No. It is not wise to counter a spell used in anger or to counter it so soon. You'll be staying in the girls' dorm until Mr Cohan decides to remove his spell" Surprisingly calm, dad said. I looked on, a sense of horror running down my spine as I thought what would have happened to me without dad's teachings before school. Only a sense of relief fell through me as dad added, "However, you get to decide what is done to Mr Cohan."

"I'll think about it" Miss Child replied.

A teenage girl, I suspected was a seventh year, guided Miss Child to the girls' line. She gave her a small smile, before leaving. As she walked passed where I was hiding, I heard her whisper to another seventh year girl, "That Tyler jerk will never live that down; a first year got the best of him on his, or rather, her first day."

The other girl giggled as they walked out of my view. I turned to the girl who had caught my eye and noticed that she seemed even more terrified than before. Once the students had passed through the gates, dad came to fetch me. "I know you saw what had happened." Calmly, he said. "Believe me when I say Miss Child's actions have earned her some points."

"Why is that?" Confused, I asked.

Dad chuckled. "The seventh year students are impressed by those few newbies who can actually fight back near or on their level." Bemused, he said. "I would not be surprised if a few ask her out to the up coming ball."

I giggled at that. "Awkward..."

Dad smiled. "Indeed."
154111112122.title: Reader's choice

1541111121222.content:
After orientation, we were sent to our various dormitories. I was sent to Cauldron Hall. I looked around, but I couldn't see Miss Child. I guess she was sent to the other girls' dorm.

As I looked around at my new home for the duration of the school year, I felt a tickle on my ears. Reaching up to them, I gasped in surprise. They had suddenly grown large and pointed.

I heard someone giggling. "Check it out, girls, we've got an elf in the house!"

I blushed. For all the counter-spells Dad had taught me, I had been caught unawares at the first attempt at a prank. "You got me fair and square," I said.

"That's Your reaction?" asked the guilty party.

I shrugged. "I've endured worse pranks at the orphanage. Try sticking me in a dresser drawer. That one never seemed to get boring to them."

She was taken aback. "You're an orphan?"

"I was adopted right before school started." I held out my hand. " Tia Wardwell."

She turned white as a sheet. "Th-the groundskeeper?"

I nodded. "He says he was smaller than I am when he was my age. Big oaks grow from little acorns, is how he puts it."

"I'm glad I won't be here to see you full-grown, if that's the case." She took my hand. " Eva Addams." With her other hand, she tapped me with her wand. "There you are, back to normal."
1541111121222.title: I get pranked.

15411111212222.content:
"Let me give you a little insider information." Smiling, Eva said. "The pranks are not personal, though some do get carried away. They are allowed to teach the first years how to detect magic and set up their defenses before a spell or worse a fist hits them."

"A fist?" Taken back, I asked.

Eva nodded. "Energy is energy, regardless of its source." Calmly, she explained. "A person must summon physical energy in order to throw a fist that will do any kind of damage. If you can sense it building, you can dodge the blow."

"That makes sense." Thoughtful, I said. "Um... just curious but why did you turn pale hearing that my father was the groundskeeper Wardwell?"

Eva smiled kindly. "Wardwell is a highly respected person on campus; he had saved each and every one of us seventh year students on more than one occasion." She sighed happily. "He just seems to know the right thing to say to a student who is having a rough time and exactly what to do when a student is in trouble." She giggled. "Or thinks he or she is in trouble."

"So he watches over everyone." Smiling, I said. "Like a family."

Eva nodded. "I could not think of anyone more deserving of having a family than him." Tearing up, she said. "You are very lucky to have him as a father."

I smiled at that.
15411111212222.title: Respect.

154111112122221.content:
My first class was spells and incantations with Professor Isaac Burroughs. I made certain to get there early, using what Wardwell had taught me to keep a look out for mischief. Professor Burroughs, who preferred to be called Issac, knelled down to my level with a warm smile.

"Blessed be, Miss Wardwell." Kindly, he said. "It is an honor to meet you."

"The honor is mine." Bowing slightly, I replied.

Issac chuckled. "Like you, Wardwell was an orphan." Softly, he said. "He was raised here in these very halls; this is home to him."

"I- I didn't know that." Worried, I said.

Issac smiled. "He is family to us and now so are you." Kindly, he said. He then pointed at you with a smirk. "Just don't think we'll go any easier on you just because you are family."

I could not help giggle at that. "I wouldn't have it any other way."

Issac nodded, satisfied. "Since you are the first one here, might I suggest to take a seat near the front so you have a clear view of the chalkboard."

I nodded and took my seat as other students began shuffling in and claimed seats of their own. The younger students gave me curious looks while some of the seventh years gave me a kind smile before sitting down. Less than a minute before class began, two girls ran in with a young boy not too far behind. I recognized the first girl as Nico Child from the standoff at orientation. The other must have been her roommate. The bell rang and the door slammed in the boy's face.

I winced before giving Issac a pleading look. He merely winked at me before turning to the door. "What is the most misused magick word, known to cowan? asked Isaac.

There was a pause before the boy guessed, "Abracadabra?"

The door opened and Isaac allowed him inside. "Each time you are late for class, the question gets harder." he explained to the entire class. "If you answer incorrectly, you get a pass back to your dorm and you will have to ask to read the notes of one of your classmates."

"Yes, sir." replied the boy, softly. "It won't..."

"Do not say 'it won't happen again'." warned Isaac. "You are only asking for a jinx, if you do that."

He then smiled. "Now that we have all settled, let us begin." he said, pulling out a wand. "Who would like to volunteer?"

"You should have Miss Child volunteer. She is already transformed" a voice says somewhere behind me. Hearing a few snickers, I was tempted to turn and give the boy a dirty look but I noticed that Issac was not impressed by the outburst. I wisely decided to remain still and silent.

"Thanks for volunteering, Mister Parsens" Isaac says seriously. "I was going to show several amongst the class but I guess Nate wants it all for himself." He then turned to Nico Child who was seated next to me; he was blushing terribly. "You're already seen gender.." Issac said, "..but guess you can all see it again."

"No. Don't.. I don't want.... what have you done to me!?!" the newly formed girl shrieked.

I turned and winced seeing the new girl. In a way, I felt sorry for him, or rather her but I had a feeling Isaac would keep her like that for very long.

"Another spell we use is age progression/ regression"

"Isn't it enough to.. Urrgh" Nate said, as she began to develop a little more.

Now Nate was clearly a teenager with lovely curves and a modest bust. It made me wonder if i would look as good when I reached that age. Nate, however as clearly freaked out by it. Some of the other girls suggested she be regressed while others asked to see more progression. I decided to turn back to face the front seeing the awkward look on the boy's faces.

"Okay," the embarrassed girl begged, 'you've had your fun. Please turn me back."

"And so you see, class," Smiling, Issac said, "the first and most important thing to remember in spellcasting is to be very careful what you say." With that, he returned Nate to his original form, and sent him back to his seat.

"If there are no further out bursts, let us begin with simple spell casting..."
154111112122221.title: First class.

1541111121222212.content:
After class, I was walking along when I got a strong feeling that something was up. Dad had warned me about this, that it meant I was about to be on the receiving end of a prank. Luckily, he taught me a couple of counter-spells. I quickly cast one, so it turned out that the seventh-year who cast the spell found himself wearing a diaper instead.

As the day progressed, I noticed there was something of interest spreading among the teachers. They were very excited when they heard it, and I remembered Dad telling me how fast news spread among witches.

After school, I went to visit Dad. "I noticed the teachers talking about something. What was it?"

Dad lit up. "Very good news, indeed, Tia. Sam has been found."

"Sam?"

"Counselor Procter's son. Turns out he was next door for I don't know how long. The Magistra has taken care of the person responsible." He changed the subject. "Where would you like to go in town?"

"In town?"

"Students who keep good behavior get to go into town every weekend. I thought you might have some ideas?"

I shrugged. "I thought that I'd spend the weekend with you."

"That wouldn't be such a good idea. On weekends, I tend to the students on bad behavior. Most of them are alright, they just need a little help straightening themselves out. Every now and then, though, you get one who's trouble."

"I'll have to think about that." I checked the time. "Guess I'd better get back to the hall."

"Blessed be, Tia. See you soon."
1541111121222212.title: After class.

choices: the infirmary, fear made me ill.
15411111212222122.content:
I was walking to my next class when I spotted a pouting young girl in the school uniform being escorted towards dad's detention hall by an older girl. I could not help wonder what she had done to be sent there but, as the older girl was no doubt a seventh year, I was wise enough not to ask. The young girl paused looking at me then turned to a window before sticking her tongue out at someone in another hall. Curios, I turned to find a small boy looking at her with an almost sad expression on his face. "Was he the one who reported her?" Wincing, I thought.

The young woman escorting the girl smiled before urging her on but paused upon seeing me. "Blessed be, Miss Wardwell." Kindly, she said. "You had better move on quickly, the professors tend to pick on those who are tardy for class."

"Thank you." Bowing, I replied. "Um... what did she do?"

The young woman patiently smiled. "We are not allowed to discuss such things as it can and will promote unnecessary rumors." Lightly scolding, she said. "Run along now."

Not wanting to annoy the seventh year student, I hurried along but I caught the girl blurting out, "Thanks for not telling her I was once a full grown woman."

The seventh year giggled. "I didn't have to, you just did."

I kept walking, not daring to turn around but hearing what the girl said sent an icy chill down my spine. "She had to be the one who had taken Mrs Procter's son." Unnerved, I whispered. "This school does not fool around." I gulped, wondering what punishments were handed down to the students who misbehaved or were tardy to class. Unknown to me, the school was no where nearly as harsh as I had feared only, feeling frightened, I hurried off to...
15411111212222122.title: Fearful misunderstanding.

154111112122221222.content:
I had thought I was going to my next class, but I must have been more distracted than I thought, and I almost stepped on Maddalena's tail. *Excuse you,* she said.

"Sorry."

She looked up at me for a long moment. *Follow me.*

I looked where she was going. "But my next class is this way."

*That may be the way to your next class, but you need to come this way.*

I followed Maddalena, eventually realizing that she was leading me to Counselor Procter's office. Mrs. Procter looked up from her desk as we walked in. I could tell she had been crying, and wondered why. "Blessed be, Tia. How are you?"

*I met her in the halls,* Maddalena said. *She needs a bit of help.*

"Thank you, Maddy. Have a seat, Tia. Would you like a cup of tea?"

"Yes, please. Thank you."

She tapped a kettle with her wand, and it immediately whistled. She then put three tea bags into a teapot and poured the boiling water in. "How do you take it?"

"Uh, milk, two sugars."

She nodded, and poured a little milk into two teacups. She tapped the teapot with her wand, and poured fresh-brewed tea into the cups. She then added two sugar cubes to one cup, stirred it, and put it in front of me. Putting the other cup in front of her, she asked, "What's on your mind?"

"I saw a new student, and overheard her saying that she used to be a grown woman. It made me scared of what kind of punishments are handed out here."

"You have nothing to worry about, Tia. That was no punishment." She took a sip of tea. "Years ago, my husband and I hired a woman as a babysitter. She seemed friendly, and we trusted her with the truth that we were witches. Shortly after that, she kidnapped our Sam."

"Why did she do that?"

"She had two reasons: she felt that two people of college age shouldn't be burdened with a child, and she had heard that a cowan who was mother to a witch might be invited to become a witch herself."

"Was that why she became a little girl?"

She nodded. "She wanted to be a witch, and so she will be. Since she is younger than when she kidnapped Sam, it's as if she had never done it. We've adopted her."

"So everything's okay."

"All is well, Tia."

When I finished my tea, Mrs. Procter gave me a note. "Just press this against the door to your class. The door will open for you. Bright blessings."
154111112122221222.title: talk to Mrs Procter.

1541111121222212222.content:
The rest of the day was quite eventful. Thanks to dad's teachings before school, I was able to avoid most pranks. Unknown to me, it made me quite a celebrity among the seventh years as they were privately impressed with my ability to detect magickal pranks and deflect them. Upon approaching my next class, talismans, charms, and amulets, I placed my pass onto the door and it opened only i noticed a slight glow around the opening. "I have a pass back to class from guidance counselor Procter." Politely, I said. "Please cancel your prank before I enter."

I heard a feminine giggle before the glowing stopped and I entered the room only to freeze half way through. "I sense a talisman." Pouting, I said. "Did you not hear that I had a pass?"

"Very good, Miss Wardwell." Smiling, the professor said. "You are actually the first to detect the trap before entering, I am impressed."

Professor Janet Good was very tall and slender with long flowing sand blond hair and ocean blue eyes; her long black dress accented her figure well. She motioned me to enter and I felt a change immediately after. I screamed upon realizing I had become a boy in the boy's uniform. I turned to Professor Good who merely smiled. "Do not fear, Mr. Wardwell." gently, she said. "You will return to your proper gender and attire upon leaving this classroom." She then pointed to a strange object above the door that looked like the male and female signs intertwined in a Celtic cross. "When you are able to forge a talisman that will counteract my gender swap charm, you will have passed a third of my class."

"That is an interesting way to motivate students to learn." Pouting, I said. "It may also inspire some to strike back."

Janet smiled kindly. "None of those transformed will face male or female issues; I am not that mean." Softly, she explained. "As for fighting back, I have a shield talisman over my desk protecting myself and all the students in this room from pranks. The offender will only be throwing a prank on him or herself."

I smiled at that to which Janet nodded and offered a seat near the front of the class next to a familiar looking girl. She smiled upon catching my eye. "Sam Procter." Introducing herself, she said. "You must be Tia Wardwell; mom told me about you."

"Ty Wardwell for now." Chuckling, I replied. "Your mom spoke of you too." I paused. "Did I miss too much?"

Sam smiled. "I'll lend you my notes after class."

With that, class continued...

I headed back home after class with a smile on my face. I had declined Professor Good's extra credit challenge but optioned for a report on what I felt boys went through in a day. I thought it would be an interesting study. It was after dinner when I sensed something was wrong. I rose from the table and looked out the window to see a strange man wearing bluejeans shirt and jacket silently jumping down from the high wall into one of the gardens. "Dad, we have a prowler!" Whispering, I alerted.

Dad looked out the window and growled slightly as we both saw him grabbing a female student from behind, forcing a hand over her mouth. I recognized her as Nico Child. There was another girl with her, I recognized as Rachel demanding he release her friend. "Stay here." Firmly, dad commanded. "I shall deal with this immediately." He turned to his dogs. "Protect her."

The dogs immediately surrounded me, their eyes steel focused outward for any trouble. I wanted to go with dad to confront this intruder but the dogs held me back and all I could do was helplessly watch through the window.

"Please don't get the wrong idea." I heard the man quickly say. "I'm a private detective, investigating this school. I just want to ask you two a few questions."

"You are trespassing on school grounds and assaulting a student!" almost screaming, Rachel said. "Let my roommate go, and get out of here!"

"I'll go but, sorry, she comes with me." pulling Nico along, the man said. "I'll release her once I get my answers."

Hearing that made my blood boil. "How dare he..." Furious, I whispered. "That man has no respect for people or plants!"

I then smiled seeing dad easily lift the man off the ground with one arm by the collar of his shirt; surprising him enough to let Nico go. "Not only have you trespassed and assaulted a student, you trampled all over my prize Ghost Orchids!" giving the man a slight shake, dad thundered. "Do you have any idea how rare those flowers are!?!"

Dad then turned to Nico and Rachel, his face softening. "Are you two injured?" ignoring the man for the moment, he asked.

"He- He twisted my wrist." showing him her now bruised wrist, Nico said.

Dad drew in an angry breath. "Both of you report to the infirmary," his breath heavy, he said. "You do not need to see what is about to come next."

Both Rachel and Nico hurried down the path, not daring to look back as dad then literally carried the struggling man to the house and ushered him inside. "Sit down!" Angrily, he ordered.

The man was pale with fear and obeyed immediately, eying the large dogs as they growled a warning, still guarding me. "I did not mean any real harm." Nervous, the man protested. "Just let me go and we can forget all about this."

"You will be leaving with the police." Firmly, dad countered. "I would not try to run; my dogs can reach the fence in three and a half seconds."

As the man caught my eye, I turned pale. "I know him; he's a con artist named Michael Cort." Fearful, I said. "He claimed to be looking for someone to adopt only he was really looking for dirt to blackmail the orphanage into paying him a ton of cash." I shivered at the memory. "He locked me in a steam trunk to keep me from telling on him; it took them two days to find me."

The man, Michael, turned red with annoyance. "You bratty tattle tale!" Hissing, he spat. He rose from his seat in an aggressive gesture only to freeze as the dogs barked and snapped in a clear display of protection. He got the message and quickly sat back down.

Dad gave the man a warning glare, causing him to again turn pale. "A blackmailer scam artist." Annoyed, he said. "Not to worry, my dear daughter, we have dealt with his kind before." He then picked up a telephone. "Security, we have an intruder..."

Minutes later, the man was escorted away by a number of men in police uniforms as the dogs continued to guard me. "That man will answer for his crimes including his crime against you last year; you need not give him any more thought."

"Those poor orchids..." Tearing up, I muttered. "They're hurt; they need help."

Dad turned to me, surprised. "You feel their pain, don't you."

I slowly nodded. "I do..."

Then, to dad's further surprise, the orchids suddenly rose back up, looking as beautiful as ever before a number of bruises appeared on my face and sides. Dad cried out my name just as I had fainted...

I woke up what seemed like hours later completely healed...
1541111121222212222.title: Reader's choice

15411111212222122221.content:
Dad smiled upon seeing me open my eyes. "You gave me quite the scare, young lady." Lightly scolding, he said. "Fortunately, I know all the shortcuts here so I was able to get you to Dr Willard almost immediately."

"What happened?" Groggy, I demanded. "the last thing I remember is feeling sorry for the poor ghost orchids that man trampled upon."

"You have a rare magickal ability known as karma healing." Calmly, Dr. Willard explained. "You can take someone's pain and make it your own and heal yourself rapidly thereafter." He smiled. "I have this same ability so I can confidently say that, with practice, you will be able to heal yourself instantaneously as you heal others."

"In short, Tia, you are a healer witch." With a hint of pride, dad said. "Healers are highly regarded, you have a bright future ahead of you."

"Yes, but this must be kept quiet, for the most part." Serious, Dr Willard said. "If word got out, students who hurt themselves doing something foolish will be tempted to go to you rather than me to avoid getting demerits for reckless use of magick." He sighed. "I went through that trouble in my youth and I do not wish to see you deal with it."

I quickly nodded in agreement. "I won't say a word." Serious, I promised.

Dr Willard nodded, satisfied. "I expect you to see me once a week for lessons so you can hone your talent." Serious, he said. "If anyone asks, you are taking a class for extra credit; which is, in fact, the truth."

Shortly after, I walked out of the infirmary with dad to meet with the Magistra who seemed concerned. "Did that intruder harm you as well, Miss Wardwell?"

I shook my head. "He did last year, at the orphanage." Calmly, I explained. "I'm here due to another issue."

Dad smiled and whispered in the magistra's ear to which she smiled and turned to me. "Don't let your little secret slip, young lady." Bemused, she said. "You are going to have enough trouble with suitors for this coming ball."

I shuddered slightly at the thought of boys trying to sweep me off my feet to which dad chuckled. "Not to worry." Amused, he said. "I have a feeling only the bravest or the boldest will approach you to ask to take you to the ball."
15411111212222122221.title: in the infirmary.

154111112122221222212.content:
The next morning, I sought out Eva. I found her examining a dress in a mirror, occasionally tapping it with her wand to change its color or style. "May I ask you something?"

She turned to look at me. "Oh, hi, Tia. Okay if I work on my gown for the Mabon Ball while we talk?"

"Sure." I sat on her bed. "In fact, that's kind of what I wanted to ask you about." I screwed up my courage. "What is the Mabon Ball? Dad says that I'm going to have boys asking me to go to it, and I don't know anything about it."

"Well, you can relax at least a little bit," she said. "It's mainly a big deal for sixth- and seventh-years. For the younger students, it's more like what the cowan call a mixer, just an occasion for kids to get together. Of course, kids are still encouraged to ask each other. It helps to get them to learn consent, something I hear the cowan schools have a problem with."

"Oh." As I got up and headed for the door, I asked, "If you had a secret, who would you tell?"

"As few people as possible. Otherwise, it wouldn't be a secret anymore, would it? Take care, Tia."
154111112122221222212.title: the next morning.

1541111121222212222122.content:
Classes were uneventful for the most part. In fact, I found them fun. My research on boys was rather slow, though. Many of boys I questioned seemed to feel awkward to even be near me. "I think I bit more than I can chew on this extra credit assignment." Wincing, I said. "Boys seem embarrassed to talk about their issues."

"It's not their issues they are uncomfortable with." Smiling, Professor Good said. "It's explaining them to a girl." She chuckled. "It's similar to a girl trying to explain their issues to a boy. You have to be the gender to understand it fully."

"Not too keen on that." Wincing, you said.

Professor Good chuckled. "Try the library." Kindly, she said.

I blushed at that, not having thought of it at first. "Thank you."

In the library, as I was studying, I was startled by a small voice beside me. "E-Excuse me, Miss Miss Wardwell." Stammering, he said.

I turned, surprised to find a boy, no taller than myself nervously holding a folded piece of paper. "I- I'm..." He blushed terribly. "My name is Rio Mage." Shyly, he said. "I- I was wondering if... if you would go to the Mabon Ball with me next weekend."

Now it was my turn to blush terribly. Rio was rather cute with his short forest brown hair and gentle green eyes. He was the first person to summon the courage to ask me and he was almost exactly my height. I sensed no malaise from him, just nervousness and I shyly smiled. "I'd love to."

The boy grinned ear to ear. "Okay, I- I'll pick you up at your house then...?" Nervous, he asked. "He gulped. "Maybe I should introduce myself to your father as well."

"He won't bite you." Smiling, I said. "Still, it is gentleman like to meet the father of your escort before going to the dance."

******************************************************************** ********


Later that night, I told dad about the small boy who has asked me to the dance and he chuckled, surprising me. "The shiest boy in all the first years and he had the courage to ask you first." Bemused, he said. "I am pleased you were asked by someone so kind hearted."


I smiled at that then gasped as dad and I heard a loud painful yelp! Dad sighed and looked out the window. "It seems we have a young male suitor whose found some bad luck." half grinning, he said. "Stay here. I do not want him to see your healing abilities in case he is a cowan."

I watched, staying behind the protection of dad's three dogs. "You there!" dad thundered, "This is a private school! What are you doing here?"

The boy gave a mumbled response i did not hear. ""Regardless of the reason, we can not have you or anyone else trespassing." seriously, dad said. "I must ask you to come with me."

The boy stood but cried out again as he tried to walk. Dad sighed wearily before taking the boy into his arms. "Consider yourself thankful all you did was twist your ankle, young man." he said.

Dad then took the boy into the school. Nearly an hour later, he returned, muttering to himself. "Sloppy, real sloppy." Huffing, he said under his breath.

"Is everything okay, dad?" Wincing, I asked.

"That was a cowan friend of Samuel Proctor." Softly, dad explained. "Because security forgot to give plausible explanations for both person's vanishings, he sneaked in to check up on him."

"That is a good friend." Smiling, I said.

"Perhaps." Calmly, dad said. "However, there are some secrets than simply must be kept for the safety of all those involved."
1541111121222212222122.title: Two daring boys.

15411111212222122221221.content:
The next day, I didn't head back to the cottage right away. I heard there was to be a sleepover of sorts, with the students in each hall gathering. It was to be an official school function, so pranks would be forbidden.

I went home to read up on boys, when I heard Dad's voice coming from inside the cottage. This was different, as I usually found Dad reading when I came home. I could hear him talking about the pictures on the wall. "I've loved all my pups," he said, "but I really felt it when my little girl came into my life."

When I got to the door, I realized what had got him talking, as I heard a quieter voice inside with him. When I opened the door, I saw that it was Rio, keeping his promise to ask Dad's permission to take me to the Mabon Ball. "Ah, there's my girl," Dad said as I came in.

Rio stood up immediately. Ever the gentleman, I thought.

"Good to see you again, Tia."

"I think Rio will be a fine young man, Tia. If you'd like him, I see no reason why he can't accompany you at the Mabon Ball."

I smiled. "I'd like that very much, Dad."

"Then it's settled. I'll need to make arrangements, so you can pick out a gown to wear. I'll see you in a few weeks, Rio." Rio's hand disappeared into Dad's.
15411111212222122221221.title: Dad meets Rio Mage.

choices: A boy tries to crash the party.
154111112122221222212211.content:
The sleepover was held that night in Chalice Hall, where we met up with an upperclasswoman who seemed to have been waiting for me to arrive. She easily stood two feet taller than me with shoulder length brown hair and blue eyes and wore a prefect badge on her sleeve. She smiled politely at me, making me wince only I was not wincing at her. I had caught a glimpse of the girl, Nico Child who still seemed rattled by her encounter with her attacker. Seeing me wince, the girl sighed.

"You have nothing to fear from pranks tonight, Miss Wardwell." Serious, she said. "This sleepover is a school function, to allow all the students, young and old, to get to know each other."

"Actually, I was wincing at poor Nico Child." Softly, I said. "I saw the man attack her in the garden that night." I sighed. "He attacked me too, last year at the orphanage."

The girl raised a single eyebrow. "Did he now?" Concerned, she asked. "Are you permitted to talk about it?"

I nodded. "He was a blackmailing con artist named Michael Cort." Serious, I replied. "Dad scared him good and handed him over to the police."

The girl smiled. "Then it is unlikely you or Miss Child will ever see that man again." Kindly, she said. "I am Melissa Strange, captain of the seventh year prefects. We do what we can to ensure the safety of all students." She motioned me to enter. "Please, Enjoy the sleepover."

I entered the hall where I was greeted by another upperclassman girl wearing a prefect badge. "Bright blessings, Miss Wardwell." Smiling, she said. "I am Melissa Stonehenge, second captain of the prefects." She giggled. "I must tell you that you and a few others have become quite the celebrities among the seventh year boys."

I blushed at that. "I- I'm no one special." Timidly, I said.

Melissa smiled. "You have held your own against more pranks than any other first year student in Ravenscroft history." Bemused, she said. "Make no mistake, you are special in more ways than one." She sighed before changing the subject. "Has any boy dared to ask you out to the Mabon Ball?"

I smiled, nodding. "A shy first year named Rio Mage." Softly, I said. "He is quite the gentleman. He even asked dad for permission."

Melissa shook her head. "Shy but brave." Bemused, she said.

I smiled at that and Melissa left me to enjoy the festivities. I saw several girls there, all talking among themselves around various tables where a wide variety of snacks were being offered. At the most isolated table I saw Nico standing with Rachel and Melissa Strange talking. Nearby was Nico Child talking with Sam Procter. They stopped upon seeing me approach. "Bright blessings." Nervously, I said.

"Bright blessings." Sam replied. "We were just talking about girl issues."

"That and nightmares." Shuddering, Nico muttered.

"I was there when you were attacked." Surprising Nico, I said. "That man attacked me too last year when I was at the orphanage." Shuddering, I added, "I had nightmares for days after that."

I went on to explain who the man was, my own encounter with him and what had happened after dad had pulled him away from Nico and Rachel. This brought a small grin to Nico's face. "I'm guessing we won't ever be seeing him again." Softly, she said. "That makes me feel better."
