"I have been told by the other seventh years here that I've become quite a celebrity among the seventh year boys." With a nervous grin, Sam said. "So far, no boy has dared to ask me to the Mabon Ball."

"Same here." Smiling slightly, Nico said. "only it's because I managed to hold my own against a notorious seventh year prankster named Tyler Cohan."

I smiled at that. "It would be ironic if he ends up being the one to ask you to the ball."

Nico laughed at that. "It would be ironic, wouldn't it?" Bemused, she asked. Then her grin turned into a smile. "It would be more ironic if I'm the one to ask him."

We all laughed at that. "I was asked to the ball by a shy first year named Rio Mage." Smiling, I said.

Nico smiled and raised a glass. "To the celebrities."

I grinned at that and took up a glass as did Sam. "To the celebrities." We all said, toasting each other.

As we talked, I spotted the nervous first year girl, Winnie Alexander slowly enter the hall for the sleepover. With her was her roommate, whom i had not met yet. Catching their eye, I politely waved them over...
154111112122221222212211.title: The sleepover

1541111121222212222122111.content:
Winnie was about five feet tall, with mid-back blond hair and blue eyes. She walked over to us with an air of uncertainty, with her roommate at her side. She was about her height, with short brown hair and brown eyes. "Bright blessings." Politely, she said. "I'm Tanith, and this is my roommate, Winnie."

"I am Tia Wardwell, and this is Sam Proctor and Nico Child." Smiling, I said. "We were just talking about how we all seemed to have become celebrities here on campus."

"I sort of know the feeling." Blushing, Winnie said. "We overheard you talking about a seventh year asking you to the Mabon Ball." She winced adding, "It would be rather inappropriate for a seventeen year old to date and eleven year old."

I giggled at that. "Oh, heavens no!" Bemused, I said.

"It's just a running gag among the professors here." Smiling, Sam said. "I was a bit nervous when I first heard it too."

"Perhaps you heard it." Smiling as well, Nico said. "Don't be surprised if a seventh year asks you to the ball."

Winnie thought back a moment before blushing further. "Mrs Procter said that to me on my first full day when I cast that powerful illusion in the cafeteria."

"So you were the one who caused that commotion." Surprised, Nico said. "That was very impressive."

"It took a lot out of me." Nervous, Winnie said.

"We've all used magick to the point of exhausting ourselves." Blushing, I said. Giggling, I added, "I guess you are a celebrity too."

Winnie giggled back. "I guess..."

Tanith smiled. "I heard what you did to Taylor Cohan." Bemused, she said. "My older sister told me all about it. Perhaps his younger brother, Charles will ask you to the ball. He is a first year as well."

Nico blushed at that. "I think that would be very ironic." He then smiled. "Has anyone asked either of you two?"

"I'm going to the ball with a shy first year named Andy Gale." Smiling, Winnie replied. "He had his older sister, Anna ask for him but I spotted him watching from the bushes behind her." She giggled. "He's really sweet, once you get him to open up."

The sleepover went smoothly, a good time was had by all and we were all escorted back to our dorms by seventh year students early the following morning.
1541111121222212222122111.title: Winnie and I talk.

15411111212222122221221111.content:
The time had finally come for the Mabon Ball. The weather was perfect and the moon was full, at its closest in nearly a century. As such, it was announced that the ball would be held outside, in the spacious courtyard behind Wand and Cauldron Hall. Dad and I were very busy the morning before, preparing everything for the event. Tables and chairs were set up around the courtyard with various small huts prepared past the groves and orchards. I wrinkled my nose at the huts, turning to Dad. "Are those set up for what I think?" Softly, I asked.

Dad smiled before giving me a nod. "For the upperclassmen, the Mabon Ball is more of a romantic event." Calmly, he replied. "No underclassmen are permitted to enter the huts."

I could only wince at that. "Ew..."

Dad chuckled. "You will think differently in a few years." Bemused, he said. He motioned to various objects we had set up in the past few hours. "The torches surrounding the courtyard are magickal, used to keep insects and other pests out for the event, so we can enjoy ourselves."

"I take it the large tables are for the food, so everyone can help themselves?' curious, I asked.

Dad shook his head. "The food materializes onto each student's plate upon sitting down to eat." Serious, he replied. "The head chef is a clairvoyant, she knows what everyone is hungry for the moment they sit down."

"I don't think i have ever met the head chef." Curious, I said.

Dad blushed slightly. "Her name is Summer West, a very shy woman in her mid-thirties." Softly, he explained. "She and I, well..."

I tried not to smile, knowing that Dad had a crush on someone, and decided to change the subject. "How will the ball start?"

Dad sighed, happy that I had changed the subject. "The boys will enter the courtyard from Wand Hall, while the girls will enter from Cauldron Hall." Calmly, he replied. "They will bow to their chosen partner, and escort each other to their designated spot."

Looking at the marked tables, I noticed a pattern. "It's like the points on a map." Surprised, I said. "Seventh years to the north, the staff to the south..."

"Not quite." Chuckling, dad said. He motioned to the marked tables. "The faculty and staff will face the seventh years on either side of the courtyard. The sixth, fifth, and fourth years will be to their right, while the third, second, and first years will be to their left. Each will take turns dancing to various styles of music."

I heard my stomach grumble. "Which is first, the eating or the dancing?"

Dad laughed. "First is a long and boring speech from the Magister, Daniel Cochrane, and the Magistra, Heather Gardner." Bemused, he replied. "Then comes the meal, and then the dancing, with meals in between each dance, as well as small events, games and contests."

"Like what?" Curious, I asked.

"Crowing the top first year for one." smiling, Dad replied. "You are definitely in the running, having foiled the most prank attempts by the seventh years."

I blushed at that, but Dad quickly changed the subject. "Come on, I'm sure you've built up an appetite helping me all morning. Let's have lunch."

info.description:
I'm an 11-year-old, ready to start school at Ravenscroft Academy. It's a rather exclusive school, more so than most. Not because of racial or financial restrictions, but because it's exclusively for the teaching of witches.

Of course, you've gotta have rules:

1) First person, past tense.

2) Don't kill the main character.

3) Sex, if age-appropriate, is fine, but don't go into detail.

4) Keep the language PG-13.

5) Pop-culture witches are fictional characters in this story. Don't introduce anybody to Harry Potter, the Halliwell sisters, etc.

Here's a short glossary for the less-familiar words we'll be using:

athame: A ceremonial dagger, used for drawing magick circles or cutting or carving for sacred purposes. Must be handled with great care; if the athame ever draws blood - even accidentally - it will be useless for magick.

Blessed be: A common salutation among witches. May be used as greeting or farewell.

Book of Shadows: The spellbook of a witch or coven, so called because it should be kept hidden.

Bright blessings: A variation on Blessed be. Some witches only use one term, and some use one for greeting and the other for farewell.

cowan: A person who is not a witch. Singular or plural.

magick: This spelling is used to distinguish between witchcraft and stage magic.

Here are a couple of characters to get started:

Alex Weaver was brought up Wiccan, so he's used to his parents not being like others in the neighborhood. On his eleventh birthday, however, he learns that his mother is an actual witch. Moreover, he's a witch, too, and must go to Ravenscroft to learn magick.

Winnie Alexander was brought up in an evangelical household, taught that anything to do with witchcraft was the Devil's work. So it's a bit of a shock when it seems that a clerical error has sent her to Ravenscroft. It's a bigger shock, though, when they tell her that she is also a witch.
